BMGT488F.title: Special Topics in Logistics, Business, and Public Policy; Introduction to Sports Management II

BMGT490H.title: Quest Consulting and Innovation Practicum
BMGT490H.description: Final course in the QUEST Honors Fellows Program three-course curriculum. Based on a team-based consulting project with one of QUEST's professional partners. A project advisor and professional champion supervise each student team. Requires extensive out-of-class work.

BMGT491.title: Defining Consulting and Innovation Projects
BMGT491.description: Cultivate relationships with new and current corporate partners and prepare project scopes for QUEST's capstone course, BMGT/ENES 490H. Requires independent work communicating with clients and class visits to a variety of potential project sites.

BMGT494H.title: Honors Study
BMGT494H.description: Second semester of the senior year. The student shall continue and complete the research initiated in BMGT 493, additional reports may be required at the discretion of the faculty advisor and Assistant Dean of Undergraduate Studies.
BMGT494H.restriction: Permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business; and must be in the Smith School Honors Fellows program.

BMGT495.title: Strategic Management
BMGT495.description: A case-based course where students learn to play the role of the "strategic manager" who defines the scope of its business operations and, within the chosen scope, how the firm will compete against rivals.  This course focuses on how a firm can both formulate effective business-level and corporate-level strategies to achieve competitive advantage and earn above average profits.

BMGT495H.title: Strategic Management
BMGT495H.description: A case-based course where students learn to play the role of the "strategic manager" who defines the scope of its business operations and, within the chosen scope, how the firm will compete against rivals.  This course focuses on how a firm can both formulate effective business-level and corporate-level strategies to achieve competitive advantage and earn above average profits.

BMGT495M.title: Strategic Management
BMGT495M.description: A case-based course where students learn to play the role of the "strategic manager" who defines the scope of its business operations and, within the chosen scope, how the firm will compete against rivals.  This course focuses on how a firm can both formulate effective business-level and corporate-level strategies to achieve competitive advantage and earn above average profits.

BMGT496.title: Business Ethics and Society
BMGT496.description: A study of the standards of business conduct, morals and values as well as the role of business in society with consideration of the sometimes conflicting interests of and claims on the firm and its objectives. Emphasizes a strategic approach by business to the management of its external environment.
BMGT496.prerequisite: 1 course in BMGT; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BMGT498L.title: Special Topics in Business and Management; Innovo Consulting Practicum: Transform Learning

BMGT498M.title: Special Topics in Business and Management; Business Consulting: Social Enterprise & Impact Organizations

BMGT808D.title: Special Topics in Information Systems; Information Systems Economics I

BMGT808E.title: Special Topics in Information Systems; Information Systems Economics II

BMGT808R.title: Special Topics in Information Systems; Research Seminar in Decision, Operations and Information Technologies

BMGT818B.title: Special Topics in Accounting and Information Assurance; Topics in Financial Accounting

BMGT818R.title: Special Topics in Accounting and Information Assurance; Workshop in Accounting Research

BMGT828.title: Independent Study in Business and Management

BMGT838O.title: Special Topics in Operations Management/Management Science; Seminar in Operations Management

BMGT838R.title: Special Topics in Operations Management/Management Science; Research Seminar in Decision, Operations and Information Technologies

BMGT848F.title: Special Topics in Finance; Workshop in Finance Research

BMGT858E.title: Special Topics in Marketing; Experimental Design

BMGT858G.title: Special Topics in Marketing; Analytical Modeling

BMGT858L.title: Special Topics in Marketing; Marketing Strategy

BMGT858R.title: Special Topics in Marketing; Marketing Research Seminar

BMGT868C.title: Special Topics in Organizational Behavior/Human Resource Management; Career and Professionalization Workshop in Management and Organization

BMGT868P.title: Special Topics in Organizational Behavior/Human Resource Management; Organizational Behavior and Human Resource Management Presentations

BMGT878C.title: Special Topics in Strategic Management and Entrepreneurship; Cross Discilpinary Workshop in Strategy and Entrepreneurship

BMGT878P.title: Special Topics in Strategic Management and Entrepreneurship; Strategy and Entrepreneurship PhD Presentations

BMGT888E.title: Special Topics in Supply Chain Management; Seminar in Supply Chain Management Research

BMGT888P.title: Special Topics in Supply Chain Management; People and Performance

BMGT888W.title: Special Topics in Supply Chain Management; Workshop in Supply Chain Management

BSCI103.title: The World of Biology
BSCI103.description: An introduction to modern biology for the non-science major. Major themes include molecular biology, cell biology, evolution and organismal biology. Relevance of study of biology to modern human life will be emphasized.

BSCI103M.title: The World of Biology
BSCI103M.description: An introduction to modern biology for the non-science major. Major themes include molecular biology, cell biology, evolution and organismal biology. Relevance of study of biology to modern human life will be emphasized.

BSCI120.title: Insects
BSCI120.description: A survey of the major groups of insects, their natural history, and their relationships with humans and their environment. Course not acceptable toward major requirements in Biological Sciences, Chemistry or Biochemistry.

BSCI124.title: Plant Biology for Non-Science Students
BSCI124.description: A basic course in plant biology specifically designed for the non-science student. Emphasis is placed on an evolutionary and ecological approach to studying fundamental concepts and processes of plants, their place in the biosphere, the importance of plants to man, and the manner in which humans impact on plants and their environment. This course will not count toward graduation requirements for any student in Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Biochemistry or the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.
BSCI124.restriction: For non-science majors only; and must not have completed BSCI105; and must not have completed BSCI170 or BSCI171.

BSCI125.title: Plant Biology Laboratory
BSCI125.description: An introduction to the biology of plants with emphasis on the processes by which plants function, the diversity of plants, and the importance of plants to humans. This course will not count toward graduation requirements for any student in Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Biochemistry or the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources. CORE Lab Science.
BSCI125.restriction: For non-science majors only; and must not have completed BSCI105; and must not have completed BSCI170 or BSCI171.

BSCI160.title: Principles of Ecology and Evolution
BSCI160.description: Basic principles of biology with special emphasis on  ecological and evolutionary biology.
BSCI160.prerequisite: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.

BSCI161.title: Principles of Ecology and Evolution Lab
BSCI161.description: Basic laboratory principles of biology with special emphasis on ecological and evolutionary biology.
BSCI161.prerequisite: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.

BSCI170.title: Principles of Molecular & Cellular Biology
BSCI170.description: Basic principles of biology with special emphasis on cellular and molecular biology.
BSCI170.prerequisite: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher. Prerequisite:

BSCI170C.title: Principles of Molecular & Cellular Biology
BSCI170C.description: Basic principles of biology with special emphasis on cellular and molecular biology.
BSCI170C.prerequisite: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.

BSCI171.title: Principles of Molecular & Cellular Biology Laboratory
BSCI171.description: Basic laboratory principles of biology with special emphasis on cellular and molecular biology.
BSCI171.prerequisite: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher. Prerequisite:

BSCI171S.title: Principles of Molecular & Cellular Biology Laboratory
BSCI171S.description: Basic laboratory principles of biology with special emphasis on cellular and molecular biology.
BSCI171S.prerequisite: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.

BSCI201.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology I
BSCI201.description: Anatomy and physiology of the skeletal, muscular, neural, endocrine, an sensory systems. Course not acceptable toward major requirements in Biological Sciences, Chemistry or Biochemistry.
BSCI201.prerequisite: BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

BSCI202.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology II
BSCI202.description: Anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, immune, digestive, urinary and reproductive systems. Course not acceptable toward major requirements in Biological Sciences, Chemistry or Biochemistry.
BSCI202.prerequisite: BSCI201; or permission of CMNS-Biology department.

BSCI207.title: Principles of Biology III - Organismal Biology
BSCI207.description: The diversity, structure and function of organisms as understood from the perspective of their common physicochemical principles and unique evolutionary histories.
BSCI207.prerequisite: BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106. And BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105. And must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in CHEM131.

BSCI222.title: Principles of Genetics
BSCI222.description: Principles and mechanisms of heredity and gene expression. Considers plant, animal, and microbial organisms.
BSCI222.prerequisite: CHEM131 and CHEM132; and (BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106); and (BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105). Or must have completed BSCI105 or (BSCI170 and BSCI171); and two semesters of chemistry.

BSCI223.title: General Microbiology
BSCI223.description: Fundamental concepts in morphology, physiology, genetics, immunology, ecology, and pathogenic microbiology. Applications of microbiology to medicine, the food industry and biotechnology.

BSCI279.title: Supplemental Study; Supplemental Study in Biology

BSCI283.title: Principles of Microbiology
BSCI283.description: Introduction to microorganisms designed for science majors. Genetic principles underlying microbial abilities; microbial structure-function relationships; metabolism, physiology, and ecology of microorganisms; interactions between microorganisms (including pathogens) and their hosts.

BSCI328R.title: Special Topics in Entomology; Ecology of Organic Pest Management

BSCI329H.title: Instructional Assistance Practicum; Honors Instructional Assistance Practicum

BSCI330.title: Cell Biology and Physiology
BSCI330.description: Biochemical and physiological mechanisms underlying cellular function. Properties of cells which make life possible and mechanisms by which cells provide energy, reproduce, and regulate and integrate with each other and their environment.
BSCI330.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in CHEM131 and CHEM132. And minimum grade of C- in BSCI170 and BSCI171; or minimum grade of C- in BSCI105.

BSCI334.title: Mammalogy
BSCI334.description: Introduction to the biology of mammals, including evolution, physiological, and behavioral specializations.
BSCI334.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI207. And minimum grade of C- in BSCI160 and BSCI161; or minimum grade of C- in BSCI106.

BSCI335.title: Mammalogy Laboratory
BSCI335.description: Lab and field techniques for the study of mammals, focusing on their identification, anatomy, histology, spatial distribution, ecology, and behavior.
BSCI335.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI160 and BSCI161; or minimum grade of C- in BSCI106. And minimum grade of C- in BSCI207; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BSCI334.

BSCI337.title: Biology of Insects
BSCI337.description: An overview of the biology, evolution and diversity of insects and their relatives. Insect morphology, physiology, behavior and ecology; the impact of insects on humanity and the management of pest insect populations; assembly of an insect collection is required.
BSCI337.prerequisite: BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106; or permission of CMNS-Entomology department.

BSCI338F.title: Special Topics in Biology; iGEM Research Seminar

BSCI338R.title: Special Topics in Biology; Darwinian Medicine

BSCI338Z.title: Special Topics in Biology; Field Research

BSCI339C.title: Selected Topics in Biology; Cell Biology Lab

BSCI339E.title: Selected Topics in Biology; Developmental Genetics

BSCI339F.title: Selected Topics in Biology; Neurophysiology of Cells & Circuits

BSCI339Q.title: Selected Topics in Biology; Diseases Due to Dysfunctional Cell Organelles

BSCI339R.title: Selected Topics in Biology; Membranes and Biological Interfaces

BSCI339T.title: Selected Topics in Biology; The Science of Complementary and Alternative Medicine

BSCI348.title: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics

BSCI348A.title: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Scientific Teaching Internship

BSCI348P.title: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Introductory Biology Curriculum and Instruction Practicum

BSCI348Q.title: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics: Introductory Biology Learning Assistantship

BSCI348R.title: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Microbiology Internship

BSCI348T.title: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Research Methods for Terrapin Teachers

BSCI353.title: Principles of Neuroscience
BSCI353.description: Principles of nervous system function, ranging from molecular and cellular basis of neuron function through nervous system integration.
BSCI353.prerequisite: 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (BSCI207, BSCI330).

BSCI360.title: Principles of Animal Behavior
BSCI360.description: Study of animal behavior with emphasis on its evolution and function. Topics include genetic basis of behavior, communication, aggression, foraging, cooperation, mate selection, and relevance for conservation.
BSCI360.prerequisite: BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106. And BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105. And BSCI222.

BSCI361.title: Principles of Ecology
BSCI361.description: Basic principles of population, community, and ecosystem ecology. Use o these principles to predict possible consequences of human-caused changes in the environment and to understand the level of uncertainty of those predictions.
BSCI361.prerequisite: BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106. And (MATH130 or MATH140).

BSCI370.title: Principles of Evolution
BSCI370.description: Understanding evolutionary processes in a natural and human environment including adaptation; DNA sequence, protein, and genome evolution; evolution of developmental mechanisms; mechanisms of evolutionary change (mutation, natural selection, drift); epidemiology; coevolution and biological control; speciation; comparative methods; extinction and conservation; human evolution.

BSCI378H.title: Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics Department Honors Seminar
BSCI378H.description: Required seminar for all students participating in departmental honors research program.

BSCI379G.title: Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics Department Research; Research in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics

BSCI379H.title: Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics Department Honors Research
BSCI379H.description: Student should consult program guidelines. Research project carried out under guidance of faculty advisor.

BSCI379L.title: Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics Department Research; Lab Research

BSCI392.title: Biology of Extinct Animals
BSCI392.description: A survey of extinct animals that have few, if any, direct living descendants. The principles governing the functional design of animals will be used to infer life styles for extinct, and frequently bizarre, organisms.

BSCI393.title: Biology of Extinct Animals Laboratory
BSCI393.description: An overview of the techniques used in paleobiological reconstructions o extinct animals.
BSCI393.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BSCI392.

BSCI398H.title: Biology Department Honors Seminar
BSCI398H.description: Required seminar for all students participating in departmental honors research program.

BSCI399.title: Biology Department Research; Biology Department Research

BSCI399H.title: Biology Department Honors Research
BSCI399H.description: A laboratory research problem; required each semester during honors participation and culminating in an honors thesis.

BSCI399L.title: Biology Department Research; Biology Lab Research

BSCI403.title: Biology of Vision
BSCI403.description: An upper level undergraduate course on the physical, molecular, and neural basis of vision.

BSCI410.title: Molecular Genetics
BSCI410.description: An advanced genetics course emphasizing the molecular basis of gene structure and function in the context of modern approaches to the genetics of humans and model organisms.
BSCI410.prerequisite: BSCI222. And must have completed CHEM233; or (CHEM231 and CHEM232).

BSCI412.title: Microbial Genetics
BSCI412.description: A laboratory/lecture based course that covers the fundamentals of mutation, mobile genetic elements and transmission genetics of microbial organisms using both classical and molecular approaches.

BSCI416.title: Human Genetics
BSCI416.description: Approaches to human genetics and applications to biology and medicine focusing on specific human genetic topics using primary research papers as the main resource.
BSCI416.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI410.

BSCI417.title: Microbial Pathogenesis
BSCI417.description: Current research in microbial pathogenesis and the molecular and cellular basis of bacterial disease. Comprehensive overview of the molecular basis of pathogenesis with a focus on model microbial systems to illustrate mechanisms of disease pathogenesis. Topics covered: how microorganisms attach to and enter cells; how host cells are damaged by microbial products; how the host responds to invasion; and host-pathogen evolution.

BSCI420.title: Cell Biology Lectures
BSCI420.description: Molecular and biochemical bases of cellular organization and function in eukaryotes.

BSCI421.title: Cell Biology
BSCI421.description: Molecular and biochemical basis of cellular organization and function in eukaryotes.

BSCI422.title: Principles of Immunology
BSCI422.description: The immune system in health and disease. Presentation and analysis of the cellular and molecular processes that comprise the immune system.

BSCI423.title: Immunology Laboratory
BSCI423.description: Current techniques for assessment of immune status and evaluation of th immune response, including monoclonal antibody production, Western blotting, cytokine assays, ELISA and flow cytometry.

BSCI433.title: Biology of Cancer
BSCI433.description: Causes and consequences of neoplastic transformations at the biochemica and cellular levels.
BSCI433.prerequisite: BSCI222 and BSCI330; or permission of CMNS-Biological Sciences UG Program.

BSCI437.title: General Virology
BSCI437.description: Discussion of the physical and chemical nature of viruses, virus cultivation and assay methods, virus replication, viral diseases with emphasis on the oncogenic viruses, viral genetics, and characteristics of the major virus groups.
BSCI437.prerequisite: BSCI222; or permission of CMNS-Biological Sciences UG Program.

BSCI440.title: Mammalian Physiology
BSCI440.description: A study of the cardiovascular, hemopoietic, gastrointestinal, renal and respiratory systems. Chemical and endocrine regulation of physiological functions in mammals. Course does not count as an upper level lab for BIOL majors (see BSCI441).
BSCI440.prerequisite: BSCI330; and (CHEM231 and CHEM232; or must have completed CHEM233). Or permission of CMNS-Biological Sciences UG Program.

BSCI441.title: Mammalian Physiology Laboratory
BSCI441.description: Laboratory exercises in experimental mammalian physiology.
BSCI441.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BSCI440.

BSCI442.title: Plant Physiology
BSCI442.description: A survey of plant physiology and development and responses and adaptation to the environment
BSCI442.prerequisite: BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105; or PLSC201. And CHEM231 and CHEM232; or CHEM237; or permission of CMNS-Biological Sciences UG Program.
BSCI442.restriction: Must not have completed ENST407; or must not have completed PLSC400.

BSCI446.title: Neural Systems
BSCI446.description: Neural development, followed by sensory, motor and integrative system organization in the central nervous system.Sponsoring Dept. (BIOL) Specialization Areas:  PHNB, GENB.
BSCI446.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI330 and BSCI353.

BSCI454.title: Neurobiology Laboratory
BSCI454.description: Basic neuroanatomical techniques, intracellular and extracellular recordings of electrical potentials from nerve and muscle.
BSCI454.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI330; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BSCI353; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in PHYS122, PHYS132, or PHYS142.

BSCI464.title: Microbial Ecology
BSCI464.description: Interaction of microorganisms with the environment, other microorganism and with higher organisms. Roles of microorganisms in the biosphere. Microorganisms and current environmental problems.
BSCI464.prerequisite: BSCI223 and CHEM241. And must have completed CHEM243; or CHEM242.

BSCI473.title: Marine Ecology
BSCI473.description: Courses in evolution and animal behavior are strongly recommended. A detailed analysis of the evolutionary ecology of marine invertebrates; emphasis on testing of theories and on current literature.

BSCI480.title: Arthropod Form and Function
BSCI480.description: Survey of the morphological, systematic and physiological diversity of the phylum Arthropoda.

BSCV182.title: Civicus and Service-Learning
BSCV182.description: Students will examine domestic societal issues and their national, regional, and local dimensions from political, economic, and policy perspectives. Students will work with local direct service non-profit organizations.
BSCV182.prerequisite: BSCV191 and BSCV181; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in SOCY105.
BSCV182.restriction: Must be in the Civicus program.

BSCV302.title: Civicus Capstone
BSCV302.description: Capstone course required for CIVICUS citation. Supervised internship, community service, or research project on civil society topic. Application and continued study of skills and concepts, grounded in the social sciences, relevant to understanding and effectively dealing with contemporary social issues.

BSGC102.title: Global Issues
BSGC102.description: A survey of some of the major global challenges facing society today, such as human trafficking, nuclear security, and global health. We explore contending approaches to resolving problems, culminating in a major group project.
BSGC102.restriction: Must be in Global Communities Living-Learning program.

BSGC398A.title: BSGC Experiential Learning in Global Communities: Global Service; Alternative Break/International Service

BSOS388B.title: Behavioral and Social Sciences Special Topics; Innovation and Social Change: Do Good Now

BSST331.title: Response to Terrorism
BSST331.description: Explores the manners in which a variety of different actors respond to both terrorist incidents and the threat of terrorism. Examines local responses to terrorists incidents; local impacts of terrorism including effects on individual and group attitudes and behaviors; policy decisions made in response to both terrorist attacks and the threat of terrorism; terrorism prevention, deterrence, interdiction, and mitigation efforts; and individual and community recovery from terrorist attacks.
BSST331.restriction: Must be in the Terrorism Studies minor program.

BSST338G.title: Special Topics in Terrorism Studies; Ideology and Social Conditions in the Making of Terrorism

BSST338Y.title: Special Topics in Terrorism Studies; Seminar in Terrorism Studies: The New Theater of Terror:    Online Terrorism

BSST386.title: Experiential Learning in Terrorism Studies
BSST386.description: This course will supplement student's experiential learning experience, or internship in the field of terrorism studies and homeland security with guided reflection on their experiences.

BSST399M.title: Individual Study in Terrorism Studies; Community Resilience, Engagement, and Dialogue Career Development Part 4

BSST399T.title: Individual Study in Terrorism Studies; Teaching Terrorism

BSST631.title: Societal Impacts of and Responses to Terrorism
BSST631.description: Explores the manners in which a variety of different actors respond to both terrorist incidents and the threat of terrorism. Examines local responses to terrorist incidents; local impacts of terrorism including effects on individual and group attitudes and behaviors; policy decisions made in response to both terrorist attacks and the threat of terrorism; terrorism prevention, deterrence, interdiction, and mitigation efforts; and individual and community recovery from terrorist attacks.
BSST631.restriction: Must be in Terrorism Analysis Graduate Certificate Program; or permission of department.

BSST633.title: Research Methods in Terrorism and Counterterrorism
BSST633.description: Provides students with the opportunity to conduct original research, while exposing them to analytical tools relevant to the study of terrorism. Students will work with a range of data sources on domestic and international terrorism, and will be tasked with using data to test hypotheses related to the causes, behaviors, and/ or impacts of terrorism.

BUAC758Z.title: Special Topics in Accounting and Information Assurance; International Tax II

BUAC759.title: Independent Study in Accounting and Information Assurance

BUAC786.title: Internal Auditing I: Conceptual and Institutional Framework
BUAC786.description: Provides students with an overview and basic understanding of internal auditing. Internal audit's role in internal control, risk management, business processes and risks, and Sarbanes-Oxley, Section 404 compliance efforts compliance efforts are considered. Internal auditing is presented as an integral part of effective corporate governance. Examples of assurance and consulting activities undertaken by the internal audit function, as well as the sourcing strategy (i.e., full insourcing, co-sourcing or full outsourcing models) are discussed. Students ae introduced tointernal control theory, test design concepts and internal auditing bestpractices.
BUAC786.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BUAC787.title: Internal Auditing II: Internal Audit Application and Practice
BUAC787.description: This advanced internal auditing course contains an in-depth coverage of the internal audit process. Students receive experience in planning and conducting internal audit assurance and consulting engagements. Also, students build on the theory and techniques introduced in Internal Auditing I, through practical, in-depth coverage of specific audit areas. Other matters covered include audit evidence, workpapers, audit sampling, and communicating of engagement results. Internal auditing case studies are used to reinforce the learning process.
BUAC787.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BUAC790.title: Informtion Security, Audit and Control
BUAC790.description: Builds on basic information technology (IT) courses, focusing on key issues including IT security, IT controls, and IT auditing. Addressing issues such as auditing a computer information system; assessing risks; identifying control objectives; identifying appropriate audit procedures; learning the concepts and basic features or audit software thereby providing the tools for choosing audit software; conducting an operational audit basic controls over computer information systems; and developing world-class IT control frameworks.
BUAC790.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BUDT732.title: Decision Analytics
BUDT732.description: Analytical modeling for managerial decisions using a spreadsheet environment. Includes linear and nonlinear optimization models, decision making under uncertainty and simulation models.

BUDT759.title: Independent Study in Decision and Information Technologies

BUFN750.title: Valuation in Corporate Finance
BUFN750.description: An advanced topics course in Corporate Finance dealing with valuation. Main topics will be, building pro forma statements, cost of capital, using ratios and comparables to value projects and firms, dicounted cash flow valuations, WACC and APV methods of valuation and Real Option Valuations.
BUFN750.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUFN751.title: Financial Strategy For Corporations
BUFN751.description: An advanced course in corporate finance, focusing on the issues that firms face when they plan to raise external capital from financial markets. The focus is on the financing problems faced by mid-market to large firms and on capital raised from public markets. The forms of external finance vary from simple debt or equity to more complex securities that bundle with an element of risk management.
BUFN751.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUFN755.title: Entrepreneurial Finance and Private Equity
BUFN755.description: An advanced topics course in Corporate Finance. The major emphasis is how financiers help growing firms - and in particular young start-ups - using different types of securities at different points in the industry's and firm's life. Financing arrangements and securities studied will include private equity funds and private financings placements, Venture Capital (VC) and preferred equity, Investment Banks through Initial Public Offerings (IPOs), Private equity finds, debt and leveraged buyouts. Students will learn additional techniques that will help them understand how financiers value firms and how to understand, plan and value different financing strategies.
BUFN755.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUFN758E.title: Special Topics in Finance; Financial Programming

BUFN758R.title: Special Topics in Finance; Financial Institute Risk Management

BUFN758V.title: Special Topics in Finance; Advanced Equity Modeling

BUFN758W.title: Special Topics in Finance; Applied Equity Modeling

BUFN760.title: Applied Equity Analysis
BUFN760.description: Students will learn to analyze equity securities using the basic EIC (Economy/Industry/Company) framework used in the financial industry, paying special attention to financial statement analysis. Students also will learn the primary valuation techniques used to estimate market values for equity securities.
BUFN760.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUFN761.title: Derivative Securities
BUFN761.description: Standard types of derivatives contracts are presented, and illustrated as to how they are used in practice. The theory of pricing these contracts is then presented in detail. The use of static and dynamic replication strategies, and the concept of no-arbitrage strategies is illustrated in numerous ways. Standard valuation techniques are covered, and standard formulas are presented. The theory is then applied to develop specific pricing and hedging strategies for various types of derivatives on different underlying assets. The management of the exposure of various risks is covered in detail as well.
BUFN761.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUFN762.title: Fixed Income Analysis
BUFN762.description: Describes important financial instruments which have market values that are sensitive to interest rate movements. Develops tools to analyze interest rate sensitivity and value fixed income securities. Defines and explains the vocabulary of the bond management business.
BUFN762.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUFN763.title: Portfolio Management
BUFN763.description: Provides training that is important in understanding the investment process - the buy side of the financial world. Specifically, the objective is to provide graduate-level instruction in the following topics, both in theory and in using financial markets data to test the basic theory and practice of portfolio choice and equilibrium pricing models and their implications for efficient portfolios.
BUFN763.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUFN764.title: Quantitative Investment Strategy
BUFN764.description: Provides an introduction to quantitative techniques of selecting equities, as used commonly among long-short equity hedge funds and other quantitative equity asset management companies. Statistical factor models are developed to locate stocks with higher expected returns, based on the observable characteristics of the stocks. Implementation issues, including statistical estimation, backtesting and portfolio construction, are covered, as is performance evaluation.
BUFN764.restriction: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUFN772.title: Bank Management
BUFN772.description: Analyze and discuss readings in bank management,with primary focus on the measurement and management of risk, including credit, market, and interest rate risk. Look at the management of liquid reserves. Examine the special nature of financial institutions, incorporating their functions, policies, services, and regulation. Study the evolving nature of the financial services inductry, by reading the financial press and by having outside practitioner speakers. Focus is on U.S. banks.
BUFN772.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BULM724.title: Negotiations in Supply Chain Management
BULM724.description: This high experiential course will improve students' negotiation skills and capacity to acquire and effectively use power. By using a variety of assessment tools, feedback sources, skill-building exercises, and exercise debriefings, the class will increase students' negotiating self-confidence and improve their capacity to achieve win-win solutions to individual, team, and organizational problems. The course is designed to enhance students negotiating self confidence and improve students analytical skills, interpersonal skills, creativity (e.g., identifying creative solutions to conflict), and persuasive abilities.
BULM724.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BULM733.title: Global Trade Logistics
BULM733.description: Acquaints students with managerial issues in international logistics and transportation, and provides students with an understanding of issues related to import/export management and the global marketplace.
BULM733.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BULM758C.title: Special Topics in Logistics, Business and Public Policy; Assessing & Managing Supply Chain Risks

BUMK716.title: Brand Management
BUMK716.description: Brand names are valuable assets for firms. Effective brand management is critical to maintaining the long-term profitability of products and services. Topics include understanding brands from the customer's perspective, building brand equity, measuring brand equity, leveraging brand equity, managing brand portfolios and managing brands over time.
BUMK716.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUMK717.title: Integrated Marketing Communications
BUMK717.description: Marketing communications are a complex but critical component of marketing strategy. Topics include communication tools: advertising, sales promotions, corporation communications, one-on-one or direct marketing, public relations, internet communications, sponsorship/events marketing, and marketing communcation plans: defining objectives, implementing the plan, and measuring communications effectiveness. Achieving integration in the content, look, and feel of all marketing communications is stressed.
BUMK717.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUMK722.title: Customer Equity Management
BUMK722.description: Focuses on managing customers of a business, whether in B2B or B2C space, as a portfolio of equity; understanding the current and future value of customers to the business; selective acquisition, development, and retention of customers using latest developments in information technology.
BUMK722.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUMO714.title: Competitive and Collaborative Negotiation
BUMO714.description: Increase negotiating self-confidence and improve capacity to achieve win-win solutions to organizational problems. Improve effectiveness at finding creative solutions to conflict.
BUMO714.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUMO725.title: Networks and Influence
BUMO725.description: Focuses on networks, social capital, and influence as they relate to operating effectively in organizations. It draws heavily on emerging literature related to social capital and networks, but also integrates concepts from persuasion, communication, and motivation literatures to aid your efforts to build a successful track record for yourself and your organization.
BUMO725.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BUMO751.title: Implementing Strategy: Organizing to Compete
BUMO751.description: Organizational dynamics of competitive advantage. Impact of alternative organizational structures, planning and control systems, human resource management practices, and executive leadership styles on the implementation of archetypically different strategies.
BUMO751.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BUSI690. And must have completed MBA core requirements; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUMO754.title: Global Strategy
BUMO754.description: Focuses on the "strategic" and "organizational" questions that a company must address as it globalizes its footprint.  Among the questions that will be addressed are:  What are the potential benefits, costs, and risks associated with going abroad?  What differentiates a "global" from a "multidomestic" industry?  What are the sources of competitive advantage in a global context?

BUMO758A.title: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Strategic Growth for Emerging Social & Commercial Ventures

BUMO758K.title: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Business Consulting

BUMO758T.title: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Technology Entrepreneurship

BUMO759.title: Independent Study in Management and Organization

BUMO796.title: Leadership and Human Resource Management for Accountants and Auditors
BUMO796.description: Develops the concepts, frameworks, and skills that are important to be effective leaders and to successfully manage human resources. Topics for discussion include: Creating a motivating and empowering environment; leadership attributes, power and effective influence; building effective decision-making; strategic management of human resources; specification of the skills and competencies requisite for job success; recruiting and selecting employees to fit the job and the organization; measuring, appraising and improving performance. All of the topics selected for discussion are critical ones that every professional needs to know, regardless of functional area (not just HR professionals), and will help students become more effective consultants, managers and leaders.
BUMO796.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BUSI611.title: Managerial Accounting
BUSI611.description: Use of accounting data in corporate planning and control. Cost-volume- profit analysis, budgeting, pricing decisions and cost data, transfer pricing, activity-based management, performance measures, and standard costing.
BUSI611.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUSI621.title: Strategic and Transformational IT
BUSI621.description: Introduces students to the key issues in managing information technolog (IT) and provides an overview of how major IT applications in today's firms support strategic, opertaional, and tactical decisions. Topics include: synchroizing IT and business strategy; the transformational impacts of IT; evaluating and coping with new technologies; governing, managing, and organizing the IT function including outsourcing/offshoring considerations; assessing the business value of IT and justifying IT projects; and managing IT applications in functional areas to support strategy and business process.
BUSI621.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSI622.title: Managing Digital Business Markets
BUSI622.description: The objective is to understand the strategic and tactical issues involved in managing digital businesses and markets. Also, some of the characteristics of digital businesses and markets that make them unique and understand how companies can best manage them will be examined.
BUSI622.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSI630.title: Data, Models and Decisions
BUSI630.description: Analytical modeling of business decisions; uncertainty, risk and expected utility; regression modeling to infer relationships among variables.
BUSI630.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUSI634.title: Operations Management
BUSI634.description: Operations management is concerned with efficient and effective design and operation of business processes for delivering products and/or services. Emphasis is given to process analysis and design, capacity management and bottlenecks, waiting lines and the impact of uncertainty in process performance, quality management, lean, six-sigma, and revenue management.
BUSI634.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSI640.title: Financial Management
BUSI640.description: Focuses on the valuation of the real assets of firms as well as the valuation of stocks and bonds, the primary financial assets in an economy. While details vary, the conceptual foundations of valuation boil down to three themes: time value of money, no-arbitrage, and systematic risk.
BUSI640.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUSI650.title: Marketing Management
BUSI650.description: Analysis of marketing problems and evaluation of specific marketing efforts regarding the organization's products and services, pricing activities, channel selection, and promotion strategies in both domestic and international markets.
BUSI650.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUSI672.title: Global Supply Chain Management
BUSI672.description: Offers a practical blueprint for understanding, building, implementing, and sustaining supply chains in today's rapidly changing global supply chain environment. It will provide the student with a survey of the fast-moving Supply Chain Management discipline and practice, including the evolution of supply chain strategies, business models and technologies; current best practices in demand and supply management; and methodologies for conducting supply chain-wide diagnostic assessments and formulating process improvement plans.
BUSI672.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)).

BUSI758J.title: Special Topics in Business; SAP Software & Solutions / Enterprise Resource Planning

BUSI758L.title: Special Topics in Business; Managers in Society

BUSI758R.title: Special Topics in Business; Business Ethics

BUSI764.title: Business Law for Managers
BUSI764.description: Survey of United States legal institutions and processes as well as substantive areas of the law that affect business. Examination of tort and contract law, the legal forms of business organization and legal liability and major regulatory laws that affect business.
BUSI764.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSI771.title: New Venture Financing
BUSI771.description: Development of skills for financing new ventures (both small and potentially large). Exploration of various funding sources. Criteria used in evaluation and decision process, including commercial banks, venture capital companies, small business investment companies, underwriters, private placement-financial consultants, mortgage bankers, and small business innovative research grants (U.S. Government).
BUSI771.prerequisite: BUSI640; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSI785.title: Project Management in Dynamic Environments
BUSI785.description: Addresses project management skills that are required by successful managers in increasingly competitive and faster-moving environments. Examines fundamental concepts of successful project management, and the technical and managerial issues, methods, and techniques.
BUSI785.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSM701.title: Marketing Research Methods
BUSM701.description: The process of acquiring, classifying and interpreting primary and secondary marketing data needed for intelligent, profitable marketing decisions. Evaluation of the appropriateness of alternative methodologies, such as the inductive, deductive, survey, observational, and experimental. Recent developments in the systematic recording and use of internal and external data needed for marketing decisions.
BUSM701.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSM702.title: Consumer Behavior
BUSM702.description: Analysis of customer decision-making and how marketing strategy can be used to influence those decisions. The framework is a buyer behavior model, in which concepts from psychology, sociology, and economics are applied to individual and organizational purchase decisions. Marketing strategies of leading firms in consumer products, technology, and services (including internet services) are analyzed using a variety of case study formats. Focus is consumer behavior; however, principles can also be applied to the decision-making of business.
BUSM702.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSM713.title: Market Forecasting
BUSM713.description: Students will learn a number of market forecasting methods, each appropriate for different contexts. The majority of this course focuses on quantitative modeling techniques based on established statistical methods. We also cover non-statistical methods that are often used when empirical data is scarce. This is a very hands-on class where students will apply the forecasting methods learned to real data.
BUSM713.restriction: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BUSM765.title: Social Media and Web 2.0
BUSM765.description: Over the past years, social computing technologies such as online communities, blogs, wikis, and social networking systems have become important tools for individuals to seek information, socialize with others, get support, collaborate on work, and express themselves. Increasingly, businesses are trying to leverage web 2.0 by using social computing technologies to communicate with customers, employees, and other business partners or to build new business models. This course will review concepts and principles related to web 2.0 and examine issues and strategies associated with business use of social computing technologies.
