FMSC290.title: Family Economics
FMSC290.description: Application of economic methodology to study families under various economic situations. Examination of how decisions about marriage, divorce, fertility, consumption and time use are influenced by labor/housing markets, tax structure, social welfare benefits and other economic considerations.

FMSC302.title: Research Methods in Family Science
FMSC302.description: Introduction to the methods of the social and behavioral sciences employed in family science. The role of theory, the development of hypotheses, measurement, design, and data analysis.
FMSC302.prerequisite: Must have completed an introductory statistics course.
FMSC302.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Family Science department.

FMSC310.title: Maternal, Child and Family Health
FMSC310.description: Overview of the major issues in Maternal, Child, and Family Health in the U.S. and the world. The course will cover the social, political, environmental, and economic factors that shape the health of women, children, and families throughout the life course. It will employ the core disciplines of public health -- 1) epidemiology/biostatistics, 2) environmental health, 3) health policy and administration, and 4) social and behavioral health -- to examine these factors. The course introduces specific issues and interventions and places these issues and interventions within their broad sociohistorical context.

FMSC330.title: Family Theories and Patterns
FMSC330.description: Theory and research on the family, including a cross-cultural analysis of family patterns.

FMSC332.title: Children in Families
FMSC332.description: A family life education approach to the study of children and families. Emphasis on the interaction of children with parents, siblings, extended kin, and the community.

FMSC341.title: Personal and Family Finance
FMSC341.description: Individual and family financial strategies with emphasis on financial planning, savings, investments, insurance, income taxes, housing, and use of credit. Planning, analyzing, and controlling financial resources to resolve personal/family financial problems and to attain financial security.

FMSC381.title: Poverty, Affluence, and Families
FMSC381.description: Social, political, cultural and economic factors influencing income and wealth in American families.
FMSC381.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Family Science department.

FMSC383.title: Delivery of Human Services to Families
FMSC383.description: Processes of service delivery with special emphasis upon relationships among managers, service providers and clients. The impact of human service systems on families.
FMSC383.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Family Science department.

FMSC430.title: Gender Issues in Families
FMSC430.description: The development of historical, cultural, developmental, and psychosocial aspects of masculinity and femininity within the context of contemporary families and the implications for interpersonal relations.

FMSC431.title: Family Crises and Intervention
FMSC431.description: Family crises such as divorce, disability, substance abuse, financial problems, intra-familial abuse, and death. Theories and techniques for intervention and enhancement of family coping strategies.

FMSC432.title: Adult Development and Aging in Families
FMSC432.description: Theory, research, history, and programming related to adult development and aging in the intergenerational context of family.
FMSC432.prerequisite: PSYC100; and (SOCY100 or SOCY105). And FMSC332; or must have completed a comparable development course.
FMSC432.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Family Science department.

FMSC460.title: Violence in Families
FMSC460.description: Theories of child, spouse, and elder abuse in the family setting. Emphasis on historical, psychological, sociological and legal trends relating to physical, emotional, and sexual abuse. Introduction to methods for prevention and remediation.

FMSC477.title: Internship and Analysis in Family Science
FMSC477.description: A supervised internship and a seminar requiring analysis. Opportunities to integrate theory and practice including 120 hours of contracted field experience. Summer or fall internship contracts due May 1; Spring contracts due December 1. See department for application procedures.
FMSC477.prerequisite: FMSC383; and 9 credits in FMSC courses; and permission of SPHL-Family Science department.
FMSC477.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Family Science department.

FMSC487.title: Legal Aspects of Family Problems
FMSC487.description: Laws and legal procedures, with emphasis on adoption, marriage, divorce, annulment, and property rights, and how they affect family life.

FMSC498.title: Special Topics: Family Science; Family Studies

FMSC498H.title: Special Topics: Family Science; Family Studies Honors Thesis

FMSC498M.title: Special Topics: Family Science; Theory and Techniques of Family Mediation

FMSC610.title: Research Methods in Family Science
FMSC610.description: Research methods in family science. The role of theory, design, use of qualitative and quantitative measurement techniques, data collection and data analysis. Development of research proposals.
FMSC610.prerequisite: EDMS645; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

FMSC641.title: Couples Therapy, Theory, and Techniques
FMSC641.description: Overview of theoretical models of couple relationships and methods of facilitating growth and interaction within those relationships. Emphasis on couples with conflicting needs and expectations, and dysfunctional communication and conflict negotiation skills.

FMSC642.title: Normal and Abnormal Individual and Family Development
FMSC642.description: Normal development and psychopathology in the family system. Emphasis o parent-child relationships and application of the current Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) to family therapy.

FMSC647.title: Theory and Techniques of Family Mediation
FMSC647.description: An introduction to family mediation as an approach to helping families deal effectively with the issues associated with separation and divorce. Theory, practice, and techniques of negotiation, with an emphasis on custody, property division, and the constructive restructuring of family relationships.

FMSC651.title: Psychopathology in the Family Context
FMSC651.description: Diagnosis and treatment of psychopathology within the family context, with application of various family therapy models.
FMSC651.restriction: Must be in Couple and Family Therapy (Master's) program.

FMSC653.title: Advanced Application of MFT Models and Techniques
FMSC653.description: Advanced application and integration of family therapy skills and theoretical models in the practice of marriage and family therapy. Emphasis on treatment plans from different therapeutic models demonstrated in case presentations and supervision of therapy.
FMSC653.restriction: Must be in Couple and Family Therapy (Master's) program.

FMSC658.title: Supervised Clinical Practice of Marriage and Family Therapy; Theory and Practice of Clinical Supervision

FMSC720.title: Study Design in Maternal Child Health Epidemiology
FMSC720.description: A detailed survey of key epidemiologic study designs provided through readings, lectures, and exercises. Lectures begin by considering the evolution of epidemiologic thought and parallel developments in design of epidemiologic studies. Topics covered include assessment of causality in observational studies, investigation of acute outbreaks, survey design, cohort and case-control study designs, clinical randomized trials, and discussion of issues pertaining to measurement error in the assessment of exposures and outcomes in epdemiologic studies.

FMSC760.title: Legal Issues & Families
FMSC760.description: Analysis of marriage and family issues from a legal perspective. Review of legal decisions affecting families, including procreative rights, marriage, termination of marriage, parental and child rights, adoption, child custody, and child/family medical treatment. Relationship between family law and family policy.

FMSC780.title: Qualitative Methods in Family and Health Research
FMSC780.description: Theoretical perspectives and methodological tools to conduct research with individuals and families across the life span. Review of research designs, participant fieldwork, observation and interview projects, data collection, computer-assisted data analysis, and development of grounded theory.

FMSC879.title: Preparing Future Faculty and Professionals Seminar

FREN103.title: Intensive Elementary French
FREN103.description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of French-speaking world.
FREN103.prerequisite: Must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
FREN103.restriction: Must not have completed FREN102; and must not be a native/fluent speaker of French.

FREN203.title: Intensive Intermediate French
FREN203.description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of French-speaking world.
FREN203.prerequisite: FREN103; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
FREN203.restriction: Must not be a native/fluent speaker of French.

FREN204.title: French Grammar and Composition
FREN204.description: Intensive study of French grammar and composition.
FREN204.prerequisite: FREN201 or FREN203; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
FREN204.restriction: Not open to native/fluent speakers of French.

FREN250.title: Introduction to Cultural and Textual Analysis
FREN250.description: Introduction to cultural and textual analysis of selected readings from various genres in French literature. Taught in French.
FREN250.prerequisite: FREN204; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.  Prerequisite:
FREN250.restriction: Must not be a native/fluent speaker of French.  Restriction:

FREN250H.title: Introduction to Cultural and Textual Analysis
FREN250H.description: Introduction to cultural and textual analysis of selected readings from various genres in French literature. Taught in French.
FREN250H.prerequisite: FREN204; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
FREN250H.restriction: Must not be a native/fluent speaker of French.

FREN301.title: Composition and Style
FREN301.description: Grammatical analysis, elements of style; range of written genres.
FREN301.prerequisite: FREN250; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
FREN301.restriction: Must not be a native/fluent speaker of French.

FREN302.title: Translation: French to English
FREN302.description: Practicum in translation primarily from French to English; contrastive analysis.
FREN302.prerequisite: FREN301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

FREN303.title: Translation: English to French
FREN303.description: Practicum in translation primarily from English to French; contrastive analysis.
FREN303.prerequisite: FREN301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

FREN352.title: From the Age of Epic and Romance to the Enlightenment
FREN352.description: A survey of the chief authors and major movements of French literature from the Middle Ages to the end of the 18th century.
FREN352.prerequisite: FREN301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.Prerequisite:

FREN352H.title: From the Age of Epic and Romance to the Enlightenment
FREN352H.description: A survey of the chief authors and major movements of French literature from the Middle Ages to the end of the 18th century.
FREN352H.prerequisite: FREN301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

FREN386.title: Experiential Learning
FREN386.description: Prerequisite: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.  Restriction: Junior standing or higher.
FREN386.prerequisite: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

FREN387.title: Critical Writing on France and the French-Speaking World
FREN387.description: Intensive writing course based on focused study of issues and concerns drawn from French and Francophone literatures, films, and cultures. Elements of style, review of grammar. Taught in French.

FREN495H.title: Honors Thesis Research
FREN495H.description: The writing of a paper under the direction of a professor in this department and an oral examination. Required to fulfill the departmental honors requirement.
FREN495H.restriction: Must be admitted to the departmental honors program.

FREN498N.title: Special Topics in French Literature; 19th Century Literature

FREN498Q.title: Special Topics in French Literature; Quebec Literature/Film

FREN699K.title: Seminar; French Critical and Cultural Perspectives on Literature and Film

FREN699V.title: Seminar; Literature History of the French-Speaking Caribbean

GEMS102.title: Research Topic Exploration and Team Formation
GEMS102.description: Under the guidance of staff and visiting speakers, students will develop research topics that they will pursue for the remainder of their participation in the Gemstone program, and form into interdisciplinary teams around these topics.
GEMS102.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program.

GEMS104.title: Topics in Science, Technology and Society (STS)
GEMS104.description: An examination of how cultural, economic, political and social forces shape scientific and technological systems and, conversely, how scientific and technological systems have affected the culture, economies, organization and politics of societies. Students in the course will form small teams to carry out semester-long research on socio/technical topics related to the course theme chosen for that specific semester.
GEMS104.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program.

GEMS208E.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; Research Topic Exploration Teaching Freshmen First Time Section Leader

GEMS208F.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; Research Topic Exploration Teaching Freshmen: Returner Section Leader

GEMS208G.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; Science, Technology and Society Teaching Freshmen First Time Section Leader

GEMS208I.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; Science, Technology & Society Teaching Freshman, Returnee Section Leader

GEMS208J.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; Gems Camp

GEMS208K.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; GEMS Connect

GEMS208L.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; GEMS GSC Executive Board

GEMS208T.title: Special Topics in Leadership and Team Development; Thesis Conference Planning Team

GEMS296.title: Team Project Seminar I
GEMS296.description: This is the first of six seminars during which Gemstone students carry out multidisciplinary research with the guidance of a faculty mentor. The teams develop their working relationship, start their literature search, define their research question, and set short & long term goals.
GEMS296.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program with sophomore standing in a research team.

GEMS297.title: Team Project Seminar II
GEMS297.description: This is the second of six seminars during which Gemstone students carry out interdisciplinary research with the guidance of a faculty mentor. The team develops its website, prepares and presents its research proposal and beegins its research project.
GEMS297.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program with sophomore standing in a research team.

GEMS396.title: Team Project Seminar III
GEMS396.description: This is the third of six seminars during which Gemstone students carry out interdisciplinary research with the guidance of a faculty mentor. The team presents its progress at the Gemstone Colloquia.
GEMS396.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program with junior standing in a research team.

GEMS397.title: Team Project Seminar IV
GEMS397.description: This is the fourth of six seminars during which Gemstone students carry out interdisciplinary research with the guidance of a faculty mentor. The team further develops its website. Also they will prepare and present the team project in the poster session of Undergraduate Research Day.
GEMS397.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program with junior standing in a research team.

GEMS496.title: Project Writing Seminar
GEMS496.description: This is the fifth of six seminars during which Gemstone students carry out research with the guidance of a faculty mentor. The team finishes the analysis of their data and writes and edits its team thesis.
GEMS496.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program.

GEMS497.title: Team Thesis Defense
GEMS497.description: Gemstone teams will complete the team research project and thesis. The team will formally present the thesis to experts in the area of interest at a Team Thesis Conference before final submission.
GEMS497.restriction: Must be in the Gemstone program.

GEOG130.title: Developing Countries
GEOG130.description: An introduction to the geographic characteristics of the development problems and prospects of developing countries. Spatial distribution of poverty, employment, migration and urban growth, agricultural productivity, rural development, policies and international trade. Portraits of selected developing countries.

GEOG140.title: Natural Disasters: Earthquakes, Floods, and Fires
GEOG140.description: Catastrophic Environmental Events (CCE) that are becoming more common i this time of global environmental change and it is essential that today's students be equipped with the knowledge and skills to be leaders as we, as a society, understand the upheaval that these CCEs are causing. Students will examine how CEEs shape human society and ecosystem from the interdisciplinary perspective afforded by the field of Geography. Students will use the latest geographic science concepts and techniques in exploring these events. Using satellite imagery they will gain a multi-scale perspective of the ecological and societal aspects of the events.

GEOG201.title: Geography of Environmental Systems
GEOG201.description: A systematic introduction to the processes and associated forms of the atmosphere and earth's surfaces emphasizing the interaction between climatology, hydrology and geomorphology.

GEOG202.title: Introduction to Human Geography
GEOG202.description: Introduction to what geographers do and how they do it. Systematic stud of issues regarding social and cultural systems from a global to a local scale. Looks at the distribution of these variables and answers the question "Why here, and not there"?

GEOG211.title: Geography of Environmental Systems Laboratory
GEOG211.description: A laboratory course to accompany GEOG 201. Analysis of the components of the earth's energy balance using basic instrumentation; weather map interpretation; soil analysis; the application of map and air photo interpretation techniques to landform analysis.
GEOG211.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in GEOL120, GEOL100, or GEOG201.

GEOG212.title: Career Planning for Geographical Sciences, GIS, and ENSP Majors
GEOG212.description: Increase student knowledge of professional development opportunities in Geographical Sciences through classroom activities and invited speakers, and to build awareness of career development tools and strategies.
GEOG212.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Geography; GEOG-GIS & Computer Cartography).

GEOG301.title: Advanced Geographical Environmental Systems
GEOG301.description: This course will provide the students with an overview of the key elements of physical geography, including biogeography (factors and processes that control the geographical distributions of plants and animals,  climatology (processes associated with controlling variations in weather and climate), and geomorphology (factors and processes that control changes to the physical structure of the earth surface in relation to geological structures).

GEOG306.title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for the Geographic Environmental Sciences
GEOG306.description: Essentials in the quantitative analysis of spatial and other data, with a particular emphasis on statistics and programming. Topics include data display, data description and summary, statistical inference and significance tests, analysis of variance, correlation, regression, and some advanced concepts, such as matrix methods, principal component analysis, and spatial statistics. Students will develop expertise in data analysis using advanced statistical software.

GEOG331.title: Introduction to Human Dimensions of Global Change
GEOG331.description: Introduction to global-scale interrelationship between human beings and the environment. The development of global issues including but not limited to the environment, food, energy, technology, population, and policy.
GEOG331.prerequisite: ANTH220, ANTH260, GEOG202, or GEOG201; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG333.title: The Social Geography of Metropolitan Areas in Global Perspective
GEOG333.description: A socio-spatial approach to human interaction within the urban environments: ways people perceive, define, behave in, and structure world cities and metropolitan areas. Cultural and social differences define spatial patterns of social activities which further define distinctions in distribution and interaction of people and their social institutions.
GEOG333.prerequisite: Permission of BSOS-Geography department; or (GEOG201 and GEOG202).

GEOG372.title: Remote Sensing
GEOG372.description: Principles of remote sensing in relation to photographic, thermal infrared and radar imaging. Methods of obtaining quantitative information from remotely-sensed images. Interpretation of remotely-sensed images emphasizing the study of spatial and environmental relationships.

GEOG373.title: Geographic Information Systems
GEOG373.description: Characteristics and organization of geographic data; creation and use of digital geospatial databases; metadata; spatial data models for thematic mapping and map analysis; use of geographic information system in society, government, and business.  Practical training with use of advanced software and geographic databases.

GEOG376.title: Introduction to Computer Programming for GIS
GEOG376.description: Introduces conceptual and practical aspects of programming for geographic applications. The main focus is on developing a solid understanding of basic programming techniques irrespective of the specific programming language including variables, looping, conditional statements, nesting, math, strings, and other concepts. In addition, students will develop a proficiency in applying these basic programming principles to manipulating spatial data sources within the Geographic Information Systems (GIS).
GEOG376.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in MATH120, MATH130, or MATH140; or must have completed MATH220. And GEOG373; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG384.title: Internship in Geography I
GEOG384.description: Supervised field training to provide career experience. Introduction to professional level activities, demands, opportunities. Placement at a public agency, non-profit organization, or private firm. Participation requires application to the internship advisor in preceding semester.
GEOG384.prerequisite: GEOG211, GEOG306, GEOG212, and GEOG201; and (ENGL393 or ENGL390).  Prerequisite:

GEOG384H.title: Internship in Geography I
GEOG384H.description: Supervised field training to provide career experience. Introduction to professional level activities, demands, opportunities. Placement at a public agency, non-profit organization, or private firm. Participation requires application to the internship advisor in preceding semester.
GEOG384H.prerequisite: GEOG211, GEOG306, GEOG212, and GEOG201; and (ENGL393 or ENGL390).

GEOG385.title: Internship in Geography II
GEOG385.description: Supervised field training to provide career experience. Introduction to professional-level activities, demands, opportunities. Placement at a public agency, nonprofit organization, or private firm. Participation requires application to the internship advisor in preceding semester.
GEOG385.prerequisite: GEOG211, GEOG306, GEOG212, and GEOG201; and must have completed a Junior (Professional) English course.  Prerequisite:

GEOG385H.title: Internship in Geography II
GEOG385H.description: Supervised field training to provide career experience. Introduction to professional-level activities, demands, opportunities. Placement at a public agency, nonprofit organization, or private firm. Participation requires application to the internship advisor in preceding semester.
GEOG385H.prerequisite: GEOG211, GEOG306, GEOG212, and GEOG201; and must have completed a Junior (Professional) English course.

GEOG396.title: Honors Research
GEOG396.description: First course in the departmental honors sequence. Student development o a potential research topic under the guidance of a faculty advisor, culminating in a written and oral presentation of a research proposal.
GEOG396.restriction: Permission of BSOS-Geography department; and senior standing or higher; and must be in Geography program.

GEOG397.title: Honors Thesis
GEOG397.description: Second course in the departmental honors sequence. Student research under the auspices of a faculty advisor, culminating in a research paper to be defended orally before the geography honors committee.
GEOG397.restriction: Must be in Geography program; and senior standing or higher.

GEOG413.title: Migration: Latin America and the United States
GEOG413.description: Develops an understanding of the push and pull factors that have contributed to human mobility (migration) that has transformed the Americas. The class is divided in two parts: immigration and emigration from Latin American and Latin America migration to the United States. We will be interested in studying the migration shifts that have occurred in Latin America and the theories that help explain them. The themes that will be addressed are the history of migration with Latin America and to North America, the impact of this migration on both sending and receiving countries, and the various policy strategies and issues concerning migration.
GEOG413.prerequisite: GEOG313; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG415.title: Land Use, Climate Change, and Sustainability
GEOG415.description: The issues of climate change and land use change as two interlinked global and regional environmental issues and their implications for society and resource use are explored.
GEOG415.prerequisite: GEOG123 or GEOG306; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG416.title: Conceptualizing and Modeling Human-Environmental Interactions
GEOG416.description: Develops skills to carry out research that integrates environmental and economic aspects of sustainability by introducing extensively used quantitative tools for analyzing human-environmental interactions in the field of ecological economics. These include, e.g., index number calculations and decomposition analysis, Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC), environmental input-output analysis and life-cycle analysis, and multi-criteria decisions aid (MCDA). Students will need laptops to run models during class.
GEOG416.prerequisite: Permission of BSOS-Geography department. Or GEOG306, STAT100, MATH107, or MATH111; and (GEOG201 and GEOG202); and (GEOG331 or GEOG330).

GEOG421.title: Changing Geographies of China
GEOG421.description: Covers physical geography, history, and economic and political systems of the world's most populous country. The major focus will be on geographical issues in China's contemporary development: agriculture, population, urbanization, resource and energy, and environment.
GEOG421.prerequisite: Permission of BSOS-Geography department. Or GEOG202; and GEOG201; and (GEOG435, GEOG333, or GEOG332).

GEOG430.title: Climate, Energy, and Policy
GEOG430.description: Students will learn about climate change and energy policy from multiple perspectives includingsocial economic, technological, scientific, and behavioural aspects and their interdependence.The course will also consider the report of the Intergovernmental Panel onClimate Change on mitigation and applied cost/benefit analysis of Climate Change. Formatwill be discussion, supplemented with lecture segments and applied workshops asneeded. This course will make occasional use the popular open source statistical computerlanguage R for practical workshops
GEOG430.prerequisite: Permission of BSOS-Geography department. Or GEOG201 or GEOG202; and (GEOG306 and GEOG301).

GEOG441.title: The Coastal Ocean
GEOG441.description: Introduction to coastal oceanography, focusing on the physical, biological, and geological aspects of ocean areqs on the inner continental shelves. Wave, currents, and tidal dynamics of bays, open coast, estuaries, and deltas. Sedimentary environments of major coastal types. Ecology and biogeochemical relationships, including benthic and planktonic characteristics. Coastal evolution with sea level rise. Human impacts: eutrophication, modification of sedimentation. The coastal future: rising sea level, hypoxia, and increased storminess.
GEOG441.prerequisite: GEOG140; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG472.title: Remote Sensing: Digital Processing and Analysis
GEOG472.description: Digital image processing and analysis applied to satellite and aircraft land remote sensing data. Consideration is given to preprocessing steps including calibration and geo registration. Analysis methods include digital image exploration, feature extraction thematic classification, change detection, and biophysical characterization. One or more application examples may be reviewed.
GEOG472.prerequisite: GEOG372 and GEOG306; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

GEOG473.title: Geographic Information Systems and Spatial Analysis
GEOG473.description: Analytical uses of geographic information systems; data models for building geographic data bases; types of geographic data and spatial problems; practical experience using advanced software for thematic domains  such as terrain analysis, land suitability modeling, demographic analysis, and transportation studies.
GEOG473.prerequisite: GEOG306 and GEOG373; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

GEOG477.title: Mobile GIS Development
GEOG477.description: Designed as an introduction to mobile GIS, to the programming concepts underlying mobile GIS development, and more importantly, to the design and implement of a mobile GIS application. Covers how to develop, test, and publish mobile GIS native apps working across two mobile platforms: Android and iOS. This course will also try to leverage the capabilities of JavaScript, Swift, Google maps, ArcGIS Server and runtime SDK to developing and publishing mobile GIS web apps.
GEOG477.prerequisite: GEOG306, GEOG373, and GEOG376; and (GEOG473, GEOG475, or GEOG476). And MATH140 or MATH120; or must have completed MATH220.
GEOG477.restriction: Must be in a major within the BSOS-Geography department; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG498B.title: Topical Investigations; Coupled Human and Natural Systems

GEOG498I.title: Topical Investigations; Data Structures for Geospatial Computing

GEOG606.title: Quantitative Spatial Analysis
GEOG606.description: Multivariate statistical method applications to spatial problems. Linea and non-linear correlation and regression, factor analysis, cluster analysis. Spatial statistics including: trend surfaces, sequences, point distributions. Applications orientation.
GEOG606.prerequisite: GEOG305; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG630.title: Climate, Energy, and Policy
GEOG630.description: Students will learn about climate change and energy policy from multiple perspectives including social economic, technological, scientific, and behavioural aspects and their interdependence. The course will also consider the report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on mitigation and applied cost/benefit analysis of Climate Change.
GEOG630.prerequisite: Permission of BSOS-Geography department; or enrolled in the Geographical Sciences Graduate Program(s).

GEOG676.title: Advanced Programming for Geography and Remote Sensing
GEOG676.description: Comprehensive instruction is provided in the advanced use of a commercial programming language and analysis tool used for scientific programming and data visualization, with an emphasis on applications in geography and remote sensing or GIS.
GEOG676.prerequisite: GEOG376; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG777.title: Mobile GIS Development
GEOG777.description: Designed as an introduction to mobile GIS, to the programming concepts underlying mobile GIS development, and more importantly, to the design and implementation of a mobile GIS application.  Covers how to develop, test, and publish mobile GIS native apps working across two mobile platforms: Android and iOS. This course will also try to leverage the capabilities of JavaScript, Swift, Google maps, ArcGIS Server and runtime SDK to developing and publishing mobile GIS web apps.
GEOG777.prerequisite: Permission of BSOS-Geography department; or must be enrolled in Geographical Sciences Phd or MS degree program.
GEOG777.restriction: Must be in a major within the BSOS-Geography department; or permission of BSOS-Geography department.

GEOG788B.title: Selected Topics in Geography; Coupled Human and Natural Systems

GEOG788D.title: Selected Topics in Geography; From Communicating Science to Facilitating Learning and Didactical Skill

GEOG788I.title: Selected Topics in Geography; Geospatial Algorithms and Data Structures

GEOG788M.title: Selected Topics in Geography; Migration: Latin America and the United States

GEOG788N.title: Selected Topics in Geography; Global Supply Chains, Unequal Exchange and Sustainable      Development

GEOG790.title: Internship in Geography
GEOG790.description: Field experience in the student's specialty in a Federal, state, or local agency or private business. Research paper required.

GEOG798.title: Selected Topics in Geography: Seminar Series; Seminar Series

GEOL100.title: Physical Geology
GEOL100.description: A general survey of the rocks and minerals composing the earth, its surface features and the agents that form them, and the dynamic forces of plate tectonics.

GEOL102.title: Historical Geology
GEOL102.description: Earth's history as revealed through the principles of stratigraphy and the processes of physical geology. Emphasis on formations and geologic development of the North American continent.
GEOL102.prerequisite: GEOL120 or GEOL100; and GEOL110. Or permission of CMNS-Geology department.

GEOL110.title: Physical Geology Laboratory
GEOL110.description: The basic materials and tools of physical geology stressing familiarization with rocks and minerals and the use of maps in geologic interpretations.
GEOL110.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in GEOL120 or GEOL100.

GEOL120.title: Environmental Geology
GEOL120.description: A review of geologic factors underlying many environmental problems and the interactions between population and physical environment: geologic hazards, land-use planning, conservation, mineral resources, waste disposal, land reclamation, and the geologic aspects of health and disease. The course is aimed at lower division students in education and liberal arts, and should be useful to any student concerned with geologic perspectives of environmental problems.

GEOL123.title: Causes and Consequences of Global Change
GEOL123.description: Study of the major components of Earth's climate system and climate change history. Discussion of 21st century climate change prediction, mitigation and adaptation efforts.

GEOL204.title: Dinosaurs, Early Humans, Ancestors, and Evolution; The Fossil Record of Vanished Worlds of the Prehistoric Past
GEOL204.description: Examination of evidence used to reconstruct critical events in the history of life by looking at case studies of significant evolutionary origins, transitions, and extinctions; addressing the role of paleontology in human society, including science education, conservation, and the media.

GEOL322.title: Mineralogy
GEOL322.description: Basic mineralogy for geology majors. The principles of morphologic crystallography, crystal chemistry, and determinative mineralogy.
GEOL322.prerequisite: GEOL120 or GEOL100; and GEOL110. And CHEM131 and CHEM132; or (CHEM135 and CHEM136); or CHEM103.
GEOL322.restriction: Permission of instructor is required for non-degree seeking students.

GEOL340.title: Geomorphology
GEOL340.description: Analysis of landforms, organized on the basis of the geologic processes that have operated during the late Cenozoic. Constructional and erosional landforms related to physical systems operating on geologic structures through time.
GEOL340.restriction: Permission of instructor is required of non-degree seeking students.

GEOL341.title: Structural Geology
GEOL341.description: Study of the deformation of Earth's lithosphere, especially stress, rheology, strain, and the origin and significance of structural features. Development of 3-dimensional thinking through drafting and drawing of structures, construction of geologic maps and cross-sections, and stereographic and orthographic representation of structures. Improvement of scientific writing. Two weekend field trips.
GEOL341.prerequisite: GEOL120 or GEOL100; and GEOL102; and GEOL110. Or permission of CMNS-Geology department.
GEOL341.restriction: Permission of instructor is required of non-degree seeking students.

GEOL393.title: Geology Senior Thesis I: Proposal
GEOL393.description: The first semester of the two-semester Geology Senior Thesis. Emphasis is on developing a plan for original research in the geosciences and presenting that plan both in writing and in public presentations that adhere to geosciences professional standards.
GEOL393.prerequisite: PHYS141 and MATH141. And CHEM131 and CHEM132; or (CHEM135 and CHEM136). And must have completed at least two upper-level geology courses and be concurrently enrolled in a third.
GEOL393.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in Geology program; and non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.

GEOL394.title: Geology Senior Thesis II: Research
GEOL394.description: The second semester of the two-semester Geology Senior Thesis. Investigation of specific original research question in geosciences. Emphasis is on completion of original research proposed in GEOL393 and presentation of results both in writing  and in public presentations that adhere to geosciences professional standards.
GEOL394.prerequisite: GEOL393; and must have completed at least three upper level GEOL courses.
GEOL394.restriction: Must be in Geology program; and junior standing or higher; and in addition, non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the department.

GEOL437.title: Global Climate Change: Past and Present
GEOL437.description: Introduction to the processes by which climate varies, the paleoclimate record, and projections of climate change into the 21st century, including discussion of climate sensitivity to external radiative forcing.
GEOL437.prerequisite: MATH115 or MATH140; and (GEOL100 or GEOL120); and (CHEM131 or CHEM135); and (CHEM132 or CHEM136).

GEOL443.title: Petrology
GEOL443.description: Study of igneous and metamorphic rocks: petrogenesis, distributions, chemical and mineralogical relations, macroscopic and microscopic descriptions, geologic significance.
GEOL443.prerequisite: GEOL322. And CHEM131 and CHEM132; or (CHEM135 and CHEM136); or CHEM103. And must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in GEOL423; and (GEOL100 or GEOL120); and GEOL110.
GEOL443.restriction: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.

GEOL456.title: Engineering Geology
GEOL456.description: An overview of engineering geology with an emphasis on physical understanding of natural hazards and natural resources. General theories of stress and strain, failure criteria, frictional stability, fluid flow in porous media and poroelasticity are introduced. Quantitative approaches on earthquakes, landslides, land subsidence, and geotechnical aspects of oil/gas exploration are discussed.
GEOL456.prerequisite: PHYS141 and MATH141; and (GEOL120 or GEOL100). Or permission of CMNS-Geology department.
GEOL456.restriction: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.

GEOL457.title: Seismology
GEOL457.description: General overview of the basics of seismology, starting with wave propagation, seismic reflection and refraction. Applications to the determination of the seismic velocity and anisotropy structure of the Earth. Earthquake generation, postseismic deformation and creep events, relation to faulting and plate tectonics.
GEOL457.prerequisite: GEOL120 or GEOL100; and (MATH141, GEOL110, and MATH140). Or permission of CMNS-Geology department.
GEOL457.restriction: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.

GEOL489F.title: Special Topics; Special Topics in Biogeochemistry: Isotopes at the Atmosphere/Surface Interface

GEOL497.title: Recent Advances: Geology
GEOL497.description: A survey of important recent advances in geological sciences in the context of the methods and practices of scientific research.
GEOL497.prerequisite: Must have completed at least 2 upper-level GEOL courses. Prerequisite:
GEOL497.restriction: Must be in Geology program; and GPA of 3.0 or better in both overall and in all courses required for the major; and senior standing; and to be taken  as late as possible in the program.  Restriction:

GEOL497H.title: Recent Advances: Geology
GEOL497H.description: A survey of important recent advances in geological sciences in the context of the methods and practices of scientific research.
GEOL497H.prerequisite: Must have completed at least 2 upper-level GEOL courses.
GEOL497H.restriction: Must be in Geology program; and GPA of 3.0 or better in both overall and in all courses required for the major; and senior standing; and to be taken  as late as possible in the program.

GEOL654.title: Fluvial Geomorphology Seminar
GEOL654.description: Fluvial geomorphology is the study of the movement of water and sedimentin stream channels. This includes: formation of channels, open channel hydraulics, sediment transport or bedload and suspended load, river morphology and landscape evolution. The course is designed for graduate students and advanced undergraduates.
GEOL654.restriction: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.

GEOL656.title: Engineering and Environmental Geology
GEOL656.description: An overview of mechanical aspects of earthquakes as a result of fault instability. Quantitative approaches on soil and rock strength, instability on earthquakes, landslides, land subsidence, and geotechnical aspects of oil/gas exploration are discussed. Emphasis is on theoretical framework of mechanics of earthquake and faulting, earthquake source mechanisms, earthquake scaling relations, the seismic cycle etc.
GEOL656.prerequisite: GEOL100, GEOL110, MATH141, and PHYS141; or permission of instructor.
GEOL656.restriction: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.

GEOL657.title: Seismic Wave Propagation
GEOL657.description: A description of the physics of seismic wave propagation and their applications to the determination of the structure of the Earth and the mechanics of earthquakes.
GEOL657.prerequisite: MATH140 and MATH141; and (PHYS141, PHYS161, or PHYS171); and permission of CMNS-Geology department.
GEOL657.restriction: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.

GEOL789B.title: Recent Advances in Geology; Planetary Habitability and Surface Chemistry

GEOL789C.title: Recent Advances in Geology; Advanced Data Analysis Workshop

GEOL789F.title: Recent Advances in Geology; Special Topics in Biogeochemistry: Isotopes at the Atmosphere/Surface Interface

GERM103.title: Intensive Elementary German
GERM103.description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of German-speaking world.
GERM103.prerequisite: Must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
GERM103.restriction: Must not have completed GERM102; and must not be a fluent/native speaker of German.

GERM148Y.title: Germanic Languages - Elementary I; Yiddish I

GERM203.title: Intensive Intermediate German
GERM203.description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of German-speaking world.
GERM203.prerequisite: GERM103; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
GERM203.restriction: Must not have completed GERM201; and must not have completed GERM202; and must not be a fluent/native speaker of German.

GERM204.title: German Grammar Review
GERM204.description: An in-depth study and analysis of selected grammatical topics in a contextualized framework.
GERM204.prerequisite: GERM203; or Must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
GERM204.restriction: Must not be a fluent/native speaker of German.

GERM301.title: Conversation and Composition I: The German-Speaking World
GERM301.description: Practice in contemporary spoken and written German. Systematic review of grammar, and exercises in composition. Emphasis on cultural contrasts in the German-speaking world.
GERM301.prerequisite: GERM204; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

GERM302.title: Conversation and Composition II: Current Topics in German-Speaking Society
GERM302.description: Further practice in contemporary spoken and written German. Contemporary social, political, and cultural themes.
GERM302.prerequisite: GERM301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

GERM320.title: Survey of German Studies
GERM320.description: Approaches to analysis of German cultural products such as literature, film, poetry, architecture and works of art. Taught in German.
GERM320.prerequisite: GERM301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.Prerequisite:

GERM320H.title: Survey of German Studies
GERM320H.description: Approaches to analysis of German cultural products such as literature, film, poetry, architecture and works of art. Taught in German.
GERM320H.prerequisite: GERM301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

GERM386.title: Experiential Learning
GERM386.description: Prerequisite: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.  Restriction: Junior standing or higher.
GERM386.prerequisite: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

GERM397H.title: Honors Reading (Independent Study)
GERM397H.description: Supervised reading to be taken normally only by students admitted into honors program.

GERM403.title: Advanced Composition
GERM403.description: Advanced instruction in and acquisition of German writing skills.
GERM403.prerequisite: GERM302; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.Prerequisite:

GERM403H.title: Advanced Composition
GERM403H.description: Advanced instruction in and acquisition of German writing skills.
GERM403H.prerequisite: GERM302; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

GERM441.title: Border Crossings and Cultural Transfers
GERM441.description: Border Crossings and Cultural Transfers emphasizes the transnational and global dimensions of German culture, analyzing the interrelationship of dominant and minority cultures within Germany and/or the impact of German cultures abroad. Topics include migration, exile, (post)colonialism, and globalization. Taught in German.

GERM488B.title: Capstone Seminar; German-Jewish Authors/Works: Kafka, Seghers, Benjamin, Celan

GERM489B.title: Social Issues in German Culture; Weimar Culture

GERM689C.title: Special Topics - M.A. Level; Comparative Media Studies: Theory, History, Culture

GERM689P.title: Special Topics - M.A. Level; Postcolonial German Enlightenment: Migrants, Refugees, and Exiles

GERM689X.title: Special Topics - M.A. Level; Weimar Culture

GREK102.title: Elementary Ancient Greek II
GREK102.description: Continuing development of basic grammar and reading skills; study and discussion of central aspects of Greek culture.
GREK102.prerequisite: GREK101; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

GREK112.title: Elementary Modern Greek II
GREK112.description: It is designed for students who have already completed the first semester course (GREK111) and/or those whose level of proficiency in Greek is not advanced enough for the intermediate level. Like GREK111, an introduction is provided to the language and culture of modern Greece. Students acquire the basic tools of the language and learn to communicate in simple, everyday situations. This is the second of our two-semester sequence in Elementary Modern Greek and contributes to the fulfillment of the Global Engagement requirement of the College of Arts and Humanities.

GREK212.title: Intermediate Modern Greek II
GREK212.description: A continuation in the development of fluency in spoken and written communication along with the exploration of syntactic and grammatical structures. Comprehension and vocabulary enrichment are further developed through selected readings from Modern Greek prose and poetry. This is the second of our two-semester sequence in Intermediate Modern Greek and contributes to the fulfillment of the Global Engagement requirement of the College of Arts and Humanities.

GREK301.title: Scenes from Athenian Life
GREK301.description: Makes the transition from study of Greek grammar to reading. Focus on selected aspects of life in Athens: marriage, friendship, the courts, festival, theatre. Reading short works by three authors: Lysias, Plato, and a playwright (e.g., Menander). Readings are in ancient Greek.

GREK399A.title: Topics in Advanced Modern Greek Language and Culture; Advanced Modern Greek II

GREK472.title: History and Development of the Greek Language
GREK472.description: Mastery of ancient Greek through grammar review, prose composition, and analysis of historical developments in Greek writers' modes of expression.

GREK499.title: Independent Study in Greek Language and Literature

GREK672.title: History and Development of the Greek Language
GREK672.description: Mastery of ancient Greek through grammar review, prose composition, and analysis of historical developments in Greek writers' modes of expression.

GVPT101.title: Introduction to Political Science
GVPT101.description: A study of the basic principles and concepts of political science.

GVPT170.title: American Government
GVPT170.description: A comprehensive study of national government in the United States.

GVPT200.title: International Political Relations
GVPT200.description: A study of the major factors underlying international relations, the causes of conflict and cooperation among international actors, the role of international institutions, the interactions of domestic and foreign policies, and major issues in security, economy and the environment.

GVPT201.title: Scope and Methods for Political Science Research
GVPT201.description: An introduction to empirical research in political science.

GVPT221.title: Introduction to Formal Theories of Political Behavior and Politics
GVPT221.description: An introduction to the theories of rational choice including theories of negotiation and bargaining, elections and voting in democracies, community organizing and the contrast between the roles and performances of government and market.

GVPT241.title: The Study of Political Philosophy: Ancient and Modern
GVPT241.description: Examines some of the salient continuities and breaks between the ancient and modern traditions in Western political philosophy.
GVPT241.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program; or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program.

GVPT273.title: Introduction to Environmental Politics
GVPT273.description: An overview of modern environmental philosophy, politics, and policy, exploring environmental politics in the US by way of comparison with other developed and developing countries.

GVPT282.title: Politics and the Developing World
GVPT282.description: A study of the domestic governmental institutions; processes and problems such as conflict and economic development; and the socio-economic environments that are common to developing countries of Africa, the Middle East, Asia, and Latin America.

GVPT289J.title: Special Topics in Government and Politics; Uncertain Partners: US & China in a Changing World

GVPT306.title: Global Environmental Politics
GVPT306.description: Focus on three processes of international environmental policy development- identifying problems, negotiating solutions, and implementing agreements- through a range of case studies, including global climate change.

GVPT317.title: Mock Trial II: Advanced Trial Advocacy
GVPT317.description: Development of trial advocacy skills through participation in practice trials and intercollegiate mock trial competitions. Student may have an opportunity to represent the university in intercollegiate mock trial tournaments, including the National Mock Trial Championships.

GVPT331.title: Courts, Law and Justice
GVPT331.description: An introductory course to the study of law with emphasis on how lawyers and judges think and argue. Topics include, contract law, property, family law, torts, and criminal procedure.

GVPT355.title: Capstone in International Conflict Management
GVPT355.description: Serves as one of the two capstone courses for the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management. Focuses on advanced theory and the practice and profession of international conflict management and is designed to provide students an introduction to, and a chance to engage with, a core set of practical skills relevant to the field.
GVPT355.restriction: Enrollment is restricted to students in the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management; and sophomore standing or higher; and permission of BSOS-Government & Politics department.

GVPT356.title: Capstone in International Development
GVPT356.description: Serves as one of the two capstone courses for the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management. Focuses on advanced theory and the practice and profession of international development and is designed to provide students an introduction to, and a chance to engage with, a core set of practical skills relevant to the field.
GVPT356.restriction: Enrollment is restricted to students in the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management; and sophomore standing or higher; and permission of BSOS-Government & Politics department.

GVPT360.title: International Negotiations
GVPT360.description: A study of the complexities of international negotiation and cross-cultural decision-making. Students will apply advanced computer technology in an interactive simulation involving actual negotiations.

GVPT373.title: Geographic Information Systems for Redistricting
GVPT373.description: Local, state and federal governments must periodically draw and redraw political boundaries to account for shifts in the population. This course will be an introduction and overview of district drawing and redistricting as an important application of GIS research in political science and public policy. This class will equip students to use convenient GIS tools to create and consider alternative district scenarios to find the best possible solution. After finishing this class students will be able to draw districts to define police beats, sales territories, congressional and state legislative districts, school and fire protection districts, and numerous other boundaries.
GVPT373.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Government & Politics; Government & Politics: International Relations).

GVPT386.title: Experiential Learning
GVPT386.description: Restriction: Permission of BSOS-Government & Politics department; and junior standing or higher.
GVPT386.restriction: Permission of BSOS-Government & Politics department; and junior standing or higher.

GVPT388L.title: Topical Investigations; Maryland Politics, Policy, and Leadership

GVPT388M.title: Topical Investigations; Mock Trial Independent Study

GVPT388W.title: Topical Investigations; Experiential Learning: Maryland, Public Policy and Beyond

GVPT390.title: Game Theory
GVPT390.description: Introduction to game theory with applications to political science, economics and sociology. Topics include preference theory, expected utility theory, Nash equilibria, subgame perfection, repeated games, folk theorems, and evolutionary stability.

GVPT396.title: Introduction to Honors Research
GVPT396.description: A required course for all honors students designed to emphasize library research, methodology, and writing skills in political science and political philosophy. A written proposal, bibliography and research design for an honors paper required of all students as a final project.
GVPT396.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics Honors Program; and must have permission of the Government & Politics Honors Program.

GVPT397.title: Honors Research
GVPT397.description: Individual reading and research. Preparation of an original paper.
GVPT397.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics Honors Program.

GVPT409C.title: Seminar in International Relations and World Politics; Civil Resistance

GVPT409H.title: Seminar in International Relations and World Politics; International Relations of the Middle East

GVPT409I.title: Seminar in International Relations and World Politics; The Politics of International and Domestic Human Rights

GVPT409O.title: Seminar in International Relations and World Politics; The Politics of Climate Change

GVPT421.title: Advanced Quantitative Methods
GVPT421.description: Advanced quantitative methods for political science research.
GVPT421.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Government & Politics; Government & Politics: International Relations).

GVPT423H.title: Elections and Electoral Behavior
GVPT423H.description: An examination of various topics relating to elections; the focus includes the legal structure under which elections are conducted, the selection and nomination process, the conduct of election campaigns, and patterns of political participation and voting choice in different types of elections.
GVPT423H.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program.

GVPT429E.title: Problems in Political Behavior; Public Opinion and Partisanship

GVPT432.title: Civil Rights and the Constitution
GVPT432.description: A study of civil rights in the American constitutional context, emphasizing freedom of religion, freedom of expression, minority discrimination, and the rights of defendants.
GVPT432.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program.

GVPT439A.title: Seminar in Public Law; Comparative Constitutional Law

GVPT445.title: Marxism and Postmarxism
GVPT445.description: The study of Marxist thought and an assessment of the critical transformations and reassessments of the theory and practice of Marxism.
GVPT445.restriction: Must be in a major within BSOS-Government & Politics department.

GVPT454.title: Seminar in the International Relations of China
GVPT454.description: Explores the foreign relations behavior of the People's Republic of China, with focus on the contemporary era.
GVPT454.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program; and junior standing or higher. Or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program; and junior standing or higher.

GVPT456.title: The Politics of Terrorism
GVPT456.description: Examination of the definition, causes and organization of terrorist activity, along with key domestic and international counter- and anti-terrorism responses. Special emphasis on challanges and opportunities to the scientific study of terrorism.
GVPT456.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program; or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program.

GVPT459E.title: Seminar in Comparative Politics; Comparative Politics of the Middle East

GVPT459O.title: Seminar in Comparative Politics; Politics of Authoritarian Regimes

GVPT459R.title: Seminar in Comparative Politics; The Rise and Fall of Communism

GVPT473.title: The U.S. Congress
GVPT473.description: A detailed survey of lawmaking and the legislative process, emphasizing the U.S. Congress, and its members.
GVPT473.restriction: Junior standing or higher. And must be in Government & Politics program; or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program.

GVPT479D.title: Seminar in American Politics; Minority Politics

GVPT479L.title: Seminar in American Politics; Local Politics and Government

GVPT479P.title: Seminar in American Politics; Political Polarization

GVPT479Y.title: Seminar in American Politics; Political Psychology

GVPT482H.title: Government and Politics of Latin America
GVPT482H.description: A comparative study of the governmental systems and political processes of the Latin American countries.
GVPT482H.restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program; or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program.

GVPT722.title: Advanced Quantitative Methods For Political Science
GVPT722.description: Introduction to multivariate analysis. Elementary matrix algebra, multiple linear and curvilinear correlation and regression, analysis of variance, canonical correlation and regression, discriminant analysis, and several types of factor analysis.

GVPT729M.title: Special Topics in Quantitative Political Analysis; Multilevel Analysis

GVPT743.title: Contemporary Political Theory
GVPT743.description: Theorists from Nietzsche (1884-1900) to the present will be covered with a focus on the apparent failure of the Enlightenment to usher in an age of peace and reason.

GVPT771.title: Seminar in American Political Behavior
GVPT771.description: This is the core seminar in American political behavior. The course wil deal with prominent theoretical and empirical issues in the areas of voting, public opinion, political participation and other aspects of political behavior in the American context.

GVPT808B.title: Selected Topics in Functional Problems in International Relations; Conflict and World Politics

GVPT808C.title: Selected Topics in Functional Problems in International Relations; Prospectus Seminar in International Relations & Comparative Politics

GVPT831.title: Formal Theories of Politics I
GVPT831.description: Survey of major formal theories of politics, with emphasis on those theories based on the assumptions of rationality. The theory of public goods, game theory, coalition theory, and the theoretical properties of voting systems.

GVPT873.title: Seminar in Legislatures and Legislation
GVPT873.description: Reports on topics assigned for individual study and reading about the composition and organization of legislatures and about the legislative process.

GVPT888B.title: Selected Topics in Comparative Governmental Institutions; Democracy and Democratization

GVPT888E.title: Selected Topics in Comparative Governmental Institutions; Conflict Studies

GVPT888F.title: Selected Topics in Comparative Governmental Institutions; Social Movements

HACS101.title: Applied Cybersecurity Foundations
HACS101.description: Prepares students for team research that will be conducted in HACS 200.  Students gain an understanding across the breadth of cybersecurity including system monitoring, networking basics and penetration testing.  An applied approach to statistics is also included to prepare students to assess the data collected for their research projects.  The course is conducted with a hands-on approach applying virtual environments to practice the concepts learned in the technical lectures each week.
HACS101.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HACS100.
HACS101.restriction: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program.

HACS208A.title: Seminar in Cybersecurity; Accounting and Economic Aspects of Cybersecurity

HACS208E.title: Seminar in Cybersecurity; Introduction to Reverse Engineering

HACS208I.title: Seminar in Cybersecurity; Security Incident Handling and Management

HACS208P.title: Seminar in Cybersecurity; Beyond Technology, the Policy Implications of Cyberspace

HACS287.title: Undergraduate Research in Cybersecurity
HACS287.description: The Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students (ACES) program encourages its students to engage in research in order to gain greater insight into a specific area within cybersecurity, obtain an appreciation for the subtleties and difficulties associated with the production of knowledge and fundamental new applications, and to prepare for graduate school and the workforce.
HACS287.restriction: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program; and permission of UGST-HCOL-ACES Cybersecurity Program.

HACS297.title: Cybersecurity Experience Reflection
HACS297.description: Cybersecurity experience is defined as an experiential learning activity either with a University of Maryland entity (such as the Division of Information Technology, the ACES competition team or in an ACES outreach program), or with an external organization that will provide valuable, hands-on experience to supplement the knowledge learned in the other ACES coursework.
HACS297.restriction: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program; and permission of UGST-HCOL-ACES Cybersecurity Program.

HACS318A.title: Cybersecurity Professionals Colloquium Series; Current Issues

HACS402.title: Applied Security Analysis and Visualization
HACS402.description: Focuses on exploratory and statistical data analysis, data and information visualization, and the presentation and communication of analysis results.  These topics will be presented and explored in the context of and with applications to cybersecurity related data.
HACS402.restriction: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program.

HACS408T.title: Advanced Seminar in Cybersecurity; Penetration Testing

HDCC106.title: Introduction to Digital and Creativity II
HDCC106.description: Introduction to the methods and theory of digital cultural production, with emphasis on creative and expressive platforms.
HDCC106.restriction: Must be in the Digital Cultures and Creativity Honors College Living/Learning program.

HDCC209A.title: Practicum in Digital Cultures and Creativity

HDCC209B.title: Practicum in Digital Cultures and Creativity

HDCC209C.title: Practicum in Digital Cultures and Creativity

HDCC209D.title: Practicum in Digital Cultures and Creativity

HDCC379.title: Digital Cultures and Creativity Independent Study

HEBR107.title: Intensive Elementary Hebrew II
HEBR107.description: A continuation of intensive study of fundamentals of Hebrew reading, writing, listening, speaking and Israeli culture. Covers past tense in all verb categories, basic syntax and builds vocabulary.
HEBR107.prerequisite: HEBR106 or HEBR111; or must have appropriate score on Foreign Language Placement Assessment; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

HEBR112.title: Elementary Hebrew II
HEBR112.prerequisite: HEBR111; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
HEBR112.restriction: Must not have completed HEBR103; and must not have completed HEBR104.

HEBR207.title: Intensive Intermediate Hebrew II
HEBR207.description: A review of the fundamentals of Hebrew grammar, reading, writing, listening and speaking.
HEBR207.prerequisite: Must have completed HEBR206 OR HEBR211; or have the appropriate Score on the Foreign Language Placement Assessment; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

HEBR212.title: Intermediate Hebrew II
HEBR212.prerequisite: HEBR211; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.
HEBR212.restriction: Must not have completed HEBR203; and must not have completed HEBR204.

HEBR298A.title: Special Topics in Jewish Studies; Introduction to Classical Hebrew

HEBR314.title: Conversation and Composition II
HEBR314.description: A practical language course recommended for all students continuing with Hebrew. Review of grammar and composition. Selected readings. Oral and written exercises.
HEBR314.prerequisite: HEBR313; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

HEBR386.title: Experiential Learning
HEBR386.description: Restriction: Must have a Learning Proposal approved by the Office of Experiential Learning Programs, faculty sponsor, and student's internship sponsor; and junior standing or higher.
HEBR386.restriction: Must have a Learning Proposal approved by the Office of Experiential Learning Programs, faculty sponsor, and student's internship sponsor; and junior standing or higher.

HEBR498M.title: Special Topics in Hebrew; 1948 and the Transnational Struggle for Palestine

HEIP144.title: Contemporary Issues in Entrepreneurship and Innovation
HEIP144.description: Inspires entrepreneurial innovation and creativity through interactive lectures, workshops, and case studies on contemporary issues to include energy, life sciences, healthcare, and technology. Explores entrepreneurial innovation sources, structures and dynamics. Helps students develop skills for generating ideas and addressing current issues and problems.
HEIP144.restriction: Must be in the Entrepreneurship and Innovation Program (EIP).

HEIP241.title: EIP Capstone: Creating Enterprise with Social Impact
HEIP241.description: Addresses the global necessity to develop and implement solutions to critical social and environmental concerns in ways that are both technologically viable and economically sustainable. Through group exercises, guest speakers, discussions, and experiential learning activities, students will develop the skills to create businesses that achieve the double bottom line of both profitability and social benefit.
HEIP241.restriction: Must be in the Entrepreneurship and Innovation Program (EIP).

HESI217.title: Introduction to Student Leadership
HESI217.description: Introduction to leadership theories, concepts, and skills. Completion of personal and leadership self-assessments, values exploration, and small group application.

HESI315.title: Student Leadership in Groups and Organizations
HESI315.description: Acquiring and integrating leadership knowledge within group and organizational contexts so that students can navigate organizational environments and apply leadership in diverse communities of practice and career contexts.

HESI318G.title: Applied Contextual Leadership; Greek Presidents Class

HESI318M.title: Applied Contextual Leadership; Leadership and Education

HESI318N.title: Applied Contextual Leadership; Leadership in Collaborative Learning Groups

HESI318R.title: Applied Contextual Leadership; Foundations and Applications of Challenge Course Theory

HESI318T.title: Applied Contextual Leadership; Foundations and Applications of Adventure Leadership Instruction

HESI321.title: Advanced Social Action Seminar
HESI321.description: The use of leadership theories to inform the practice of addressing social issues in society, on campus, or within the surrounding community. Students will:  identify a current and compelling social issue; explore the historical, social, and political aspects of social issues; identify and select applicable leadership theories to confront the social issue; create and develop a plan that integrates leadership theories and the social issue; and implement and evaluate the overall social action project. Focuses on executing, implementing, and assessing a social action project in small groups and teams.
HESI321.restriction: Limited to Minor in Leadership Studies students only.

HESI417.title: Advanced Leadership Seminar
HESI417.description: Students will analyze and synthesize the concept of leadership using cultural, ethical, sociological, historical perspectives. Exploration and reflection of personal values, decision making, in-depth analysis on various leadership activities. Theories will be emphasized.
HESI417.prerequisite: HESI217; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
HESI417.restriction: Permission of EDUC-Counseling, Higher Education and Special Education department.

HESI418B.title: Special Topics in Leadership; Black Student Leadership

HESI418C.title: Special Topics in Leadership; Latina/x/o Leadership

HESI418F.title: Special Topics in Leadership; Jewish Leadership

HESI418G.title: Special Topics in Leadership; Women's Leadership

HESI470.title: Introduction to Student Personnel
HESI470.description: A systematic analysis of research and theoretical literature on a variety of major problems in the organization and administration of student personnel services in higher education. Included will be discussion of such topics as the student personnel philosophy in education, counseling services, discipline, housing, student activities, financial aid, health, remedial services, etc.
HESI470.restriction: Permission of EDUC-Counseling, Higher Education and Special Education department.

HESI489.title: Field Experiences in Higher Education, Student Affairs, and International Education Poli

HESP120.title: Introduction to Linguistics
HESP120.description: An introduction to the scientific study of natural language with focus on the basic concepts of phonology, syntax, semantics and pragmatics, with subsequent attention to the applied aspects of linguistic principles.

HESP202.title: Introduction to Hearing and Speech Sciences
HESP202.description: An introduction to communication sciences and disorders; a survey of th bases of normal speech, language and hearing ability, major forms of communicative disorders and their treatment.

HESP300.title: Introduction to Psycholinguistics
HESP300.description: An introduction to current theories of language and an investigation of their relationship to human communication behavior. Survey of the experimental literature relating to this question.
HESP300.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP202; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP303.title: Phonetic transcription
HESP303.description: An introduction to broad and narrow phonetic transcription, and to physiology of speech production. The primary goal of the course is to provide knowledge about phonetics and the ability to use this knowledge in an applied setting.

HESP305.title: Anatomy and Physiology of the Speech Mechanism
HESP305.description: Anatomy, physiology, and neurology of speech mechanism.
HESP305.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP202; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP306.title: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech & Hearing
HESP306.description: This is a 4-credit course focusing on the biological and neurological bases of human speech production and human hearing, namely the anatomy, physiology, and neurology of the vocal/speech mechanism and the hearing mechanism.Specifically, respiration, phonation, resonance, articulation, swallowing, and hearing will be highlighted. A strong understanding of normal anatomy and physiology is essential for the successful evaluation and treatment of patients with speech, language, swallowing and hearing disorders.

HESP311.title: Anatomy, Pathology and Physiology of the Auditory System
HESP311.description: Gross anatomy of the ear and pathways for transmission of sound energy through the peripheral and central auditory system. Causes, development and effects of pathological conditions contributing to temporary or chronic hearing impairments.
HESP311.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP202; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP386.title: Experiential Learning
HESP386.description: Students will have the opportunity observe and/or participate in therapy activities provided by a speech-language pathologist or audiologist in this experiential learning course.
HESP386.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP400.title: Speech and Language Development in Children
HESP400.description: Analysis of the normal processes of speech and language development in children.
HESP400.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP300; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
HESP400.restriction: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP402.title: Language and Phonological Disorders in Children
HESP402.description: Etiology, assessment and treatment of language and phonological disorders in children.
HESP402.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP400; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
HESP402.restriction: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program.

HESP403.title: Introduction to Phonetic Science
HESP403.description: An introduction to physiological, acoustic and perceptual phonetics; broad and narrow phonetic transcription; current models of speech production and perception.
HESP403.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP305; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
HESP403.restriction: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP407.title: Bases of Hearing Science
HESP407.description: Fundamentals of hearing, including the physics of sound, anatomy and physiology of peripheral and central auditory nervous system, psychophysical procedures used in measurement of auditory sensation and perception, and topics in psychological acoustics.
HESP407.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP311; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
HESP407.restriction: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP411.title: Introduction to Audiology
HESP411.description: An introduction to the field of audiology. Evaluation and remediation of hearing handicaps.
HESP411.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in HESP311; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
HESP411.restriction: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

HESP413.title: Aural Rehabilitation/Habilitation
HESP413.description: The fundamental aspects of aural rehabilitation therapy for both adults and children are introduced to students. Class time will consist of lectures, discussions, and hands-on activities.
