Populations include older adults, users with visual, cognitive or motor impairments, users who are deaf or hard of hearing, children, users in low resource contexts, and users in mobile contexts. Research trends and practical design considerations (e.g., web accessibility requirements) will be covered. Students will interact with the material through readings, discussion, and individual and group assignments.
INST704.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST728B.title: Special Topics in Information Studies; Digitization and Legacy Holdings

INST728G.title: Special Topics in Information Studies; Smart Cities and Urban Data Science

INST728Q.title: Special Topics in Information Studies; Visual Analytics

INST733.title: Database Design
INST733.description: Principles of user-oriented database design.  Requirements analysis. Data modelling.  Data integrity and security and multi-user databases. Implementing an information system using a database management system (DBMS).
INST733.prerequisite: LBSC690, LBSC671, or INFM603; or permission of instructor.
INST733.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST734.title: Information Retrieval Systems
INST734.description: Principles of organizing and providing access to information using automated information storage and retrieval systems. Retrieval systems models, index language selection, data structure, user interfaces, and evaluation for text and multimedia applications.
INST734.prerequisite: LBSC671 or INFM603; or permission of instructor.
INST734.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST736.title: Computational Linguistics II
INST736.description: Natural language processing with a focus on corpus-based statistical techniques. Topics include: stochastic language modeling, smoothing, noisy channel models, probabilistic grammars and parsing; lexical acquisition, similarity-based methods, word sense disambiguation, statistical methods in NLP applications; system evaluation.
INST736.prerequisite: LING723 or CMSC723; or permission of instructor.
INST736.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST737.title: Introduction to Data Science
INST737.description: An exploration of some of the best and most general approaches to get the most information out of data through clustering, classification, and regression techniques.
INST737.prerequisite: INST627; and (LBSC690, LBSC671, or INFM603). Or permission of instructor.
INST737.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST741.title: Social Computing Technologies and Applications
INST741.description: Tools and techniques for developing and configuring social computing applications. Theories and paradigms for social computing. Strengths and limitations of different application styles and types. Evolution of applications as responses to social computing challenges. Information and organizational systems co-development.
INST741.prerequisite: INFM603 and INFM605; or (LBSC602 and LBSC671); or permission of instructor.
INST741.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST742.title: Implementing Digital Curation
INST742.description: Management of and technology for application of digital curation principles in specific settings.   Characteristics, representation, conversion, and preservation of digital objects.  Application of standards for digitization, description, and preservation.  Planning for sustainability, risk mitigation and disaster recovery.
INST742.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST762.title: Visual Analytics
INST762.description: Visual analytics is the use of interactive visual interfaces to facilitate analytical reasoning. In essence, visual analytics is based on the--not uncontroversial--idea that humans and computers working alone are insufficient for the data challenges of today and tomorrow, and that effective synthesis of both humans and computational algorithms are needed to create human-in-the-loop systems. Thus, visual analytics bridges human-centered disciplines such as visualization and human-computer interaction with computation-centered disciplines such as machine learning, probabilistic methods, and knowledge discovery. The course contents will include both theoretical foundations of this interdisciplinary science as well as practical applications of integrated visual analysis techniques on real-world problems.
INST762.prerequisite: INFM603 or INST630; or permission of instructor.
INST762.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST767.title: Big Data Infrastructure
INST767.description: Principles and techniques of data science and business intelligence. Technologies and architectures for large-scale data warehousing and scale-out data analytics platforms. Supervised and unsupervised data mining.
INST767.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST776.title: HCIM CAPSTONE PROJECT
INST776.description: The opportunity to apply the skills learned through coursework in a semester-long project applied to a real -world problem. Capstone projects may follow the design, prototyping and evaluation process from end-to-end or may focus on a subset of elements in that process, such as formative study and design.
INST776.restriction: Must be taken in the semester immediately following completion of INST775 HCIM Capstone Prep; and permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

INST794.title: Capstone in Youth Experience
INST794.description: Through a supervised project, to synthesize design thinking, participatory design, connected learning, and learning theory/frameworks students will produce a technology-infused program for and with youth. Students will develop and carry out a project with a community partner through their library system. The project must incorporate technology and design thinking, and must be based on one or more learning theory/frameworks. Through the course, students will learn many practical skills related to planning and implementation of a technology-infused programming at or through their library, including marketing, fundraising, budgeting, legal issues, logistical issues, developing and sustaining community partnerships, developing engaging experiences for youth, and creating and analyzing learning assessments.
INST794.prerequisite: INST650, INST651, and INST652; or permission of instructor.
INST794.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies; and must be part of Youth Experience (YX) certificate program.

INST808.title: Seminar in Research Methods and Data Analysis

INST810.title: Individual Research Experience
INST810.description: Pre-candidacy individual research experience directed by a faculty member.

ISRL249G.title: Selected Topics in Israel Studies; Introduction to Jewish Literature

ISRL329D.title: Special Topics in Israel Studies; Understanding the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict through Opposing Histories

ISRL329K.title: Special Topics in Israel Studies; Jewry of Muscle: Zionism and Jewish Masculinity

ISRL329M.title: Special Topics in Israel Studies; Mizrahi Identity in Israel

ISRL342.title: History of Modern Israel
ISRL342.description: History of modern Israel since the beginning of the Zionist settlement in 1882. Attention to different interpretations and narratives of Israel's history, including the historical and ideological roots of Zionism, the establishment of the State of Israel, ideological forces, wars, and the triumphs and crises of democracy.

ISRL343.title: Global Migration and the Israeli Case Study
ISRL343.description: Over 70% of Israel's population is made of first, second or third generation immigrants, who came from over 70 countries, making Israel an ultimate immigrant society. This course will focus on the history of Israel as a case study for the understanding of the historical phenomena of modern immigration.

ISRL349C.title: Investigating Topics in Israel Studies; The history of urbanization and urban culture in Israel

ISRL349M.title: Investigating Topics in Israel Studies; Israeli Society through History, Sociology and Art

ISRL349V.title: Investigating Topics in Israel Studies; The Arab-Israeli Conflict Through Film

ISRL448A.title: Seminar in Israel Studies; Understanding Israeli Politics

ISRL448Q.title: Seminar in Israel Studies; The Holy City and the Holy Mountain: a Sociological look at the Old City of Jerusalem and the Temple Mount

ISRL448V.title: Seminar in Israel Studies; The New Theater of Terror: Online Terrorism

ISRL448W.title: Seminar in Israel Studies; 1948 and The Transnational Struggle for Palestine

ITAL103.title: Intensive Elementary Italian
ITAL103.description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of Italian-speaking world.
ITAL103.prerequisite: Must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
ITAL103.restriction: Not open to fluent/native speakers of Italian.

ITAL203.title: Intensive Intermediate Italian
ITAL203.description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of Italian-speaking world.
ITAL203.prerequisite: ITAL103; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
ITAL203.restriction: Must not have completed ITAL122; and must not be a fluent/native speaker of Italian.

ITAL207.title: Reading and Writing in Italian
ITAL207.description: Culture-based, process approach to reading and writing in Italian; selected grammatical topics.
ITAL207.prerequisite: ITAL204; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
ITAL207.restriction: Must not be a fluent/native speaker of Italian.

ITAL211.title: Intermediate Conversation
ITAL211.description: Practice in spoken Italian based on reading and listening exercises in variety of genres. Written assignments and exams.
ITAL211.prerequisite: ITAL203; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.
ITAL211.restriction: Must not be a fluent/native speaker of Italian.

ITAL261.title: Cuisine, Culture, and Society in Italy Yesterday and Today
ITAL261.description: Exposes students to an important aspect of Italian culture: the art of gastronomy. Provides an in-depth understanding of the close relationship between food and culture, while enriching their knowledge of the Italian language through reading and analysis of various texts which deal with the preparation and adaptation of Italian food in different cultural settings. Taught in Italian.
ITAL261.prerequisite: ITAL204; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

ITAL311.title: Advanced Oral Expression: Current Events
ITAL311.description: Oral expression; development of idiomatic forms and vocabulary to level of the Italian press.
ITAL311.prerequisite: ITAL211; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

ITAL386.title: Experiential Learning
ITAL386.description: Prerequisite: Must have a Learning Proposal approved by the Office of Experiential Learning Programs, faculty sponsor, and student's internship sponsor.  Restriction: Junior standing or higher.
ITAL386.prerequisite: Must have a Learning Proposal approved by the Office of Experiential Learning Programs, faculty sponsor, and student's internship sponsor.

ITAL411.title: Monsters and Demons: the Faces of Evil in Dante's Inferno
ITAL411.description: An interdisciplinary study of Dante's Inferno as represented in the Divine Comedy. Special emphasis on Dante's own portrayal of monsters and demons and their roles in the poet's eschatological vision of Hell.Taught in English

ITAL473.title: Italian Cinema II - In Translation
ITAL473.description: A study of Italian society and culture through the medium of film from the mid 1970's to the present. Taught in English.

ITAL478D.title: Colloquium in Italian; Monsters and Demons: the Faces of Evil in Dante's Inferno

ITAL498G.title: Special Topics in Italian Literature; Homophobia and Anti-Feminism in Fascist Italy

JAPN102.title: Elementary Japanese II
JAPN102.description: Continued introduction to the basic spoken patterns of contemporary Japanese.
JAPN102.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JAPN101; or appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.

JAPN202.title: Intermediate Japanese II
JAPN202.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JAPN201; or appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.

JAPN302.title: Advanced Japanese II
JAPN302.description: Continued readings in varied modern texts and advanced conversation and oral comprehension.
JAPN302.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JAPN301; or permission of instructor.

JAPN314.title: Edo Text and Context: Origins of Japanese Popular Culture
JAPN314.description: Intensive reading of various genres of literary and historical texts from the early modern (Edo/Tokugawa) period, read in English translation. Taught in English.

JAPN315.title: Reading Japanese Empire
JAPN315.description: Reading a wide variety of cultural, intellectual, and official texts, this course explores how Japan's age of empire (1869-1945) was understood, imagined, and lived in various colonial contexts and in the metropolitan center. Students will gain a textured understanding of the complexities and contradictions of Japan's imperial project and the fraught ways this history plays out today in Japan and Asia. Taught in English.

JAPN386.title: Experiential Learning
JAPN386.description: Prerequisite: Must have a Learning Proposal approved by the Office of Experiential Learning Programs, faculty sponsor, and student's internship sponsor.  Restriction: Junior standing or higher.
JAPN386.prerequisite: Must have a Learning Proposal approved by the Office of Experiential Learning Programs, faculty sponsor, and student's internship sponsor.

JAPN401.title: Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
JAPN401.description: Development of advanced reading, vocabulary, grammar, and translation skills through selected readings in Japanese drawn primarily from modern literature.
JAPN401.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JAPN302; or permission of instructor.

JAPN425.title: The Atomic Bomb in Literature and Memory
JAPN425.description: Study of declassified documents and commentary on the United States decision to use the bomb in 1945, the many ways Japanese writers have attempted to express their indescribable experiences in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and the shaping of historical narratives and national identities in post-war Japan and the U.S.

JAPN438A.title: Topics in Japanese Pragmatics; Stylistic Variation in the Films of Miyazaki Hayao

JAPN438P.title: Topics in Japanese Pragmatics; Speech Acts and Politeness

JAPN498I.title: Special Topics in Japanese Studies; Zainichi Literature

JAPN498Z.title: Special Topics in Japanese Studies; Expatriate Korean Literature in Japan

JOUR106.title: Introduction to Studio Production
JOUR106.description: Students will participate in various production roles to assist in the production of UMTV shows.

JOUR130.title: Self-Presentation in the Age of YouTube
JOUR130.description: Students, as they make use of evolving technologies, need to be able to present themselves effectively in front of any number of different audiences through any number of different outlets. Whether in an interview on radio, a guest presentation at a conference, in comments on a video blog, in commentary on TV, in the lead on a self-produced YouTube video, or as spokesperson in front of investors or management, professionals need strong oral communication skills. This class focuses on strengthening those skills through active individual and group presentations, as well as, through discussion of key techniques and group critique of presentation publicly available in the social media space on sites such as YouTube.

JOUR150.title: Introduction to Mass Communication
JOUR150.description: Survey of the functions and effects of the mass media in the United States. A consumer's introduction to newspapers, television, radio, film, sound recording, books, magazines, and new media technology.
JOUR150.restriction: Not open to students who have completed JOUR100 prior to Fall 1999.

JOUR175.title: Media Literacy
JOUR175.description: An analysis of the information, values and underlying messages conveyed via television, newspapers, the internet, magazines, radio and film. Examines the accuracy of those messages and explores how media shape views of politics, culture and society.

JOUR181.title: Grammar for Journalists
JOUR181.description: The basic grammatical structures of standard American written English and its conventions of punctuation, diction and usage in journalistic writing.

JOUR200.title: Journalism History, Roles and Structures
JOUR200.description: Introduction to the study of journalism from the standpoint of media history and sociology.

JOUR201.title: News Writing and Reporting I
JOUR201.description: Introduction to news for the print and electronic media, development of new concepts: laboratory in news-gathering tools and writing skills. Students who earned 80% or higher on the JOUR181 diagnostic are exempt from the JOUR181 prerequisite.
JOUR201.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in ENGL101, JOUR181, and JOUR200; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.
JOUR201.restriction: For students intending to be journalism majors; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR202.title: News Editing
JOUR202.description: Copy editing, graphic principles and processes, new media technology.
JOUR202.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in JOUR203.
JOUR202.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR203.title: Introduction to Multimedia Skills
JOUR203.description: Examining the basics of producing and editing digital photos, video, and audio. Topics include: framing, lighting, and other aspects of composition; sequencing, using wide, medium, and tight shots; and ethical considerations when collecting sound and visuals.
JOUR203.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR262.title: News Videography
JOUR262.description: Introduction to shooting, editing and production of video stories for broadcast and the Web; includes newsgathering in the field.

JOUR289E.title: Media Law and Ethics in the Digital Age

JOUR289F.title: Beyond Facebook: How Social Media are Transforming Society, Culture, Business and Politics

JOUR289J.title: Probing War: Investigative Narratives and American Conflicts

JOUR289P.title: Scandal! Exposing Corruption, Injustice, and Vice in America

JOUR300.title: Journalism Ethics
JOUR300.description: Examination of ethical problems in news writing and reporting.
JOUR300.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR320.title: News Writing and Reporting II: Multiplatform
JOUR320.description: Principles and practices of news reporting; covering news beats and other news sources, including researching news stories for accuracy, comprehensiveness and interpretation. Due to rigorous publication requirement, plan your schedule accordingly.
JOUR320.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JOUR201.
JOUR320.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR324.title: Commentary and Editorial Writing
JOUR324.description: Journalistic interpretation and analysis; commentary and editorial writing.

JOUR325.title: Capital News Service Bureau
JOUR325.description: Advanced journalism training. Students report as part of College's Capital News Service program.
JOUR325.prerequisite: JOUR320; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR328F.title: Special Topics in News Writing and Reporting; National Security and Press Freedom Reporting

JOUR328I.title: Special Topics in News Writing and Reporting; Advanced Public Affairs Reporting/Investigative Reporting

JOUR328R.title: Special Topics in News Writing and Reporting; Business Reporting

JOUR350.title: Multimedia Presentation
JOUR350.description: An examination of the relationship of verbal and visual components of news content and the presentation of information in print and online publications by combining typography, graphics, images and interactivity using current digital technologies.
JOUR350.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JOUR202; or minimum grade of C- in JOUR262.

JOUR352.title: Interactive Design and Development
JOUR352.description: Conceptualize, wireframe, design and build responsive Web pages using HTML, style sheets and other coding tools; work with open source interactive tools, JavaScript libraries, multimedia and text to create charts, timelines, maps and other forms of nonfiction storytelling.
JOUR352.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR353.title: News Bureau: Multimedia Reporting
JOUR353.description: Advanced reporting and writing in an online environment focusing on multimedia and non-traditional storytelling.
JOUR353.prerequisite: JOUR352; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism; and (JOUR320 or JOUR360).

JOUR354.title: Interactive Multimedia Storytelling
JOUR354.description: Advanced development of multimedia journalism, with emphasis on interactivity and application of new technologies, drawing on multiple sources, technologies and techniques to create interactive narratives.
JOUR354.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR355.title: News Bureau: Multimedia Editing and Production
JOUR355.description: Advanced online journalism training. Students work as multimedia editor and producers, building interactive content and special reports.
JOUR355.prerequisite: JOUR202 or JOUR262; and (JOUR320 or JOUR360); and JOUR352; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR360.title: News Writing and Reporting II: Broadcast
JOUR360.description: Writing and reporting for broadcast media: production of news stories.
JOUR360.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JOUR201.
JOUR360.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR361.title: Television Reporting and Production
JOUR361.description: Writing and editing for the broadcast media. Interpretive and documentary news stories.

JOUR362.title: Broadcast News Producing
JOUR362.prerequisite: JOUR262 and JOUR360; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in JOUR361.

JOUR364.title: Radio Broadcasting
JOUR364.description: Students receive hands-on training in applying what they have learned about news reporting to the preparation of stories for, and the production of, a weekly radio program.
JOUR364.prerequisite: JOUR360; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR367.title: Broadcast News Bureau
JOUR367.description: Advanced broadcast journalism training. Students report as part of the College's Capital News Service program.
JOUR367.prerequisite: JOUR361; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR368B.title: Topics in Broadcast and Electronic Media; Broadcast Sports Reporting

JOUR368K.title: Topics in Broadcast and Electronic Media; Video Innovation

JOUR368M.title: Topics in Broadcast and Electronic Media; Multimedia Mobile Journalism

JOUR368T.title: Topics in Broadcast and Electronic Media; On-Camera Performance

JOUR368V.title: Topics in Broadcast and Electronic Media; Advanced Video Storytelling

JOUR370.title: Photojournalism
JOUR370.description: Examining the basics of shooting, editing and storytelling with still photos taken with 35mm digital cameras. Students shoot portraits, feature photos and action shots. Final project is a photo story/essay.

JOUR382.title: Sports Writing and Reporting
JOUR382.description: Gives students full and wide-ranging instruction in all aspects of sports reporting and writing, including how to report, write, edit and lay out sports stories, incorporating photography and multimedia. We will also discuss ethics, objectivity, fairness and the future of sports journalism.
JOUR382.prerequisite: JOUR320; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR396.title: Supervised Internship
JOUR396.description: Students will complete a minimum of 90 hours in a supervised journalism internship over a minimum of 10 weeks in spring and fall, and eight weeks in summer. Emphasis is on relating academic training to professional experience. Students may pick up an internship proposal form in KNI 1100, have their internship supervisor fill it out, and meet with the college's internship director to receive permission to register. No requests to register after the Schedule Adjustment Period will be granted. This requirement would affect incoming freshmen from the fall 2012 class.
JOUR396.prerequisite: Must have earned a grade of C- or better in JOUR320 or JOUR360.
JOUR396.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR400.title: Media Law
JOUR400.description: Legal rights and constraints of mass media; libel, privacy, copyright, monopoly, contempt, and other aspects of the law applied to mass communication. Previous study of the law not required.

JOUR405.title: Breaking News With Numbers: Statistics for Journalists
JOUR405.description: Common statistical tools, software and data visualization techniques will be used to allow students to analyze data and solve problems relevant to reporting and writing about politics, sports, criminal justice, business and other fields.
JOUR405.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in JOUR201; and (MATH107 or MATH110; or must have completed a higher level math course). Or have permission of the instructor.
JOUR405.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR443.title: Sports, Society, Culture and the Media
JOUR443.description: Designed to explore how sports, society, culture and the media critically relate to each other and the vast audiences of fans and interested parties. Students will study how journalists impact change; how sports shape culture; and how sports are seen throughout the world. College sports, children and sports, the business of sports, the history of sports media and the future of sports in society will be studied as well.

JOUR451.title: Advertising and Society
JOUR451.description: Advertising as an institution with manifest economic purposes and latent social effects. Influences of advertising on people, and related issues of ethics and social responsibility.

JOUR452.title: Women in the Media
JOUR452.description: Participation and portrayal of women in the mass media from colonial to contemporary times.

JOUR453.title: News Coverage of Racial Issues
JOUR453.description: Analysis of news media coverage of issues relating to racial minorities in the United States, with special attention to Hispanics, Asian Americans, African Americans and Native Americans.

JOUR455.title: Media Entrepreneurship
JOUR455.description: Basic business and entrepreneurship concepts will be covered and will explore how technology is transforming the business of media. Students develop and pitch ideas for media businesses, learn startup basics, do exercises in Internet advertising and business plan analysis, use social networks and other digital communication tools, and perform other hands-on exercises in business development and presentation.

JOUR456.title: Literature in Journalism
JOUR456.description: From Truman Capote's In Cold Blood to Mark Bowden's Black Hawk Down, students will examine how literary works can help writers approach a subject in a different way than more traditional forms of journalism, including the advantages and limitations of the style.

JOUR458B.title: Special Topics in Journalism; Sports Media Today

JOUR458L.title: Special Topics in Journalism; Leadership: Making a Difference

JOUR459T.title: Special Topics in Journalism; Press Freedom and Fake News: A Global Battle for Political  Power

JOUR472.title: Computer-Assisted Reporting
JOUR472.description: Computer and online data acquisition; analytical methods for writing and reporting news.

JOUR476.title: Researching Emerging Media in Journalism: Past, Present and Future
JOUR476.description: Students will examine developments billed as innovative in the current technology-laden news ecology -- such as social media, mobile reporting and virtual reality -- and the blurring of lines between hard news, informed opinion and advocacy. While questions about the future cannot be answered with any certainty, an exploration of the past allows us to see what happened when new technologies, information systems and practices appeared as possible tools for use by journalists and the communities they served. Students will learn to use resources for researching emerging media, including UMD library databases and open access sources. The course will include presentations by the instructor, discussions, field trips, in-class exercises and student presentations. Each student will engage in a research project to understand the experience of emerging media in a decade between 1820 and 1980. Students will also write an essay contemplating current trends and the future of emerging media.
JOUR476.prerequisite: Must have completed a university statistics course.

JOUR479A.title: Special Topics in Data Gathering and Analysis; Web Analytics

JOUR479I.title: Special Topics in Data Gathering and Analysis; Seeing - Media, Images and Design

JOUR479O.title: Special Topics in Data Gathering and Analysis; Understanding Audiences

JOUR480.title: Capstone Colloquium: The Business of News
JOUR480.description: Students will learn the basic news business concepts and examine how revenue and cost structures for media businesses are evolving in new directions. Topics include basic principles and concepts that drive media businesses in the Internet age, including revenue sources, dynamics of online advertising and subscriptions, mobile media strategies, user metrics, engaging audiences, and market dynamics.
JOUR480.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism; and junior standing or higher; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR603.title: News Videography
JOUR603.description: Introduction to shooting, editing and production of video stories for broadcast and the Web; includes newsgathering in the field.
JOUR603.prerequisite: JOUR504; and permission of Journalism College required.
JOUR603.restriction: Permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR610.title: Seminar in Mass Media History
JOUR610.description: Analysis and discussion of the interrelationships between the mass media and society, including various social and cultural elements of modern society; responsibilities of the mass media and the mass communicator.

JOUR620.title: Public Affairs Reporting
JOUR620.description: Designed to add to and sharpen the skills learned in JOUR501. It is primarily an introduction to "beat" reporting that allows students to sample the most common new beats while reporting and writing on deadline. Students are required to develop and hone their multimedia skills by reporting in a variety of media.
JOUR620.prerequisite: JOUR501; or permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR623.title: Mobile Journalism
JOUR623.description: A review of several mobile applications and the "hands-on" skills needed to collect and share news in the field. First, students learn how to remotely post information to blogs and social networks. Students then learn and practice the latest location-based production techniques using web services on wireless laptops and mobile devices. Students use laptops (and their own "SmartPhone") to record, edit and upload audio and video.
JOUR623.prerequisite: Students must have basic computer skills.

JOUR624.title: Commentary and Editorial Writing
JOUR624.description: Journalistic interpretation and analysis; commentary and editorial writing.

JOUR625.title: Advanced Capital News Service Bureau
JOUR625.description: Advanced journalism training. Students report as part of College's Capital News Service program.
JOUR625.prerequisite: JOUR620; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR628B.title: Specialized Topics in News Writing and Reporting; Sports Reporting and Writing

JOUR628N.title: Specialized Topics in News Writing and Reporting; National Security and Press Freedom Reporting

JOUR628R.title: Specialized Topics in News Writing and Reporting; Business Reporting

JOUR654.title: Advanced Interactive Multimedia Storytelling
JOUR654.description: Learning and applying Flash and/or other interactive tools to assemble multiple media (i.e. graphics, video, etc.) to create interactive narratives.
JOUR654.prerequisite: JOUR652; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR655.title: Advanced Online News Bureau
JOUR655.description: Advanced online journalism training. Students work as online reporters, editors and producers for a news site. Students also package copy from the print and broadcast news bureaus.
JOUR655.prerequisite: JOUR603 or JOUR620; and (JOUR504 and JOUR652). Or permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR660.title: Broadcast News Writing
JOUR660.description: Descriptive and critical analysis of broadcast news; methods of evaluation of news judgments; decision-making and organizational aspects of the broadcast news industry.

JOUR662.title: Broadcast News Producing
JOUR662.description: Learn and practice the basics of broadcast newscast producing. Design, write, edit and implement a news program.
JOUR662.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in JOUR661; and (JOUR603 and JOUR660).

JOUR667.title: Broadcast News Bureau
JOUR667.description: Advanced broadcast journalism training. Students report as part of the College's Capital News Service program.
JOUR667.prerequisite: JOUR503; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department. And permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR668K.title: Topics in Broadcasting and Electronic Media; Video Innovation

JOUR668V.title: Topics in Broadcasting and Electronic Media; Advanced Video Storytelling

JOUR670.title: Photojournalism
JOUR670.description: Examining the basics of shooting, editing and storytelling with still photos taken with 35mm digital cameras. Students shoot portraits, feature photos and action shots. Final project is a photo story/essay.
JOUR670.restriction: Must be in a major in JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism; and permission of JOUR-Philip Merrill College of Journalism.

JOUR689F.title: News Coverage of Specialized Topics; Feature Writing

JOUR698I.title: Special Problems in Communication; Advanced Public Affairs Reporting/Investigative Journalism

JOUR772.title: Methods in Computer-Assisted Reporting
JOUR772.description: Computer-assisted (database) journalism; obtaining, manipulating and analyzing complex government data for journalism projects.
JOUR772.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in JOUR501; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

JOUR776.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Journalism and Public Communication
JOUR776.description: Methods of historical, critical and field research in journalism and public communication.  Formulation of significant research questions, systematic collection of bibliographic and phenomenal information, formulating substanial claims, organizing and writing research for disciplinary outlets.

JOUR801.title: Advanced Public Communication Theory
JOUR801.description: Advanced selected survey of communication & media theory.
JOUR801.prerequisite: JOUR601; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

JOUR889.title: Doctoral Tutorial in Journalism and Public Communication

JOUR899.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Journalism and Mass Communication

JWST225.title: Religions of the Ancient Near East
JWST225.description: Introduction to ancient Near Eastern religious systems and mythology, from the third millennium BCE through the fourth century BCE. Particular emphasis on Mesopotamia and ancient Israel.

JWST230.title: Rabbinic Movement: History and Culture
JWST230.description: Introduction to the Rabbinic movement and its history, first to seventh century CE. Survey of the essential texts of ancient Rabbinic literature, both halakhic (legal) and aggadic (non-legal).

JWST260.title: Introduction to Classical Hebrew I
JWST260.description: Readings of the Bible and other classical texts in original Hebrew. Emphasis on classical grammar and vocabulary, and reading of textual passages.
JWST260.prerequisite: HEBR111; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

JWST272.title: Introduction to Jewish Literature
JWST272.description: A survey of Jewish literature and introduction to methods of reading literature in general and Jewish literature in particular. Concern with what makes a literary corpus Jewish and other issues of canonicity. All texts in English translation.

JWST281.title: Yiddish I
JWST281.description: Introduction to the Yiddish language, with emphasis on speaking, reading, and writing skills. Students will also learn the history of the language, its significance to Jewish culture, its origins and basic structure.

JWST319C.title: Special Topics in Jewish Studies; Women and Jewish Literature

JWST319D.title: Special Topics in Jewish Studies; Mizrahi Identity in Israel

JWST319K.title: Special Topics in Jewish Studies; Jewry of Muscle: Zionism and Jewish Masculinity

JWST319L.title: Special Topics in Jewish Studies; Sexuality in Jewish Culture

JWST333.title: Jews in Early Modern Times 1450-1750
JWST333.description: Emergence of new powerful population centers, religious and cultural creativity, new forms of community, and radical messianic movements.

JWST345.title: The Holocaust of European Jewry
JWST345.description: Roots of Nazi Jewish policy in the 1930s and during World War II: the process of destruction and the implementation of the "final solution of the Jewish problem" in Europe, and the responses made by the Jews to their concentration and annihilation.

JWST386.title: Experiential Learning in Jewish Studies
JWST386.description: The Jewish Studies Program's internship program. Pre-professional experience in research, analysis, and writing related to Jewish Studies in a variety of work settings.
JWST386.prerequisite: Permission of ARHU-Meyerhoff Program & Center for Jewish Studies.

JWST418.title: Honors Thesis Research in Jewish Studies

JWST429O.title: Advanced Topics in Jewish Studies; 1948 and the Transnational Struggle for Palestine

JWST499.title: Independent Study in Jewish Studies; Independent Study in Jewish Studies

JWST619J.title: Directed Readings in Jewish Studies; Testimony of Witness: Trauma, History and Narratives of Witness

JWST658.title: Readings in Jewish Thought and Culture

KNES131Z.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Beginning Softball

KNES140O.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Tumbling and Balancing (Intermediate)

KNES140V.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Tumbling and Balancing (Beginning)

KNES144Q.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Martial Arts, Karate (Beginning)

KNES154T.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Swimming, Fitness (Intermediate)

KNES154W.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Swimming/Lifeguard Training

KNES157N.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Weight Training (Beginning)

KNES157O.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Weight Training (Intermediate)

KNES157T.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Fight the 15: Introduction to Fitness and an Active Lifestyle

KNES161G.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Yoga for Fitness (Intermediate)

KNES161K.title: Physical Education Activities: Coed; Cardio Kickboxing (Beginning)

KNES201.title: Kinesiological Principles of Physical Activity
KNES201.description: An introduction to Kinesiology, the study of human movement, through the experience of learning a specific motor skill or being engaged in physical activity. Emphasis on the theories and knowledge underlying the learning and performance of all motor and sport skills.
KNES201.restriction: Must be in a major in SPHL-School of Public Health.

KNES214.title: Science and Methods of Personal Fitness Instruction
KNES214.description: Basic concepts of human anatomy, exercise physiology, applied kinesiology, nutrition and the physiology of exercise training. Includes the CORE knowledge required for the American Council on Exercise (ACE) Personal Trainer certification.

KNES222.title: Gambling in the New Millennium: Poker, The Preakness, Point-spreads, Powerball and Public Policy
KNES222.description: Is gambling in the public interest? Students will critically examine the various implications of "what it means to gamble" through investigations of various gambling forms, different sectors of the gambling industry and the related economics, along with consumer behavior, sport, public policy and public health in this context.

KNES260.title: Science of Physical Activity and Cardiovascular Health
KNES260.description: Course details (1) the public health importance of and the processes underlying cardiovascular disease, (2) the risk factors for cardiovascular disease and the methods whereby they were identified, and (3) the principles of the scientific evidence supporting the use of physical activity to prevent cardiovascular disease.

KNES282.title: Basic Care and Prevention of Athletic Injuries
KNES282.description: Theoretical and practical foundations of the prevention, treatment and rehabilitation of athletically related injuries. Topics include: physical conditioning, preventive taping, recognition of injuries, first aid and CPR.
KNES282.restriction: Must be in a major within the SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES286.title: Empowering Healthy Physical Activity
KNES286.description: Learn evidence-based techniques that health professionals use to promote physical activity programs that meet the needs of diverse populations. Develop and implement an intervention plan targeting a specific population.

KNES287.title: Sport and American Society
KNES287.description: Sport will be related to such social problems as delinquency, segregation, collective behavior, and leisure; to social processes such as socialization, stratification, mobility, and social control; and to those familiar social institutions the family, the school, the church, the military, the economy, the polity, and the mass media.

KNES289P.title: Topical Investigations; Mathematical and Physical Bases of Human Movement and Performance

KNES293.title: History of Sport in America
KNES293.description: The growth and development of sport in America. The transformation of sport within the perspective of American history, including class sport, professionalization, amateurism, and international involvement.

KNES300.title: Biomechanics of Human Motion
KNES300.description: The study of human movement and the physical and physiological principles upon which it depends. Body mechanics, posture, motor efficiency, sports, the performance of a typical individual and the influence of growth and development upon motor performance.
KNES300.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI201. And 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (MATH112, MATH113, MATH115); or (must have completed one General Education: Fundamental Studies-Math course with a minimum grade of C-; and must have math eligibility of MATH140 or higher).  Prerequisite:
KNES300.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.Restriction:

KNES300H.title: Biomechanics of Human Motion
KNES300H.description: The study of human movement and the physical and physiological principles upon which it depends. Body mechanics, posture, motor efficiency, sports, the performance of a typical individual and the influence of growth and development upon motor performance.
KNES300H.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI201. And 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (MATH112, MATH113, MATH115); or (must have completed one General Education: Fundamental Studies-Math course with a minimum grade of C-; and must have math eligibility of MATH140 or higher).
KNES300H.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES332.title: Exercise Testing and Prescription for the Fitness Professional
KNES332.description: Practical applications of exercise physiology and psychology to target fitness instruction for the general adult population Includes discussion of certification standards and professional development as well as evaluation of program safety and current trends.
KNES332.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in KNES360.  Prerequisite:
KNES332.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.  Restriction:

KNES332H.title: Exercise Testing and Prescription for the Fitness Professional
KNES332H.description: Practical applications of exercise physiology and psychology to target fitness instruction for the general adult population Includes discussion of certification standards and professional development as well as evaluation of program safety and current trends.
KNES332H.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in KNES360.
KNES332H.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES333.title: Motor Development and Fitness for Individuals with Disabilities
KNES333.description: Implications of Federal and State regulations for planning and implementing motor development and physical fitness programs for individuals with disabilities. Evaluation strategies for assessing motor performance and fitness levels in educational programs for these individuals.
KNES333.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in KNES287 and KNES370.
KNES333.restriction: Must be in a major within the SPHL-Kinesiology department; and must have earned a minimum of 45 credits.

KNES335.title: Swimming Pool Management
KNES335.description: Analysis of the position of the swimming pool manager. The systematic treatment of swimming pool water; swimming pool first aid; and laws pertaining to swimming pool operation. Qualifies the student for a pool operator's license in most Maryland counties.

KNES350.title: The Psychology of Sports
KNES350.description: An exploration of personality factors, including but not limited to motivation, aggression and emotion, as they affect sports participation and motor skill performance.

KNES350H.title: The Psychology of Sports
KNES350H.description: An exploration of personality factors, including but not limited to motivation, aggression and emotion, as they affect sports participation and motor skill performance.

KNES355.title: Sport Management
KNES355.description: Application of concepts and issues related to management principles and business concerns across various sections of the sport industry. Principles pertaining to the management of sport organizations.
KNES355.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in a major within the SPHL-Kinesiology department.  Restriction:

KNES355H.title: Sport Management
KNES355H.description: Application of concepts and issues related to management principles and business concerns across various sections of the sport industry. Principles pertaining to the management of sport organizations.
KNES355H.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in a major within the SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES360.title: Physiology of Exercise
KNES360.description: A study of the physiology of exercise, including concepts of work, muscular contraction, energy transformation, metabolism, oxygen debt, and nutrition and athletic performance. Emphasis on cardiovascular and respiratory function in relation to physical activity and training.
KNES360.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI202 and BSCI201; or permission of SPHL-Kinesiology department.  Prerequisite:
KNES360.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Kinesiology; Public Health Science).Restriction:

KNES360H.title: Physiology of Exercise
KNES360H.description: A study of the physiology of exercise, including concepts of work, muscular contraction, energy transformation, metabolism, oxygen debt, and nutrition and athletic performance. Emphasis on cardiovascular and respiratory function in relation to physical activity and training.
KNES360H.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI202 and BSCI201; or permission of SPHL-Kinesiology department.
KNES360H.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Kinesiology; Public Health Science).

KNES370.title: Motor Development
KNES370.description: Motor development across the life span. The developmental sequences of motor skills from birth to old age; neuromaturation of neuromuscular system; analysis of the underlying mechanisms of motor skill development; and correlates of motor development.
KNES370.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.Restriction:

KNES370H.title: Motor Development
KNES370H.description: Motor development across the life span. The developmental sequences of motor skills from birth to old age; neuromaturation of neuromuscular system; analysis of the underlying mechanisms of motor skill development; and correlates of motor development.
KNES370H.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES385.title: Motor Control and Learning
KNES385.description: Physiological and cognitive bases for motor control and their applications to the acquisition of movement skills and understanding of movement disorders. Topics include: neurophysiology, motor control theory, sensory/perceptual processes, perception-action coupling, information processing, memory, attention, individual differences, motivation, practice organization and role of feedback.
KNES385.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.Restriction:

KNES385H.title: Motor Control and Learning
KNES385H.description: Physiological and cognitive bases for motor control and their applications to the acquisition of movement skills and understanding of movement disorders. Topics include: neurophysiology, motor control theory, sensory/perceptual processes, perception-action coupling, information processing, memory, attention, individual differences, motivation, practice organization and role of feedback.
KNES385H.restriction: Must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES386.title: Experiential Learning
KNES386.description: Explore and analyze concepts and procedures related to a quality service-learning experience to include planning, implementing, and evaluating a service-learning project.
KNES386.prerequisite: Must have completed three KNES core classes.
KNES386.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES400.title: The Foundations of Public Health in Kinesiology
KNES400.description: An investigation of the role of physical activity and inactivity in relation to health and well-being through a public health perspective. Past and current perspectives on health promotion, health education, and social policies and approaches will be examined for various populations.
KNES400.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in KNES287; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in KNES360.  Prerequisite:
KNES400.restriction: Senior standing or higher; and must be in a major within the SPHL-Kinesiology department.  Restriction:

KNES400H.title: The Foundations of Public Health in Kinesiology
KNES400H.description: An investigation of the role of physical activity and inactivity in relation to health and well-being through a public health perspective. Past and current perspectives on health promotion, health education, and social policies and approaches will be examined for various populations.
KNES400H.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in KNES287; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in KNES360.
KNES400H.restriction: Senior standing or higher; and must be in a major within the SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES442.title: Psychology of Exercise and Health
KNES442.description: Examines the antecedents and consequences of exerciese behavior. Explores motivation, attitude, control, socialization. Proposes intervention strategies at the individual, organizational and societal levels.

KNES442H.title: Psychology of Exercise and Health
KNES442H.description: Examines the antecedents and consequences of exerciese behavior. Explores motivation, attitude, control, socialization. Proposes intervention strategies at the individual, organizational and societal levels.

KNES451.title: Children and Sport: A Psychosocial Perspective
KNES451.description: Examination of youth sports from a psychosocial perspective, including the impact of highly structured sports on young athletes and the complex social network of coaches, parents and peers.
KNES451.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.Restriction:

KNES451H.title: Children and Sport: A Psychosocial Perspective
KNES451H.description: Examination of youth sports from a psychosocial perspective, including the impact of highly structured sports on young athletes and the complex social network of coaches, parents and peers.
KNES451H.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES457.title: Managing Youth Programs: Educational, Fitness and Sport
KNES457.description: An examination of the basic functions involved in managing physical education, fitness, and youth sports programs. Focus on leadership skills, organizational management, and techniques for applying learned skills in a variety of organizational settings that serve the nation's youth.

KNES460.title: Physiology of Aging and the Impact of Physical Activity
KNES460.description: Biology of the aging process in healthy individuals and those with chronic disease, the effects of acute exercise and exercise training on the physiological decline that occurs in humans, and the role that regular physical activity plays on enhancing the quality of life and activities of daily living in individuals.

KNES460H.title: Physiology of Aging and the Impact of Physical Activity
KNES460H.description: Biology of the aging process in healthy individuals and those with chronic disease, the effects of acute exercise and exercise training on the physiological decline that occurs in humans, and the role that regular physical activity plays on enhancing the quality of life and activities of daily living in individuals.

KNES461.title: Exercise and Body Composition
KNES461.description: An in-depth overview on how body composition is measured, what it is composed of, and the physiological and biochemical signals that change it. The effects of acute and chronic exercise on food storage, breakdown, and use as an energy source, is the major focus. This information is applied to important issues in public health and athletic performance.

KNES461H.title: Exercise and Body Composition
KNES461H.description: An in-depth overview on how body composition is measured, what it is composed of, and the physiological and biochemical signals that change it. The effects of acute and chronic exercise on food storage, breakdown, and use as an energy source, is the major focus. This information is applied to important issues in public health and athletic performance.

KNES464.title: Exercise Metabolism: Role in Health and Disease
KNES464.description: Examines the role of metabolism in kinesiology, especially as it relate to physical inactivity, health and disease. Includes bioenergetics, substrate utilization, cell signaling, and metabolic gene expression and their impact on chronic health conditions or disease.

KNES464H.title: Exercise Metabolism: Role in Health and Disease
KNES464H.description: Examines the role of metabolism in kinesiology, especially as it relate to physical inactivity, health and disease. Includes bioenergetics, substrate utilization, cell signaling, and metabolic gene expression and their impact on chronic health conditions or disease.

KNES466.title: Graded Exercise Testing
KNES466.description: Functional and diagnostic examination of the cardiovascular responses to graded exercise testing. Emphasis on electrophysiology, mechanisms of arrhythmias, normal electrical activation of the heart, axis termination and the normal 12-lead electrocardiogram.
KNES466.prerequisite: KNES360; or permission of SPHL-Kinesiology department.Prerequisite:

KNES466H.title: Graded Exercise Testing
KNES466H.description: Functional and diagnostic examination of the cardiovascular responses to graded exercise testing. Emphasis on electrophysiology, mechanisms of arrhythmias, normal electrical activation of the heart, axis termination and the normal 12-lead electrocardiogram.
KNES466H.prerequisite: KNES360; or permission of SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES477.title: Honors Thesis
KNES477.description: Advisement will be on the individual basis. Thesis must be defended in the honors seminar.
KNES477.restriction: Must be a KNES Honors student; and senior standing.

KNES483.title: Sport Marketing and Media
KNES483.description: Industry practices in sport marketing and media. Marketing strategies and consumer behavior in different sport contexts. Critical examination of selected social and economic issues related to the buying and selling of sport.
KNES483.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.Restriction:

KNES483H.title: Sport Marketing and Media
KNES483H.description: Industry practices in sport marketing and media. Marketing strategies and consumer behavior in different sport contexts. Critical examination of selected social and economic issues related to the buying and selling of sport.
KNES483H.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in a major within SPHL-Kinesiology department.

KNES485.title: Sport and Globalization
KNES485.description: Examination of sport culture from a global perspective; focuses on theorizing the similarities and differences between various national sporting cultures.

KNES497.title: Kinesiology Senior Seminar
KNES497.description: Discussions of contemporary issues vital to the discipline, critiques of research in the student's area/areas of special interest, completion of a major project where the student will be asked to demonstrate the ability to carry out investigative processes in problem solving and critical writing under faculty direction.
KNES497.prerequisite: A professional writing course with a minimum grade of C-; and all 7 KNES core courses and 2 KNES option courses. And STAT100; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department. And minimum grade of C- in KNES400; or must be concurrently enrolled in KNES400.
KNES497.restriction: Senior standing or higher; and must be in Kinesiology program.

KNES498T.title: Special Topics in Kinesiology; Principles and Applications of Exercise Rehabilitation

KNES498W.title: Special Topics in Kinesiology; Prosthetics for Limb Amputations

KNES601.title: Epidemiology of Physical Activity
KNES601.description: An exploration of basic epidemiological study design, methods, and health outcomes in the field of physical activity.
KNES601.prerequisite: KNES600; and must have completed an undergraduate statistics course (e.g., STAT100 or equivalent).

KNES610.title: Methods and Techniques of Research
KNES610.description: Studies methods and techniques of research used in Kinesiology; an analysis of examples of their use; and practice in their application to problems of interest to the student.

KNES618.title: Current Readings in Exercise and Applied Physiology

KNES689K.title: Special Problems in Kinesiology; Research Design: Physical Cultural Studies

KNES689N.title: Special Problems in Kinesiology; Curriculum Development in Physical Education

KNES689O.title: Special Problems in Kinesiology; Psychology of Exercise and Health

KNES689T.title: Special Problems in Kinesiology; Teaching Internship

KNES689Y.title: Special Problems in Kinesiology; Public Health and Research Ethics

KNES694.title: Metabolic Aspects of Exercise Physiology
KNES694.description: Effects of exercise on digestion, absorption, transport, storage, mobilization, and utilization of macronutrients. Emphasis on the effects of exercise training on energy metabolism.

KNES711.title: Professional Development and Grantsmanship
KNES711.description: Enhance continued professional development through an exploration of culture, climate, expectations and mentoring in research I universities. Generate a grant application including the hypothesis, structure, specific aims, background and significance, and submission of a total grant. Grant process and product will be emphasized.
KNES711.restriction: Must be a Doctoral student; and must be in a major in SPHL-School of Public Health.

KNES786.title: Capstone Project in Physical Activity and Public Health
KNES786.description: The culminating experience in which the student applies knowledge and skills learned in the MPH program to conduct independent work on a physical activity problem under the supervision of a faculty advisor.
KNES786.prerequisite: KNES600, EPIB610, EPIB650, HLSA601, HLTH665, MIEH600, and KNES601.

KNES789C.title: Advanced Projects in Kinesiology; Computational Motor Control and Learning: Engineering the Mind

KNES789R.title: Advanced Projects in Kinesiology; Brain Dynamics and EEG: Applications to Cognitive-motor Performance

KORA102.title: Elementary Korean II
KORA102.description: Continued training in elementary spoken and written Korean.
KORA102.prerequisite: KORA101; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
KORA102.restriction: Must be a non-Heritage student; and permission of instructor required for new students.

KORA202.title: Intermediate Korean II
KORA202.description: The second stage of an intermediate-level course designed for non-Heritage students. It continues the second year of instruction in the University's two track Korean Program.

KORA212.title: Introductory Reading for Speakers of Korean II
KORA212.description: Continuation of KORA211; grammar, style, usage, and vocabulary of written Korean.
KORA212.prerequisite: KORA211; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
KORA212.restriction: Must not have completed four or more years of schooling in Korea.

KORA345.title: Korean Language and Linguistics
KORA345.description: An exploration of Korean language and society, in particular the role and nature of the alphabet, Korean sounds, lexical and grammatical structures, and usage in today's South Korea.
KORA345.prerequisite: KORA102 or KORA211; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

KORA398G.title: Special Topics in Korean Studies; Cold War Cultures in Korea

LARC120.title: Digital Fundamentals
LARC120.description: An introduction to fundamental computer tools and techniques commonly used in design communication and landscape architecture practice. Non-drafting computer tools will be used to orient basic digital image capture, manipulation, and presentation formatting.
LARC120.restriction: Permission of AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department; and must be in Landscape Architecture program.

LARC160.title: Introduction to Landscape Architecture
LARC160.description: History, theory, philosophy and current practice of the profession of landscape architecture. Explores the interactive relationship between humans and their environment by examining people's perceptions of and changing attitude towards the landscape, as well as, an examination of how these are related to ecological and cultural influences.

LARC221.title: Digital Design Tools
LARC221.description: The development and application of computing skills as used by the landscape architecture profession. This Computer-Aided Design and Drafting (CADD) course develops computer drafting using a variety of software programs. It also introduces students to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) mapping technologies.
LARC221.restriction: Sophomore standing or higher; and must be in Landscape Architecture program.

LARC240.title: Graphic Communication and Design Studio
LARC240.description: Exploration of graphic presentation techniques and original concept development for landscape architecture planning and design.
LARC240.restriction: Sophomore standing or higher; and must be in Landscape Architecture program.

LARC263.title: History of Landscape Architecture
LARC263.description: A survey of landscape architecture history from the ancient Western civilizations to the twentieth century with consideration of parallel developments in the Eastern World, European Africa and the Americas.

LARC321.title: Landscape Structures and Materials
LARC321.description: An examination of the use, properties, and detailing of materials used in landscape construction. The use and design of structures in the landscape.
LARC321.restriction: Must be in Landscape Architecture program.

LARC341.title: Regional Design Studio
LARC341.description: An examination of the landscape architect's role within the interdisciplinary regional design field incorporating GIS technologies, spatial modeling, and the regional design process.
LARC341.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and must be in Landscape Architecture program.

LARC461.title: People and the Environment
LARC461.description: Focus is placed on human and environmental interactions. Students will look at both natural and built environments and how they influence human health and well-being. Many environmental settings will be examined. These include hospitals, public housing neighborhoods, school settings, retirement communities, transportation corridors and green spaces. We will also explore how racial and socio-economic factors affect living and working environmental conditions. Ultimately, students will be using this knowledge to create environments that support individuals, families and various community groups' health and well-being.

LARC471.title: Capstone Studio: Community Design
LARC471.description: A capstone experience that emphasizes the integration of critical thinking skills and methodologies introduced throughout the landscape architecture curriculum. Students apply design and analysis methodologies, evaluate alternative solutions, involve community residents and engage in final design development, using the master plan and site design process, report writing, and oral and graphic presentations. Final presentations are open to the university and the community.
LARC471.restriction: Senior standing; and must be in Landscape Architecture program.

LARC489E.title: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture; Planting Design

LARC489V.title: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture; Digital Design Tools

LARC641.title: Graduate Studio II
LARC641.description: Principles and techniques of site analysis, environmental design and site development for human settlements and interaction with natural systems. Will expand analytical skills through complex site design problems. Students will research, observe and apply low impact development and sustainable practices, become familiar with building and landscape types by investigating alternative arrangements on the land, and understand user needs and design for populations with a range of abilities. Will support LEED and sustainable practices and acknowledge the requirements of public health, safety, and welfare.
LARC641.restriction: Permission of AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department.

LARC663.title: Landscape and Garden History
LARC663.description: History of garden making and its evolution into design practice. Students will become familiar with narratives of garden art and landscape architecture through the study of selected key sites, designers, and visual written sources. A focus on gardens' past and afterlife; the nature of primary sources (both built and written), and how these can be evaluated and used. Primary sources will be drawn from several disciplines and include a wide array of genres: treatises, epistolary exchanges, tax returns, novels, poems, paintings and drawings.
LARC663.restriction: Permission of AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department.

LARC671.title: Landscape Architecture Research Methods
LARC671.description: Investigation and discussion of broad scope of research methods and the development of landscape design and planning research techniques and skills. The urban environment will be viewed primarily as a social and psychological environment, with concern for who uses these environments and the conflicts that can arise between user groups.
LARC671.restriction: Permission of AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department.

LARC699.title: Independent Studies in Landscape and Architecture

LARC720.title: Environmental Analysis and Site Engineering
LARC720.description: Techniques for prediction of alterations in social and natural processe brought about by human use of the land; application of such assessments to environmental management; basic methods of landscape alteration, augmentation, and control including grading, drainage, road and trail design, and stormwater management.
LARC720.prerequisite: LARC640; or permission of AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department.

LASC235.title: Issues in Latin American Studies II
LASC235.description: Major issues shaping Latin American and Caribbean societies including the changing constructions of race, ethnicity, gender and class as well as expressions of popular cultures and revolutionary practices. A continuation of LASC/PORT/SPAN234, but completion of 234 is not a prerequisite. Taught in English.

LASC235H.title: Issues in Latin American Studies II
LASC235H.description: Major issues shaping Latin American and Caribbean societies including the changing constructions of race, ethnicity, gender and class as well as expressions of popular cultures and revolutionary practices. A continuation of LASC/PORT/SPAN234, but completion of 234 is not a prerequisite. Taught in English.

LASC251.title: Latin America Since Independence
LASC251.description: Introductory survey of the history of Latin America from the era of independence (c. 1810-1825) through the early 1980s. Major themes include independence and sovereignty, postcolonialism and neocolonialism, nation- and state-building, liberalism, citizenship, economic development and modernization, social organization and stratification, race and ethnicity, gender relations, identity politics, reform and revolution, authoritarianism and democratization, and inter-American relations.

LASC286.title: Internship in Latin American/Caribbean Studies
LASC286.description: Internship experience with an organization that works with or studies Latin American and/or the Caribbean. This is an experiential learning course that provides semester-long training that enriches the student's academic field of study and the LASC Certificate. Students submit a final written report of how the experience ties into their major field of study.
LASC286.prerequisite: LASC234, SPAN234, LASC235, SPAN235, LASC250, HIST250, LASC251, or HIST251; and permission of Latin American Studies Center required.
LASC286.restriction: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5; and cannot have more than 60 credits total.

LASC348E.title: Special Topics in Latin American Studies; Caribbean Literature

LASC448A.title: Special Topics in Latin American Studies; Caribbean Literature by Women

LASC486.title: Internship in Latin American/Caribbean Studies
LASC486.description: Internship experience with an organization that works with or studies Latin American and/or the Caribbean. This is an experiential learning course that provides semester-long training that enriches the student's academic field of study and the LASC Certificate. Students submit a final written report of their experience, including critical analysis of the institutional relevance to their major field of study and to Latin American Studies. Students will also be asked to give an oral presentation.
LASC486.prerequisite: Student must have completed at least two LASC courses, one of which must be a required/core course (LASC/SPAN234, LASC/SPAN235, LASC/HIST250, or LASC/HIST251); and permission of Latin American Studies Center required.
LASC486.restriction: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5; and must have earned a minimum of 60 credits.

LATN101.title: Elementary Latin I
LATN101.description: Additional information: A student who has two units of Latin in high school may register for LATN101 for the purposes of review, but ordinarily not for credit.

LATN201.title: Intermediate Latin
LATN201.description: Prerequisite: Must have completed LATN102 at University of Maryland, College Park; or permission of ARHU-Classics department.  Formerly: LATN203.
LATN201.prerequisite: Must have completed LATN102 at University of Maryland, College Park; or permission of ARHU-Classics department.

LATN301.title: Plautus
LATN301.description: Plautine drama. Literary, linguistic and socio-cultural aspects. Readings are in Latin.

LATN499.title: Independent Study in Latin Language and Literature

LATN623.title: The Augustan Age
LATN623.description: Analysis of the major literary figures and genres in prose and poetry of the period from 43 BC to AD 14.

LBSC602.title: Serving Information Needs
LBSC602.description: An introduction to the skills necessary to interact directly with individuals through the exploration of user behavior theory, strategies to locate and evaluate information from print and electronic resources, and policies and procedures to ensure that all individuals can become information literate.
LBSC602.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC622.title: Information and Universal Usability
LBSC622.description: Information services and technologies to provide equal experiences and outcomes to all users. Laws, standards, approaches, component concepts, access needs, and technologies in relation to physical and online information environments.
LBSC622.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC631.title: Achieving Organizational Excellence
LBSC631.description: Overview of the principles, practices, and techniques required for effective leadership and management. The innovative strategies, management responsibilities, and skills needed to achieve and sustain high organizational performance in information-based cultural institutions.
LBSC631.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC641.title: Selecting and Evaluating of Resources for Learning
LBSC641.description: Policies and procedures for collection development, including identifying, evaluating, acquiring, providing, and promoting resources in all formats, to support learning and teaching in elementary and secondary schools.
LBSC641.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC646.title: Literature and Materials for Young Adults
LBSC646.description: Survey of literature and other materials for older children and adolescents. Criteria for evaluating and using such materials as they relate to the needs, interests, reading abilities, and other capabilities of young readers.
LBSC646.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC671.title: Creating Information Infrastructures
LBSC671.description: Foundations of acquiring and managing collections, information structures, indexing and discovery systems needed by information professionals. An introduction to the theoretical concepts, trends, systems, and technologies central to the information field.
LBSC671.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC680.title: Principles of Records and Information Management
LBSC680.description: Principles and practices of managing records in the context of information management programs in government, corporate and other institutional settings. Includes access; legal requirements; digital technologies; and creation, administration, appraisal, and retention and disposition of records.
LBSC680.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC702.title: User Instruction
LBSC702.description: Critical analysis of the rationale, content, and processes of user instruction in library and information settings.
LBSC702.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC703.title: Field Study in Archives and Digital Curation
LBSC703.description: Supervised internship experience in archives or digital curation programs in organizations and institutions.
LBSC703.prerequisite: LBSC602, LBSC631, and LBSC671; and must have completed 9 additional credits. Or permission of instructor.
LBSC703.restriction: Must be in Library and Information Science (Master's) program; and permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC707.title: Field Study in Information Service
LBSC707.description: Supervised internship experience in a library, archive, museum, or other information organization.
LBSC707.prerequisite: LBSC602, LBSC671, and LBSC631; and must have completed an additional 9 credits. Or permission of instructor.
LBSC707.restriction: Must be in Library and Information Science (Master's) program; and permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC708P.title: Special Topics in Library and Information Science; in America

LBSC713.title: Planning and Evaluating Library and Information Services
LBSC713.description: An investigation of quantitative and qualitative methods used to plan and evaluate the effectiveness of library and information services. Planning and evaluation methodologies will be analyzed and critiqued. Selected methods will be demonstrated and/or utilized.
LBSC713.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC734.title: Seminar in the Academic Library
LBSC734.description: Role of the academic library within the framework of higher education. Planning programs and services, collections, support, fiscal management, physical plant, and cooperation.
LBSC734.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC742.title: Collaborative Instructional Design and Evaluation
LBSC742.description: School librarians' collaborative role in instruction. Systematic design development, and evaluation of instructional strategies and products for learning.
LBSC742.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC744.title: Internship in School Libraries
LBSC744.description: Opportunities to observe and participate in the operation of school libraries at the elementary and secondary levels under the supervision of certified school librarians. Required of all School Library Media certification candidates.
LBSC744.prerequisite: INST650, LBSC641, INST651, and LBSC741; or permission of instructor.
LBSC744.restriction: Permission of instructor; and permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.

LBSC785.title: Documentation, Collection, and Appraisal of Records
LBSC785.description: Development of documentation strategies and plans; collecting policies to guide programs in acquiring records; theories and techniques for appraising records to identify those with continuing value.
LBSC785.prerequisite: LBSC605 or INST604; or permission of instructor.
LBSC785.restriction: Permission of INFO-College of Information Studies.
