Instrumental and sensory methods for evaluating sensory quality, identity and wholesomeness and their integration into grades and standards of quality. Statistical Process Control (SPC).

NFSC434.title: Food Microbiology Laboratory
NFSC434.description: A study of techniques and procedures used in the microbiological examination of foods.
NFSC434.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in NFSC430.

NFSC450.title: Food and Nutrient Analysis
NFSC450.description: Methods and practices of the analysis of foods and nutrients. An overview of the principles and basic mechanisms used in many of the analytical procedures commonly used in food and nutrition research. Emphasis will be placed on hands-on development of skills necessary to complete each analytical procedure; and on the accurate and concise description of the methodology and results from their application and on the regulations governing food analysis for nutritional labeling.

NFSC460.title: Medical Nutrition Therapy
NFSC460.description: Modifications of the normal adequate diet to meet human nutritional needs in acute and chronic diseases and metabolic disorders.
NFSC460.prerequisite: NFSC380 and NFSC440; and permission of AGNR-Nutrition and Food Science department.

NFSC470.title: Community Nutrition
NFSC470.description: Perspectives underlying the practice of nutrition services in community settings. Assessment of needs, program planning and evaluation. Programs and strategies to meet nutrition needs outside the acute care setting, such as nutrition education and food assistance. National nutrition policy and federal initiatives in nutrition will be examined. Students will be required to travel to local community nutrition sites during the semester.
NFSC470.prerequisite: NFSC315; and permission of AGNR-Nutrition and Food Science department.

NFSC490.title: Special Problems in Nutrition
NFSC490.description: Individually selected problems in the area of human nutrition.
NFSC490.prerequisite: NFSC440; and permission of AGNR-Nutrition and Food Science department.

NFSC491.title: Issues and Problems in Dietetics
NFSC491.description: A capstone course for dietetics majors. Students will integrate knowledge and theory of nutrition, food, management, psychology, and social behaviors necessary to support quality dietetic practice. Working in teams, students will participate in case studies, simulated situations and community projects. Individuals and groups will present cases as well as papers on published research.
NFSC491.prerequisite: NFSC350; and permission of AGNR-Nutrition and Food Science department.
NFSC491.restriction: Senior standing or higher; and must be in Nutrition and Food Science: Dietetics program.

NFSC498L.title: Selected Topics; Diet and Optimal Human Health

NFSC633.title: Food Polymer Science
NFSC633.description: Food polymers including protein and carbohydrate from food, and their chemical, physical, and functional properties together with their structure-function relationship will be discussed. Food polymer applications in food and non-food areas will be covered. Principles and applications of instrumental methods for polymer characterization will be introduced. An emphasis on nanotechnology and its application to design and characterization food polymers will be included.

NFSC678L.title: Selected Topics in Nutrition; Diet and Optimal Human Health

NFSC678M.title: Selected Topics in Nutrition; Current Topics in Nutrition and Inflammatory Disease

NFSC679E.title: Selected Topics in Food Science; .Mechanics of Food Processing

NFSC688.title: Seminar in Nutrition and Food Science

NFSC699.title: Problems in Nutrition and Food Science

NIAP788A.title: Special Topics in National Institue of Aerospace Engineering; Applied Numerical Method

NIAV788W.title: Advanced Topics; Statistics for Engineers and Scientists

PERS102.title: Elementary Persian II
PERS102.description: Continuation of PERS101 with emphasis on the use of formal language, vocabulary building, and reading.
PERS102.prerequisite: PERS101; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
PERS102.restriction: Must not be native/fluent speaker of Persian.

PERS212.title: Intermediate Reading in Persian
PERS212.description: Focus on linguistic skill specific to reading; introduction to written traditions of Persian.
PERS212.prerequisite: PERS211 and PERS201; or permission of instructor.

PERS252.title: Gender and Body in Iran
PERS252.description: Multidisciplinary approach to key topics concerning gender and body in Iran, to include insights from religion, history, sociology, anthropology, disability studies, travel literature, arts, and fashion. Taught in English.

PERS302.title: Advanced Persian II
PERS302.description: Further development of speaking, reading, writing, listening and cultural knowledge, with special focus on reading, in a variety of literary genres.
PERS302.prerequisite: PERS301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
PERS302.restriction: Must not be native/fluent speaker of Persian.

PERS312.title: Contemporary Iranian Culture
PERS312.description: Study of the culture of contemporary Iran (post-evolution) with focus o the contemporary social, political, literary and artistic life in Iran. Taught in Persian.
PERS312.prerequisite: PERS301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
PERS312.restriction: Must not be native/fluent speaker of Persian.

PERS386.title: Experiential Learning
PERS386.description: Pre-professional experience in research, analysis and writing in a work setting. Project proposal approved by faculty and internship sponsor.
PERS386.restriction: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

PERS398B.title: Special Topics in Persian Studies; Arts, Leisure, and Entertainment: Urban Life in Modern Iran

PERS498A.title: Special Topics in Persian Studies; Advanced Literary Skills in Persian

PERS498D.title: Special Topics in Persian Studies; Political, Economic, and Social Thought in Today's Iran

PERS498E.title: Special Topics in Persian Studies; Translation of Contemporary Persian Texts

PERS498G.title: Special Topics in Persian Studies; Masterpieces of Persian Literature

PERS498M.title: Special Topics in Persian Studies; Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in the Islamic World

PERS689M.title: Special Topics in Persian Studies; Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in the Islamic World

PHIL100.title: Introduction to Philosophy
PHIL100.description: An introduction to the literature, problems, and methods of philosophy either through a study of some of the main figures in philosophic thought or through an examination of some of the central and recurring problems of philosophy.

PHIL140.title: Contemporary Moral Issues
PHIL140.description: The uses of philosophical analysis in thinking clearly about such widely debated moral issues as abortion, euthanasia, homosexuality, pornography, reverse discrimination, the death penalty, business ethics, sexual equality, and economic justice.

PHIL170.title: Introduction to Logic
PHIL170.description: Development of analytical reasoning skills through study of formal logics, reasoning systems, and fallacious inference patterns.

PHIL209A.title: Philosophical Issues; Bioethics: Regulating Right and Wrong

PHIL209J.title: Philosophical Issues: The Rights and Wrongs of Killing People

PHIL209N.title: Know Thyself: Wisdom Through Cognitive Science

PHIL230.title: Philosophy of the Arts
PHIL230.description: A survey of theoretical perspectives on the arts from Plato to the present, along with critical examination of specific works of art. Analysis of concepts central to thought about art, such as beauty, form, content, expression, representation, interpretation, creation, style, medium, realism, aesthetic experience, and aesthetic value.

PHIL261.title: Philosophy of the Environment
PHIL261.description: An evaluation of different kinds of arguments for the claim that the natural environment should be preserved. Perspectives cut across the disciplines of philosophy (environmental ethics and philosophies of nature); economics (cost-benefit analysis); and biology (evolution, ecology, environmental studies).

PHIL282.title: Free Will & Determinism
PHIL282.description: A study of the main positions and arguments in the free will debate in contemporary analytic philosophy.

PHIL309P.title: Philosophical Problems; Philosophy, Politics and Economics

PHIL318B.title: Studies in Epistemology/Metaphysics; The Wisdom of Crowds

PHIL320.title: Modern Philosophy
PHIL320.description: A study of major philosophical issues of the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries through an examination of such philosophers as Descartes, Newton, Hume, and Kant.

PHIL338B.title: Studies in Value Theory; PHILOSOPHY OF FILM

PHIL364.title: Metaphysics
PHIL364.description: The study of some central metaphysical concepts and issues including th nature and validity of metaphysical thinking, universals, identity, substance, time, God, and reality.

PHIL366.title: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL366.description: An introduction to core issues in the philosophy of mind, focusing especially on the basic metaphysical question of dualism versus physicalism.

PHIL386.title: Experiential Learning
PHIL386.description: Restriction: Permission of ARHU-Philosophy department; and junior standing or higher.
PHIL386.restriction: Permission of ARHU-Philosophy department; and junior standing or higher.

PHIL408B.title: Topics in Contemporary Philosophy; Bayesian Epistemology

PHIL408P.title: Topics in Contemporary Philosophy; Moral Psychology

PHIL414.title: The Philosophy of Aristotle
PHIL414.description: A critical study of selected portions of Aristotle's writings.

PHIL640.title: Value Theory
PHIL640.description: A basic course in value theory for beginning graduate students, coverin  a number of topics in depth, to provide a springboard for further study  and research in the area.

PHIL788G.title: Research in Philosophy; Research in Philosophy

PHIL788I.title: Research in Philosophy; Research in Philosophy

PHIL799.title: Master's Thesis Research; Masters Thesis Research

PHIL808E.title: Seminar in the Problems of Philosophy; Contractarianism: Old and New

PHIL808F.title: Seminar in the Problems of Philosophy; Varieties of Explanation

PHIL858I.title: Seminar in Logic and Philosophy of Sciences; Quantum Correlation and Causation

PHIL879A.title: Seminar in Philosophy and Cognitive Studies; Representation in Cognitive Science

PHIL899.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research; Doctoral Dissertation Research

PHSC401.title: History of Public Health
PHSC401.description: Emphasis is on the history of public health in the Western world from antiquity to the present. Also examines the influence of public health developments as they relate to the Western world as well as throughout diverse cultures and societies across the globe.  Analysis focuses on the interaction among Western and non-Western cultures with respect to health issues, including science, policies, prevention and treatment.
PHSC401.restriction: Must be in Public Health Science program; and must have earned a minimum of 45 credits.

PHSC415.title: Essentials of Public Health Biology: The Cell, The Individual, and Disease
PHSC415.description: Presents the basic scientific and biomedical concepts of modern public health problems and explores in depth mechanisms and models of the major categories of disease. The biologic principles presented are foundations to public health disease prevention, control, or management programs.
PHSC415.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI202.
PHSC415.restriction: Must be in Public Health Science program; and junior standing or higher.

PHSC420.title: Vaccines and Immunology
PHSC420.description: An exploration of immunology and vaccines through a public health lens. We will examine the cells, systems, and molecules that comprise the human immune system and defend your body against disease. In addition, we will discuss the strategies used during vaccine development including the history and future of vaccination and how increased understanding of the immune system has allowed scientists to improve and refine the process. Finally we will examine the current social and political situation surrounding vaccination and the roles and responsibility of public health practitioners.
PHSC420.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI223.
PHSC420.restriction: Must have earned a minimum of 60 credits. And must be in Public Health Science program; or permission of instructor.

PHSC430.title: Public Health in the City: Perspectives on Health in the Urban Environment
PHSC430.description: Exposure to issues related to city habitation and the health of the public, including how the urban environment impacts the lives and health of city dwellers, including discussion of the social determinants of health. Students are encouraged to think about urban health and policy, and to question the current state of urban public health.  Issues of race, class, and equality will be discussed throughout the course as they relate to each of these topics.
PHSC430.prerequisite: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI202 and MIEH300.
PHSC430.restriction: Must be in Public Health Science program; and junior standing or higher.

PHSC497.title: Public Health Science Capstone
PHSC497.description: The capstone course is the culminating experience for Public Health Science students and must be taken only in the final semester of study. The Public Health Science capstone course is designed to challenge students to integrate the five core areas of public health in investigating, researching and addressing public health issues. Throughout the semester, students will be required to evaluate, analyze and synthesize scholarly works as they research and propose solutions to a variety of public health issues. By the conclusion of this research based course, students will understand how the various public health perspectives can combine in addressing and informing public health practices.
PHSC497.prerequisite: Students must have completed the professional writing requirement, MIEH300 and EPIB300, all with a C- or higher.
PHSC497.restriction: Must have earned a minimum of 100 credits; and must be in Public Health Science program; and must be in the final semester of undergraduate study.

PHYS106.title: Light, Perception, Photography, and Visual Phenomena
PHYS106.description: Intended for the general student, this course will cover topics in optics which require minimal use of mathematics. Principles of optics, lenses, cameras, lasers and holography, physics of the eye, color vision and various visual phenomena such as rainbows.

PHYS107.title: Light, Perception, Photography and Visual Phenomena Laboratory
PHYS107.description: Optional laboratory to accompany PHYS106. Laboratory experiments include geometrical optics (lenses, cameras, eye), optical instruments (telescope, binoculars), photography, perception, color phenomena, and wave phenomena.

PHYS121.title: Fundamentals of Physics I
PHYS121.description: The first part of a two-semester course in general physics treating the fields of mechanics, heat, sound, electricity, magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Together with PHYS122, this generally satisfies the minimum requirement of medical and dental schools.

PHYS122.title: Fundamentals of Physics II
PHYS122.description: A continuation of PHYS121, which together with it, generally satisfies the minimum requirement of medical and dental schools.
PHYS122.prerequisite: PHYS121; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

PHYS131.title: Fundamentals of Physics for Life Sciences I
PHYS131.description: The first part of a two-semester course in general physics specifically oriented towards applications relevant for students in biology and pre-medical programs. The course covers basic mechanics including forces and energy, properties of matter, and thermodynamics done in authentic biological contexts.
PHYS131.prerequisite: MATH130, MATH131, and CHEM131; and (BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106); and (BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105). Or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

PHYS132.title: Fundamentals of Physics for Life Sciences II
PHYS132.description: The second part of a two-semester course in general physics specifically oriented towards applications relevant for students in biology and pre-medical programs. The course covers basic statistical physics, electricity and magnetism, and optics done in authentic biological contexts.
PHYS132.prerequisite: PHYS131; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

PHYS161.title: General Physics: Mechanics and Particle Dynamics
PHYS161.description: First semester of a three-semester calculus-based general physics course. Laws of motion, force, and energy; principles of mechanics, collisions, linear momentum, rotation, and gravitation.
PHYS161.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in MATH141.

PHYS165.title: Introduction to Programming in the Physical Sciences
PHYS165.description: Introduction to programming using examples in the physical sciences. Provides instruction in the techniques of upper-level languages such as Fortran, C, and Pascal, as well as an introduction to the object oriented programming techniques used in Python, C++ and Java. Includes strong component of visualization and graphing.
PHYS165.prerequisite: PHYS171, PHYS141, or PHYS161; or must have scored 3 or higher on AP PHYS exam.

PHYS171.title: Introductory Physics: Mechanics and Relativity
PHYS171.description: First semester of a three semester sequence for physics majors and those desiring a rigorous preparation in the physical sciences: kinematics, Newton's laws, energy and work, linear and angular momenta, temperature and pressure, ideal gas law, and special relativity.
PHYS171.prerequisite: (MATH140; and a high school physics course); or permission of CMNS-Physics department. And must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in MATH141.

PHYS174.title: Physics Laboratory Introduction
PHYS174.description: Introduces students to the techniques of data gathering and analysis. This course will lay a foundation for higher-level labs in physics and the physical sciences. Students will learn to use laboratory equipment such as calipers, meters, oscilloscopes, and computer interfaces. Techniques of measurement and error analysis will be presented. Students will be taught to use the computer for data analysis with an emphasis on using spreadsheets.

PHYS260.title: General Physics: Vibration, Waves, Heat, Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS260.description: Second semester of a three-semester calculus-based general physics course. Vibrations, waves, fluids; heat, kinetic theory, and thermodynamics; electrostatics, circuits, and magnetism. PHYS260 and PHYS261 must be taken in the same semester.

PHYS261.title: General Physics: Vibrations, Waves, Heat, Electricity and Magnetism (Laboratory)
PHYS261.description: Lab includes experiments on mechanics, vibrations, waves, heat, electricity and magnetism. PHYS260 and PHYS261 (lab) must be taken in the same semester.

PHYS261M.title: General Physics: Vibrations, Waves, Heat, Electricity and Magnetism (Laboratory)
PHYS261M.description: Lab includes experiments on mechanics, vibrations, waves, heat, electricity and magnetism. PHYS260 and PHYS261 (lab) must be taken in the same semester.

PHYS270.title: General Physics: Electrodynamics, Light, Relativity and Modern Physics
PHYS270.description: Third semester of a three-semester calculus-based general physics course. Electrodynamics, Maxwell's equations and electromagnetic waves, geometrical optics, interference, diffraction, special theory of relativity, and modern physics. PHYS270 and PHYS271 (lab) must be taken in the same semester.

PHYS271.title: General Physics: Electrodynamics, Light, Relativity and Modern Physics (Laboratory)
PHYS271.description: Lab includes experiments on ac circuits, magnetism, light and modern physics. PHYS270 and PHYS271 (lab) must be taken in the same semester.

PHYS271M.title: General Physics: Electrodynamics, Light, Relativity and Modern Physics (Laboratory)
PHYS271M.description: Lab includes experiments on ac circuits, magnetism, light and modern physics. PHYS270 and PHYS271 (lab) must be taken in the same semester.

PHYS272.title: Introductory Physics: Fields
PHYS272.description: Second semester of a calculus based general physics course. Universal gravitation, electric and magnetic fields and potentials, simple circuits, Maxwell's equations in integral form. Continues the application of mathematics to conceptual models, now with more abstract components.
PHYS272.prerequisite: PHYS161 or PHYS171; and MATH141; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in MATH241.  Prerequisite:

PHYS272H.title: Introductory Physics: Fields
PHYS272H.description: Second semester of a calculus based general physics course. Universal gravitation, electric and magnetic fields and potentials, simple circuits, Maxwell's equations in integral form. Continues the application of mathematics to conceptual models, now with more abstract components.
PHYS272H.prerequisite: PHYS161 or PHYS171; and MATH141; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in MATH241.

PHYS273.title: Introductory Physics: Waves
PHYS273.description: Oscillations and AC circuits using complex variables, Fourier series an integrals, waves on strings, sound; electromagnetic waves from Maxwell's equations in differential form; physical optics.

PHYS273H.title: Introductory Physics: Waves
PHYS273H.description: Oscillations and AC circuits using complex variables, Fourier series an integrals, waves on strings, sound; electromagnetic waves from Maxwell's equations in differential form; physical optics.

PHYS274.title: Mathematical Methods for Physics I
PHYS274.description: A first course in mathematical methods for physics. Topics include linear algebra, curvilinear coordinates and vector analysis.

PHYS275.title: Experimental Physics I: Mechanics and Heat
PHYS275.description: Methods and rationale of experimental physics. Intended for physics majors and science and engineering students who desire a more rigorous approach. Experiments chosen from the areas of mechanics (from PHYS171), gas laws, and heats. Theory and applications of error analysis.

PHYS276.title: Experimental Physics II:  Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS276.description: Second course in the three semester introductory sequence. Methods and rationale of experimental physics. Experiments chosen from the fields of electricity and magnetism including electrostatics, magnetostatics, magnetic induction, AC circuits.

PHYS299B.title: Special Problems in Physics; Developing a Physics Toolbox

PHYS332.title: Physics for Life Sciences II
PHYS332.description: The second part of a two-semester course in general physics specifically oriented towards applications relevant for students in biology and pre-medical programs. The course covers basic statistical physics, electricity and magnetism, and optics done in authentic biological contexts.
PHYS332.prerequisite: PHYS331; or PHYS131; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

PHYS371.title: Modern Physics
PHYS371.description: Introduces students to special relativity, thermodynamics and quantum mechanics at an intermediate level.

PHYS373.title: Mathematical Methods for Physics II
PHYS373.description: A second course in mathematical methods for physics. Topics include introduction to ordinary differential equations, partial differential equations, and complex analysis.

PHYS375.title: Experimental Physics III: Electromagnetic Waves, Optics and Modern Physics
PHYS375.description: Third course in the three-semester introductory sequence. Methods and rationale of experimental physics. Experiments chosen from the areas of electromagnetic waves, optics and modern physics.

PHYS399C.title: Special Problems in Physics; Physics STEM Seminar

PHYS399E.title: Special Problems in Physics; Physics STEM Seminar III

PHYS401.title: Quantum Physics I
PHYS401.description: Introduces some quantum phenomena leading to wave-particle duality. Schroedinger theory for bound states and scattering in one dimension. One-particle Schroedinger equation and the hydrogen atom.

PHYS402.title: Quantum Physics II
PHYS402.description: Quantum states as vectors; spin and spectroscopy, multiparticle systems the periodic table, perturbation theory, band structure, etc.

PHYS404.title: Introduction to Statistical Thermodynamics
PHYS404.description: Introduction to basic concepts in thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.

PHYS405.title: Advanced Experiments
PHYS405.description: Advanced laboratory techniques. Selected experiments from many fields o modern physics. Emphasis on self-study of the phenomena, data analysis, and presentation in report form.
PHYS405.restriction: Must be in a major within CMNS-Physics department.

PHYS407.title: Undergraduate Experimental Research
PHYS407.description: Students develop and complete an independent, experimental research project with a professor in the Physics Department. The project should be a continuation of work done in PHYS499A. To obtain permission, students must submit a proposal describing the experimental work to be completed and this proposal must be approved by their faculty mentor, the associate chair for undergraduate education and the chair of the laboratory committee. Students must maintain a lab notebook, give an oral presentation and complete a written report on their research that includes data and error analysis.
PHYS407.prerequisite: PHYS499 and PHYS375; and permission of CMNS-Physics department.
PHYS407.restriction: Must be in a major within CMNS-Physics department; and senior standing.

PHYS410.title: Classical Mechanics
PHYS410.description: Theoretical foundations of mechanics with extensive application of the methods. Various mathematical tools of theoretical physics.

PHYS411.title: Intermediate Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS411.description: Foundations of electromagnetic theory, with extensive applications of the methods. Thorough treatment of wave properties of solutions of Maxwell's equations.

PHYS420.title: Principles of Modern Physics
PHYS420.description: A survey of atomic and nuclear phenomena and the main trends in modern physics. Appropriate for students in engineering and other physical sciences.
PHYS420.prerequisite: MATH246. And PHYS271 and PHYS270; or PHYS273.

PHYS431.title: Properties of Matter
PHYS431.description: Introduction to solid state physics. Electromagnetic, thermal, and elastic properties of metals, semiconductors, insulators and superconductors.
PHYS431.prerequisite: PHYS271, PHYS270, and MATH241; and (PHYS401 or PHYS420).

PHYS457.title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
PHYS457.description: An introduction to the concept of a quantum computer, including algorithms that outperform classical computation and methods for performing quantum computation reliably in the presence of noise. As this is a multidisciplinary subject, the course will cover basic concepts in theoretical computer science and physics in addition to introducing core quantum computing topics.
PHYS457.prerequisite: 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (MATH240, PHYS274); and 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (CMSC351, PHYS373).

PHYS499M.title: Special Problems in Physics; Physics, Material Chemistry and Device Applications at the Nanoscale

PHYS499O.title: Special Problems in Physics; Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics

PHYS499T.title: Special Problems in Physics; Accelerator Physics - Building the Maryland 5 MeV Cyclotron

PHYS603.title: Methods of Statistical Physics
PHYS603.description: Foundations and applications of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.

PHYS606.title: Electrodynamics
PHYS606.description: Classical electromagnetic theory, electro- and magnetostatics, Maxwell equations, waves and radiation, special relativity.
PHYS606.prerequisite: PHYS604; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

PHYS615.title: Nonlinear Dynamics of Extended Systems
PHYS615.description: Theory and applications of nonlinear dynamics of extended systems including nonlinear waves, pattern formation, turbulence, self-organized criticality and networks. Additional topics to be selected by instructor from areas of current research.

PHYS623.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics II
PHYS623.description: First and second semesters. A study of the Schroedinger equation, matrix formulations of quantum mechanics, approximation methods, scattering theory etc., and applications to solid state, atomic, and nuclear physics. Continuation of PHYS 622.
PHYS623.prerequisite: Must have an outstanding undergraduate background in physics.

PHYS709.title: Seminar in General Physics; Statistical Physics

PHYS728.title: Seminar in Atomic and Molecular Physics

PHYS731.title: Solid State Physics: Survey
PHYS731.description: A variety of topics such as crystal structure, mechanical, thermal, electrical, and magnetic properties of solids, band structure, the Fermi surface, and superconductivity will be treated. Although the emphasis will be on the phenomena, the methods of quantum mechanics are freely employed in this description.

PHYS738.title: Seminar in Experimental Solid State Physics; Quantum Mechanical Many-Body Problems

PHYS739.title: Seminar in Theoretical Solid State Physics; Quantum Mechanical Many-Body Problems

PHYS748.title: Seminar in Experimental Nuclear Physics; Seminar in Nuclear Physics

PHYS758E.title: Seminar in Elementary Particles and Quantum Field Theory; Experimental Results Including Cosmic Ray Physics

PHYS759.title: Seminar in Elementary Particles and Quantum Field Theory

PHYS769.title: Seminar in Plasma Physics; Plasma Physics Research

PHYS778.title: Seminar in Space and Cosmic Ray Physics

PHYS798B.title: Special Problems in Advanced Physics; Physics Colloquium

PHYS798D.title: Special Problems in Advanced Physics; Applied Dynamics Seminar

PHYS798L.title: Special Problems in Advanced Physics; Biophysics

PHYS798N.title: Special Problems in Advanced Physics; Data Practicum at the Intersection of the Physical, computer, and Life Sciences

PHYS838C.title: Special Topics in Experimental Solid State Physics; Center for Nanophysics and Advanced Materials Seminar

PHYS839A.title: Special Topics in Theoretical Solid State Physics

PHYS851.title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
PHYS851.description: Renormalization, unitarity, gauge theory, S-matrix construction.

PHYS879G.title: Special Topics in General Relativity; Gravitational Wave Physics

PHYS879J.title: Special Topics in General Relativity; String Theory Reading Group

PHYS889E.title: Special Topics in Interdisciplinary Problems; Seminar in Physics Education Research

PLCY201.title: Leadership for the Common Good
PLCY201.description: This course is designed to provide undergraduate students an introduction to leadership theory and a chance to practice a core set of practical skills relevant to transformational and collaborative leadership.

PLCY215.title: Innovation and Social Change: Creating Change for Good
PLCY215.description: A team-based, highly interactive and dynamic course that provides an opportunity for students to generate solutions to a wide range of problems facing many communities today.  Students in the iGIVE Program will deepen their understanding of entrepreneurship and innovation practices by creating and implementing projects or ventures that address an issue of their choosing while learning topics such as communications, project management, teamwork, leadership, fundraising, project sustainability and next steps in social change.

PLCY301.title: Sustainability
PLCY301.description: Designed for students whose academic majors would be enhanced by the complementary study of a widely shared but hard-to-operationalize aspiration: that present choices should preserve or improve future options rather than foreclose or degrade them. How should we understand sustainability? How might we achieve it? How would we know if we had achieved it? And how could sustainability activists of a rising generation lead by example?

PLCY302.title: Leadership: Philosophy, Policy and Praxis
PLCY302.description: Leadership as a search for meaning, identity and purpose are explored. Also introduces major philosophical traditions, from the ancient world to the modern one, and encourages students to ground their leadership interests and aspirations in a disciplined process of self-reflection, critical thinking and inquiry.

PLCY311.title: Women in Leadership
PLCY311.description: Examines the role of women in the leadership process including the participation of women as activists, voters, advocates, public leaders and as agents of change through various avenues including, among others, public service (elected and appointed), the media, community service, political organizations, and the nonprofit sector.

PLCY313.title: Advocacy in the American Political System
PLCY313.description: Introduces students to the creation of law through the legislative process with a special focus on the Maryland General Assembly.

PLCY349.title: Internship in Political Institutions: State and Local

PLCY386.title: Experiential Learning
PLCY386.description: Prerequisite: Permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.  Repeatable to 12 credits if content differs.  Credit only granted for: PLCY386 or PUAF386.  Formerly: PUAF386.
PLCY386.prerequisite: Permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.  Repeatable to 12 credits if content differs.

PLCY388G.title: Special Topics in Public Policy; Global Perspectives on Leading and Investing in Social Change

PLCY610.title: Quantitative Aspects of Public Policy
PLCY610.description: Introduces statistical methods needed for evaluating and choosing among policy options. Topics include probability; decision-making under uncertainty; the organization, interpretation, and visual display of complex data; prediction and inferences about causality; hypothesis testing; and linear and multiple regression. Develops analytical skills and the ability to apply theory to complex, real-world problems.
PLCY610.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY611.title: Quantitative Analysis of Policy Issues
PLCY611.description: Study of a series of problems and the development of quantitative techniques to describe or evaluate the problem. The organization and interpretation of complex data and its use for prediction and inference about casual effects. The definition of objectives, trade-offs among objectives, and allocation of resources to meet objectives. Sensitivity of outcomes to changing conditions.
PLCY611.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY640.title: Microeconomic and Policy Analysis
PLCY640.description: Applies intermediate microeconomic theory to public policy issues: resource allocation by firms and consumers; the response of economic agents to changes in incentives; market allocations in competitive and non-competitive environments; and market failures and government remedies. Uses extended case studies of particular issues in such areas as the environment (acid rain), international trade (tariffs), industry regulation (cable TV), and the provision of public goods (highways).
PLCY640.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY688C.title: Topics in Public Policy; Cyberspace: Legal and Policy Implications

PLCY688E.title: Topics in Public Policy; Governance: Normative & Political Dimensions

PLCY688F.title: Topics in Public Policy; State, Local & Non-Profit Financial Management

PLCY688G.title: Topics in Public Policy; Governance: Leadership, Management and Accountability

PLCY688I.title: Topics in Public Policy; Macroeconomics for Publis Policy

PLCY688R.title: Topics in Public Policy; Public Budgeting and Financial Management

PLCY688T.title: Topics in Public Policy; Team-Based Policy Lab

PLCY688X.title: Topics in Public Policy; Human Dignity

PLCY688Z.title: Topics in Public Policy; Climate Policy Implementatin Seminar

PLCY689E.title: Public Policy Topics; Program Evaluation and Cost-Benefit Analysis

PLCY689F.title: Public Policy Topics; Current Issues in Federal Acquisition

PLCY689L.title: Public Policy Topics; Science and Technology Policy

PLCY698E.title: Selected Topics in Public Affairs; Proseminar in Normative Public Policy

PLCY698R.title: Selected Topics in Public Affairs; Developmental Challenges

PLCY699F.title: Selected Topics Public Policy; Ethics of Public Administration

PLCY699G.title: Selected Topics Public Policy; Leadership in Groups and Organization

PLCY699Y.title: Selected Topics Public Policy; Globalization, Business and Development

PLCY699Z.title: Selected Topics Public Policy; Energy Policy

PLCY717.title: Federal Budgeting: Policy and Process
PLCY717.description: Budgeting as a political and administrative instrument of government. Development of budgeting, the multiple uses of the budget, including role in fiscal policy and resource allocation, the roles and relationships of major participants, and effects of resource scarcity on budgeting behavior. Emphasis on the federal level.
PLCY717.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY720.title: International Security Policy
PLCY720.description: Reviews the principal features of international security as currently practiced. Traces the evolution of contemporary policy beginning with the initiation of nuclear weapons programs during World War II. Particular emphasis is given to experience of the United States and Russia, since the historical interaction between these two countries has disproportionately affected the international security conditions that all other countries now experience.
PLCY720.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY732.title: Policy and Politics of Education Reform
PLCY732.description: Examines education reform in its historical, fiscal, cultural, and lega contexts, and the changing relationship between education and economic opportunity. Focuses on institutional and normative issues, including national standards, public school choice, charter schools, vouchers and funding equity.
PLCY732.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY734.title: Foundations of Social Policy
PLCY734.description: Provides an overview of government's role in social policy and the history of the development of federal and state policies with respect to welfare, aging, education, and housing. Analyzes current federal institutions and legislation in the same policy areas and the demographic history of the United States. Develops skills in analytic writing and presentation of descriptive data.
PLCY734.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY740.title: Public Policy and the Environment
PLCY740.description: Surveys of major federal environmental legislation; the development and implementation of laws, and alternative ways of thinking about the relationship between humans and the environment.
PLCY740.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY745.title: Human Health and Environmental Policy
PLCY745.description: Reviews the major human physiological systems and their integrated toxicological functions; considers key bodily defenses; and discusses classic, emerging, and ambiguous risks; in all ecological context. Applies to scientific controversy, the methods of policy formation, such as risk analysis, social-cost analysis, "outcomes" analysis, and decision analysis, all in political-economic context.

PLCY780.title: The American Foreign Policy-Making Process
PLCY780.description: Survey and analysis of the governmental institutions and processes which shape U.S. global engagement on national security and international economic issues. Particular emphasis is given to executive-congressional relations and the broader domestic roots of foreign policy.
PLCY780.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY781.title: International Economic Policy
PLCY781.description: Issues and choices facing the United States in today's global economy. Primary, but not exclusive, emphasis is given to "competitive interdependence" among advanced industrial societies.
PLCY781.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY782.title: International Development Economics
PLCY782.description: Examines key current economic and policy issues for developing and transition economies. Topics include inflation stabilization, fiscal policy, selected trade issues, dealing with international capital flows, the role of multilateral organizations, such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, and issues relating to saving, investment and growth.
PLCY782.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY790.title: Project Course
PLCY790.description: Students work at a sponsoring government agency or private firm researching problem of interest to sponsor and relevant to concentration. Emphasis on problem definition, organizing information, and both oral and written presentation of results.
PLCY790.restriction: Must be in a major in PLCY-School of Public Policy; or permission of PLCY-School of Public Policy.

PLCY798F.title: Readings in Public Policy; Moral Foundations of Intelligence

PLCY798R.title: Readings in Public Policy; Quantitative Research Methods and Public Policy

PLSC100.title: Introduction to Horticulture
PLSC100.description: An overview to the art and science of horticulture. Relationships between plant science and plant production, the use of horticultural plants and plant stress as influenced by cultural practices.

PLSC226.title: Plant Diversity
PLSC226.description: Students will learn to identify and understand relationships among major plant families of northeastern North America, especially of the Mid-Atlantic region, through lecture, field, and laboratory study. Characteristics and biogeography of and evolutionary relationships among families are emphasized in lecture. These characteristics will be woven together to provide understanding of the ecological and evolutionary drivers of plant diversity and the history of the field. Sight identification of families, genera, and species and keying skills are stressed in field and laboratory sessions.

PLSC235.title: Irrigation and Drainage
PLSC235.description: An overview of U.S. and state water doctrines and plant water use rates Irrigation systems for residential and athletic field use will be discussed covering such topics as hydraulics, sprinkler spacing, pipe selection and sizing, pumps, controllers, valves, and irrigation trouble shooting. Surface and subsurface drainage for turfgrass sites will also be covered.

PLSC251.title: Financial Applications for the Green Industry
PLSC251.description: An introduction to the application of financial principles in the Green Industry business sector. Accounting, pricing, and estimating, job cost management and production efficiency are discussed and manifested in Scholarship In Practice exercises, case studies and a business plan project.

PLSC254.title: Woody Plants for Mid-Atlantic Landscape II
PLSC254.description: A field and laboratory study of trees, shrubs, and vines used in ornamental plantings. Major emphasis is placed on introduced and evergreen plant materials.
PLSC254.prerequisite: PLSC100 and PLSC253; or permission of instructor.

PLSC271.title: Plant Propagation
PLSC271.description: A study of the principles and practices in the propagation of plants.
PLSC271.prerequisite: PLSC100; or (BSCI170 and BSCI171); or BSCI105.

PLSC275.title: Fundamentals of Agricultural Chemistry
PLSC275.description: An in-depth discussion of chemistry targeted to students enrolled in plant and animal management curricula offered in AGNR. Covers the nomenclature and basic functional groups in organic chemistry, secondary plant metabolites, basic tenets of organic agriculture and the creation of genetically-modified plants. The chemistry, handling and usage of agricultural pesticides is also discussed.
PLSC275.prerequisite: CHEM131 and CHEM132. And PLSC100; or PLSC101; or (BSCI160 and BSCI161); or (BSCI170 and BSCI171); or BSCI105; or BSCI106.
PLSC275.restriction: Must not have completed CHEM104 or CHEM105. And must be in a major within the AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department; or must be in a major within the AGNR-Animal & Avian Sciences department; or permission of instructor.

PLSC303.title: Global Food Systems
PLSC303.description: An introduction to the global food system and its agricultural, biophysical, and socioeconomic domains. The problems and potentials for increasing world food supply based on current agronomic knowledge. Emphasis on international aspects of food crop production as its interrelationships with people and the environment in the developing world.
PLSC303.prerequisite: BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

PLSC400.title: Plant Physiology
PLSC400.description: A survey of plant physiology and development responses and adaptation to the environment.
PLSC400.prerequisite: BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105; or PLSC201. And CHEM231 and CHEM232; or CHEM237; or permission of AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department.

PLSC401.title: Pest Management Strategies for Turfgrass
PLSC401.description: Interdisciplinary view of weed, disease, and insect management from an agronomy perspective. Plant responses to pest invasion, diagnosis of pest-related disorders, and principles of weed, disease and insect suppression through cultural, biological and chemical means are discussed.

PLSC407.title: Advanced Crop Science
PLSC407.description: A study of principles of production for forage crops, corn, small grains, rice, millets, sorghums, soybeans and other oil seed crops. Their seed production, processing, distribution and the current federal and state seed control programs for these agronomic crops will also be discussed.
PLSC407.prerequisite: PLSC101. And BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105.

PLSC410.title: Commercial Turf Maintenance and Production
PLSC410.description: Agronomic programs and practices used in hydroseeding, commercial lawn care, sod production and seed production. Current environmental, regulatory and business management issues confronting the turfgrass industry.
PLSC410.prerequisite: PLSC305; or permission of AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department.

PLSC425.title: Green Roofs and Urban Sustainability
PLSC425.description: The integration of disciplines associated with sustainability issues. Topics range from plant science to design to policy, all of which can contribute to improving the urban environment.

PLSC432.title: Greenhouse Crop Production
PLSC432.description: The commercial production and marketing of ornamental plant crops under greenhouse, plastic houses and out-of-door conditions.
PLSC432.prerequisite: PLSC201 and PLSC202; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BSCI442.

PLSC460.title: Application of Knowledge in Plant Sciences
PLSC460.description: A capstone course based on interactions with plant science professional and student-led class discussions. Students will apply their knowledge and experience to practical issues in the discipline, further develop critical thinking ability, and enhance their communication, teamwork, and professional skills. Topics will include nutrient management, integrated pest management, plant interactions with urban and rural ecosystems, planning of public grounds, plant biotechnology, and teaching skills.
PLSC460.prerequisite: PLSC100 or PLSC101; or permission of instructor.
PLSC460.restriction: Senior standing or higher. And must be in a major within AGNR-Plant Science & Landscape Architecture department; or must be in another related major.

PLSC471.title: Forest Ecology
PLSC471.description: An understanding of the forest ecosystem, its structure and the processes that regulate it are provided. It also considers changes that occur in forests, the interaction of environment and genetics in promoting ecosystem sustainability, and the role of human influences on urban forest ecosystems.
PLSC471.prerequisite: PLSC201; or (BSCI160 and BSCI161); or BSCI106.

PLSC489O.title: Special Topics in Plant Science; Plant Taxonomy

PLSC489W.title: Special Topics in Plant Science; Plant-Microbe Associations

PLSC618.title: Advances in Research; Critiquing Primary Plant Science Literature

PLSC619.title: Seminars in Plant Science and Landscape Architecture

PLSC789M.title: Advances in Research; Plant Membrane Biology

PORT204.title: Intensive Intermediate Portuguese
PORT204.description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of Portuguese-speaking world.
PORT204.prerequisite: PORT104; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.

PORT228C.title: Selected Topics in Latin American Literature and Society; Cannibals, Savages and Carnivalization: The Making of Brazilian National Culture

PORT332.title: Brazilian Cinema
PORT332.description: Brazilian films from the late 1950s to the present with a special view to the relationship between cinema, society, historical dates, and social changes in Brazil.  Taught in English.

PORT386.title: Experiential Learning
PORT386.description: Restriction: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department; and junior standing or higher.
PORT386.restriction: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department; and junior standing or higher.

PORT405.title: Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
PORT405.description: Intensive basic grammar, reading and auditory comprehension. Native or acquired fluency in Spanish required.
PORT405.restriction: Must have native or acquired fluency in Spanish.

PSYC100.title: Introduction to Psychology
PSYC100.description: A basic introductory course, intended to bring the student into contact with the major problems confronting psychology and the more important attempts at their solution.

PSYC123.title: The Psychology of Getting Hired
PSYC123.description: Designed to introduce students to the science behind the hiring process and to prepare individuals with the academic and practical training required.  Together we will explore psychological principles that influence the selection process and how individuals can apply them for the competitive edge that makes others Fear the Turtle!

PSYC200.title: Statistical Methods in Psychology
PSYC200.description: A basic introduction to quantitative methods used in psychological research.
PSYC200.prerequisite: PSYC100. And 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (STAT100, MATH107, MATH111, MATH120, MATH130, MATH140); or must have completed MATH220 with a minimum grade of C-.

PSYC206.title: Developmental Biopsychology
PSYC206.description: Biological basis of behavioral development in relation to genetic, constitutional, anatomical, physiological, and environmental factors. Emphasis upon both phylogenetic and ontogenetic research findings in biological psychology.

PSYC210.title: Personality and Temperament: Developmental Origins, Brain Bases, and Clinical Implications
PSYC210.description: What is known about what makes each of us unique? How do these differences contribute to enduring differences in health & wealth? We will review recent research in humans and non-humans aimed at understanding the psychological & biological mechanisms underlying stable individual differences in personality. We will discuss the phylogenetic and ontogenetic origins of temperament, measurement issues, fundamental dimensions of personality across the lifespan, neurobiological substrates of temperament/personality, mechanisms contributing to stability and change, implications for psychopathology, & broader implications for public/macroeconomic policy.

PSYC221.title: Social Psychology
PSYC221.description: The influence of social factors on the individual and on interpersonal behavior. Includes topics such as conformity, attitude change, person perception, interpersonal attraction, and group behavior.

PSYC289D.title: Living the Good Life: The Psychology of Happiness

PSYC300.title: Research Methods in Psychology Laboratory
PSYC300.description: A general introduction and overview to the fundamental theoretical, conceptual, and practical issues in psychological research in both the laboratory and the field.

PSYC301.title: Biological Basis of Behavior
PSYC301.description: An introduction to the anatomical structures and physiological processe that determine behavior. After a study of the basic functioning of the nervous system, the course will examine the acquisition and processing of sensory information, the neural control of movement, and the biological bases of complex behaviors such as sleep, learning, memory, sex, language, and addiction.
PSYC301.prerequisite: PSYC100. And BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105.

PSYC303.title: Professional Development for Psychology Majors
PSYC303.description: An investigation of various career and graduate school opportunities available to psychology majors. Students will learn about a wide range of career fields, will learn how to utilize available resources to pursue career goals, and will take steps to advance their professional identity and development.
PSYC303.prerequisite: PSYC100; and must have completed 3 additional credits in PSYC courses. Or permission of BSOS-Psychology department.
PSYC303.restriction: Must be in a major within BSOS-Psychology department.

PSYC309I.title: Special Topics in Psychology; Ethical Principles and Practice in Psychology

PSYC330.title: Child Psychopathology
PSYC330.description: Etiology, diagnosis, prevention and treatment of emotional disorders of childhood and adolescence.

PSYC334.title: Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships
PSYC334.description: Research, theory and their practical applications pertaining to the development, maintenance and dissolution of human relationships. Processes critical to successful relating (e.g., communication, bargaining, conflict resolution), and issues associated with troubled dyadic relations with equal partners (e.g., jealousy, spouse abuse, divorce).

PSYC336.title: Psychology of Women
PSYC336.description: A survey of the biology, life span development, socialization, personality, mental health, and special issues of women.

PSYC341.title: Introduction to Memory and Cognition
PSYC341.description: An introduction to the basic concepts of cognitive psychology, the scientific study of mental processes. Topics will include perception, attention, memory, reasoning, and language, with an emphasis on how findings from cognitive psychology can inform real-life thinking (e.g., memory strategies for studying, pitfalls of multitasking, and how/why our memories can fail us).

PSYC353.title: Adult Psychopathology
PSYC353.description: The nature, diagnosis, etiology, and treatment of mental disorders.

PSYC354.title: Multicultural Psychology in the U.S.
PSYC354.description: What are the psychological implications of racism, sexism, homophobia and other structures of inequality in the United States? How do socio-cultural privilege and oppression influence individual and group thoughts, feelings, and behaviors? This course will take a current events focus to understanding multicultural and social justice issues in psychology with an emphasis on self-reflection, mental health, cross-cultural communication, and strategies for social change.

PSYC355.title: Developmental Psychology
PSYC355.description: Survey of research and theory of psychological development from conception through childhood, stressing physiological, conceptual and behavioral changes, and the social and biological context in which individuals develop.

PSYC361.title: Survey of Industrial and Organizational Psychology
PSYC361.description: A general survey of the field of industrial organizational psychology including such topics as organizational entry (recruitment, selection, training, socialization); organizational psychology (motivation, leadership, job attitudes); and productivity in the work place (performance appraisal, absenteeism, turnover). The role that the larger environment plays in influencing work behaviors and work attitudes.

PSYC401.title: Biological Bases of Behavior Laboratory
PSYC401.description: A laboratory course to introduce students to some of the basic physiological and anatomical techniques of contemporary neuroscience. Exercises look at specific neurons or groups of neurons and how they control such simple behaviors as swimming, prey capture, and species recognition. The lab exercises use living invertebrates and cold-blooded vertebrates.
PSYC401.restriction: Permission of instructor; and must be in Psychology program; and must have earned a minimum of 85 credits.

PSYC402.title: Neural Systems and Behavior
PSYC402.description: Research on the physiological basis of behavior, including considerations of sensory phenomenon, motor coordination, emotion, drives, and the neurological basis of memory.

PSYC406.title: Neuroethology
PSYC406.description: A merger between the disciplines of neuroscience and ethology (animal behavior) studies the behavioral functions of nervous systems using a comparative and evolutionary approach. Students will learn how the nervous system controls behavioral patterns in a variety of different organisms ranging from insects to mammals.

PSYC416.title: Development of Attachment in Infancy and Childhood: Theory, Research, Methods, and Clinical Implications
PSYC416.description: Overview of the development of attachment during infancy and childhood, examining theory, research methods, research findings, and clinical implications.  Students will observe videos of attachment assessments, lead class discussion of readings, make class presentations, and complete writing assignments.
PSYC416.restriction: Must be in a major within the BSOS-Psychology department.

PSYC420.title: Experimental Psychology: Social Psychology Laboratory
PSYC420.description: A laboratory course to provide a basic understanding of experimental method in social psychology and experience in conducting research on social processes.
PSYC420.restriction: Must be in Psychology program; and must have earned a minimum of 85 credits.

PSYC425.title: Psychology and Law
PSYC425.description: An introduction to the intersection of psychology and the criminal justice sytem, known as the field of legal psychology. The material covered will span the course of the criminal justice process and examine each aspect from a psychological perspective beginning with profiling and moving on to eyewitness memory and judgements through perpetrator memories and interrogation techniques. These apsects will be evaluated with a research lens as well as an applied outlook.

PSYC432.title: Counseling Psychology: Theories, Research, and Practice
PSYC432.description: Analysis of research and intervention strategies developed and used by counseling psychologists. Historical and current trends in content and methodology.

PSYC433.title: Basic Helping Skills: Research and Practice
PSYC433.description: Theories and research regarding effective helping relationships, with a focus on applications to counseling and psychotherapy. Students will practice helping skills with each other and will conduct research projects evaluating their helping skills. Students should be willing to talk about personal issues in class. Attendance in labs is mandatory and contributes to the course grade; thus, students should only enroll in a lab section that they will be able to attend consistently.
PSYC433.restriction: Must be in Psychology program; and must have earned a minimum of 85 credits; and must not have completed or be concurrently enrolled in EDCP 310.

PSYC436.title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology: From Science to Practice
PSYC436.description: Critical analysis of clinical psychology, with particular emphasis on current developments and trends.

PSYC437.title: The Assessment and Treatment of Addictive Behaviors
PSYC437.description: Explores the current research in assessment and treatment of addictive behaviors. Topics may include addictions in the areas of alcohol, drugs, nicotine, gambling, and eating.
PSYC437.prerequisite: PSYC100; and 9 credits in PSYC courses.

PSYC440.title: Experimental Psychology: Cognitive Processes
PSYC440.description: A survey of the content, models, and methods in cognitive psychology with an emphasis on auditory and visual pattern recognition, information processing, attention, memory, learning, problem solving, and language.
PSYC440.restriction: Must be in Psychology program; and must have earned a minimum of 85 credits.

PSYC468H.title: Field Experience and Special Assignments in Honors

PSYC489C.title: Advanced Special Topics in Psychology; Early Social Cognition

PSYC489D.title: Advanced Special Topics in Psychology; Data Science for Psychology and Neuroscience I

PSYC489G.title: Advanced Special Topics in Psychology; Hormones and Behavior

PSYC602.title: Quantitative Methods II
PSYC602.description: A continuation of PSYC 601. Topics include experimental design, analysi of variance, analysis of covariance, multiple regression, and general linear models.

PSYC603.title: Introduction to Industrial and Organizational Psychology
PSYC603.description: Advanced survey of industrial-organizational psychology, including selection, training, motivation, group processes, leadership, organizational psychology, and organizational theory. Readings stressed and seminar time will be used for lectures, discussion and integration of the reading materials.

PSYC611.title: Advanced Developmental Psychology
PSYC611.description: Systematic exploration of contemporary and classic theories of development focusing on the assumptions they make and research they generate.

PSYC622.title: Research Methods in Clinical Psychology
PSYC622.description: Examines issues and strategies in conceptual systems, designs and methodologies of current research in clinical and community psychology. Readings include critical analyses of published research. Course requirements include preparation of a research proposal for a thesis level study.

PSYC623.title: Child Psychopathology
PSYC623.description: Examines the scientific and clinical literature relevant to normal and pathological behavior in children and adolescents. Issues in developmental psychopathology and consideration of processes initiated in childhood which manifest as pathology in adulthood are also considered.
PSYC623.restriction: Permission of instructor; and must be in one of the following programs (Psychology (Master's); Psychology (Doctoral)).

PSYC625.title: Clinical Assessment: Psychometric Principles, Testing and Behavior
PSYC625.description: An examination of fundamental principles of psychological assessment; application of these principles to the development of evidence-based assessments of clinical conditions and associated behaviors; and application of evidence-based assessments to the evaluation and understanding of clinical conditions evaluated and treated in therapeutic settings.

PSYC630.title: Behavioral and Cognitive Behavioral Intervention for Adults
PSYC630.description: Introduces students to the process of therapy with particular focus on behavioral focus on behavioral and cognitive behavioral internentions. Syllabus focuses on theory, research, client diversity, ehtics, and practical aspects of conducting therapy.

PSYC632.title: Behavioral and Cognitive Behavioral Intervention for Children and Adolescents
PSYC632.description: Introduces students to the process of therapy with particular focus on behavioral and cognitive behavioral interventions in children and adolescents. Syllabus focuses on theory, research, client diversity, ethics and practical aspects of conducting therapy.
PSYC632.restriction: Permission of instructor; and must be in one of the following programs (Psychology (Master's); Psychology (Doctoral)).

PSYC638.title: Externship in Professional Psychology; Externship in Professional Psychology

PSYC639.title: Internship in Professional Psychology; Internship in Professional Psychology

PSYC654.title: Advanced Analytical Thinking: Statistical Methods at Work II
PSYC654.description: Students will delve deeply into issues of interpreting and questioning analytic results. Students will learn how to creatively present empirical results in ways that grab the attention of, and are clear to, a variety of stakeholders. Students will present group projects in two presentations, one to the rest of the class (technical audience) and one to an expert panel of practitioners. Finally, this course will introduce students conceptually to a number of advanced statistical methods, such as meta-analysis and structural equation modeling.
PSYC654.restriction: Must be in the Master of Professional Studies in Industrial/Organizational Psychology Program.

PSYC655.title: Talent Development
PSYC655.description: In this course, students will learn how to design and implement effective employee training programs as well as how to encourage informal learning in organizations. This course will review current theories in adult learning (e.g., ADDIE model, action learning, peer feedback/coaching), several popular assessment tools (e.g., MBTI), and best practices for evaluating training programs. Issues relevant to leadership identification and development, including succession planning, will also be covered. As part of this course, students will work in teams to design and deliver a brief training module and practice giving and receiving feedback. Additionally, students will complete, and facilitate a debriefing on, a 360-degree feedback assessment.
PSYC655.restriction: Must be in the Master of Professional Studies in Industrial/Organizational Psychology Program.

PSYC690.title: Research in Counseling Psychology I
PSYC690.description: Critical analysis of strategies methodological, conceptual, and content trends.

PSYC737.title: Research Methods in Industrial/Organizational Psychology
PSYC737.description: Philosophy, theory, and method issues underlying I/O psychology. History and the effectiveness of different methods for answering different questions is explored. Reliability and validity are emphasized.

PSYC757.title: Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYC757.description: Developmental cognitive neuroscience investigates the relations between neural and cognitive development. This course provides an overview of current research questions, methodologies and findings related to neurocognitive development in human infants and children, the role of developmental plasticity, and atypical outcomes, such as those observed in neurodevelopmental disorders.
PSYC757.restriction: Must be in one of the following programs (Psychology (Master's); Psychology (Doctoral); Neurosciences and Cognitive Sciences (Doctoral)) ; or permission of BSOS-Psychology department.

PSYC788B.title: Special Research Problems; Ethics in Scientific Research

PSYC798T.title: Graduate Seminar; Intermediate Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging

PSYC888A.title: Research Methods in Psychology; Reserach Methods in Psychology: Development Seminar

PSYC888E.title: Research Methods in Psychology; Selection and Diversity

RDEV250.title: People, Planet, and Profit: Building Sustainable Places
RDEV250.description: An introduction to building communities, commonly referred to as real estate development and involving  multiple professions and disciplines, including Architecture and Urban Design, Community Planning, Historic Preservation, Landscape Architecture, Civil Engineering, Law, Finance and Accounting,  that have to come together to build more sustainable places for the future by emphasizing the quadruple bottom line of: (1) financial viability, (2)environmental sensitivity, (3) social/cultural responsibility and (4) sustainable  design.    The course will provide students with an understanding of the fundamental principles and processes of  these disciplines and examine the intersections between them. Students will learn  through field studies, lecture, discussion, presentations and interactions with multiple professionals

RDEV350.title: Real Estate Development: Introduction to Principles, Process, and Practice
RDEV350.description: An introduction to the basic principles of real estate development: How real estate and communities get built and how value is created. The emphasis is on entrepreneurship  and an experiential   learning approach to the entrepreneurial real estate development process, principles, and practice.
RDEV350.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in RDEV250.

RDEV450.title: Foundations of Real Estate Finance and Investment
RDEV450.description: Real Estate Finance and Investment addresses how real estate value is established, the fundamental foundations of  the time value of money, as well as more real estate specific applications of  return on investment, net operating income,  the components of a real estate sources and uses statement, sources of  real estate equity and debt financing, commonly used debt ratios and equity returns in real estate,   as well as concepts of sensitivity analysis and  exit strategies.
RDEV450.prerequisite: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in RDEV250. And RDEV270; or an approved accounting course. And must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in RDEV350.

RDEV600.title: Principles and Practice of Real Property Development
RDEV600.description: An introduction to basic principles of real estate development: How real estate and communities get built and how value is created. The emphasis is on entrepreneurship and an experiential learning approach to the entrepreneurial real estate development process, principles, and practice.

RDEV603.title: Introduction to Real Property Finance
RDEV603.description: Introduction to Real Property Finance addresses how real estate value is established, the fundamental foundations of the time value of money, as well as more real estate specific applications of return on investment, net operating income, the components of a real estate sources and uses statement, sources of real estate equity and debt financing, commonly used debt ratios and equity returns in real estate, as well as concepts of sensitivity analysis and exit strategies.

RDEV610.title: Real Property Development Law and Ethics
RDEV610.description: Presents foundational knowledge about real property, contracts, administrative and constitutional law, and ethical principals and reasoning skills.

RDEV615.title: Principles, Process and Politics of Planning for Real Property Development
RDEV615.description: Designed to introduce and familiarize students with planning and zoning and the associated processes and requirements that impact the real property development process and products. It will look at the roles the community and politics play in shaping the built environment and the development process.

RDEV630.title: Real Property Finance and Investment
RDEV630.description: This course is designed to introduce students who have experience  in real estate finance or  have taken an introductory course in real estate finance and investment  to  move to this intermediate course that  addresses foundational concepts of commercial real estate finance and the measures used in analyzing and evaluating real estate projects. Quantitative analysis and financial modeling comprise the main focus.

RDEV650.title: Essentials of Design and Construction Management for Development Professionals
RDEV650.description: Essential terminology, process and substantative knowledge needed by development professionals to effectively move a project through the design and construction process; includes environmental and ethical considerations throughout the process.
RDEV650.restriction: Must be in Real Estate Development (Master's) program; or permission of ARCH-Real Estate Development.

RDEV689E.title: Current Topics in Real Estate Development; Structured Finance

RDEV689F.title: Current Topics in Real Estate Development; Affordable Housing Finance

RDEV689I.title: Current Topics in Real Estate Development; Design and Development Competition

RDEV689P.title: Current Topics in Real Estate Development; Introduction to International Development

RDEV689R.title: Current Topics in Real Estate Development; Retail Real Estate Development and Asset Management

RDEV689Y.title: Current Topics in Real Estate Development; Guided Real Estate Development Project

RDEV690.title: Capstone Project: Real Property Feasibility Study
RDEV690.description: The capstone course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to apply acquired classroom knowledge to real world conditions.  Each student in the class will work separately to create a development proposal and feasibility study for an assigned property. For students doing a  feasibility study of a  development  the study will address at least market analysis, entitlement process, construction, and financing for the project.
RDEV690.prerequisite: Completion of at least 7 RDEV courses.

RELS170.title: Greek and Roman Mythology
RELS170.description: An introduction to the mythology of ancient Greece and Rome. This cours is particularly recommended for students planning to major in foreign languages, English, history, the fine arts, or journalism. Taught in English.

RELS219A.title: Special Topics in Religious Studies; Religions of the Ancient Near East

RELS219B.title: Special Topics in Religious Studies; Conquest, Conversion, or Convivencia? Conflict and Toleranceamong Jews, Christians, and Muslims in the Medieval Spains

RELS219C.title: Special Topics in Religious Studies; The Rabbinic Movement: History and Culture

RELS319N.title: Special Topics in Religious Studies; Introduction to Native American Cultures of the United States

RELS343.title: The European Reformations
RELS343.description: Examination of developments in European religion between 1450 and 1700; the late-medieval Church and its critics; rise of Protestant thought in Germany and its spread throughout Europe; reform efforts in the Catholic Church; religious wars and violence and their impact on state and society; consequences of religious reform in society and its impact on the family and women.
RELS343.prerequisite: HIST112 or HIST111; or permission of instructor.

RELS419C.title: Advanced Topics in Religious Studies; History & Memory in Medieval Islam

RELS419D.title: Advanced Topics in Religious Studies; Jews in Early Modern Times 1450-1750

RELS419W.title: Advanced Topics in Religious Studies; Islam in Europe

RELS419X.title: Advanced Topics in Religious Studies; History of Iran in the Islamic Period (7th Century to the   Present)

RELS429M.title: Advanced Topics in Religious History; From Damascus to Cordoba: The First Dynasty of Islam East   and West

RUSS102.title: Intensive Elementary Russian II
RUSS102.description: A continuation of RUSS101 which will further develop the four skills: reading, writing, listening and speaking with an emphasis on communicative competence.
RUSS102.prerequisite: RUSS101 or RUSS102; and must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
RUSS102.restriction: Must not be a native/fluent speaker of Russian.

RUSS202.title: Intermediate Russian II
RUSS202.description: Continued activation and expansion of skills and knowledge acquired in RUSS201 with the goal of communicative competence.
RUSS202.prerequisite: RUSS201; or must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
RUSS202.restriction: Must not be a  native/fluent speaker of Russian.

RUSS298C.title: Special Topics in Russian Language and Literature; Russian Conversation and Phonetics for Intermediate Students

RUSS302.title: Advanced Russian II
RUSS302.description: Advanced training in written Russian communicative structures.

RUSS321.title: Survey of Russian Literature I
RUSS321.description: The first half of a survey of Russian literature.
RUSS321.prerequisite: RUSS202; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

RUSS334.title: Soviet Film: Propaganda, Myth, Modernism
RUSS334.description: A Survey of Soviet film from the 1920s to 1991, focusing on important directors, genres, themes, and styles. Taught in English.

RUSS386.title: Experiential Learning
RUSS386.description: Restriction: Junior standing or higher; and permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.
RUSS386.restriction: Junior standing or higher; and permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

RUSS398E.title: Selected Topics in Russian Language and Literature; Russian Emigre Literature and Culture

RUSS402.title: Practicum in Written Russian
RUSS402.description: Designed to improve comprehension of functional varieties of written Russian and develop ability to present in written form concise syntheses of source texts.
RUSS402.prerequisite: RUSS401; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

SLAA620.title: Second Language Research Methodologies
SLAA620.description: An exploration of research methodology in second language acquisition (SLA), with a focus on developing practical skills in data analysis and interpretation.  Preparation in both critical evaluation of existing research and design of new research models.
SLAA620.prerequisite: SLAA610; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in SLAA611.

SLAA640.title: Psycholinguistics
SLAA640.description: An introduction to the field of psycholinguistics that covers speech perception, word recognition, sentence and discourse processing, speech production, and language acquisition. Basic concepts, research methods, major research topics, leading theories and related research findings, with implications of psycholinguistic theories and findings for second language studies.
SLAA640.prerequisite: SLAA610; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

SLAA649R.title: Special Topics in Second Language Acquisition; Research Critique

SLAA719.title: Second Language Acquisition and Application Internship

SLAA749P.title: Special Topics in Second Language Learning; Bilingual Language Processing

SLAA754.title: Task-Based Language Teaching
SLAA754.description: Overview of Task-Based Language Teaching (TBLT) including needs and means analysis, syllabus design, materials writing, methodology and pedagogy, testing, and evaluation. Theoretical issues addressed include relationship of TBLT to research findings on the psychology of learning and SLA and libertarian approaches to education.

SLAA773.title: The Heritage Language Speaker
